10149{_}492{_}"The Hajjis," repeated Grace laughing, though she blushed to the eyes.
10149{_}493{_}The baronet looked from one cousin to the other, and then turned an inquiring glance on Mademoiselle Viefville.
10149{_}494{_}The latter gave a slight shrug, and seemed to ask an explanation of the young lady's meaning herself.
10149{_}495{_}"A Hajji is one of a class, Sir George Templemore," Eve at length said, "to which you and I have both the honour of belonging."
10149{_}496{_}"No, not Sir George Templemore," interrupted Grace, with a precipitation that she instantly regretted; "he is not an American."
10149{_}497{_}"Then I, alone, of all present, have that honour.
10149{_}498{_}It means the pilgrimage to Paris, instead of Mecca; and the Pilgrim must be an American, instead of a Mahommedan."
10149{_}499{_}"Nay, Eve, _you_ are not a Hajji, neither."
10149{_}500{_}"Then there is some qualification with which I am not yet acquainted.
10149{_}501{_}Will you relieve our doubts, Grace, and let us know the precise character of the animal."
10149{_}502{_}"_You_ stayed too long to be a Hajji--- one must get innoculated merely; not take the disease and become cured, to be a true Hajji."
10149{_}503{_}"I thank you, Miss Van Cortlandt, for this description," returned Eve in her quiet way.
10149{_}504{_}"I hope, as I have gone through the malady, it has not left me pitted."
10149{_}505{_}"I should like to see one of these Hajjis," cried Sir George.--"Are they of both sexes?"
10149{_}506{_}Grace laughed and nodded her head.
10149{_}507{_}"Will you point it out to me, should we be so fortunate as to encounter one this evening?"
10149{_}508{_}Again Grace laughed and nodded her head.
10149{_}509{_}"I have been thinking, Grace," said Eve, after a short pause, "that we may give Sir George Templemore a better idea of the sets about which he is so curious, by doing what is no more than a duty of our own, and by letting him profit by the opportunity.
10149{_}510{_}Mrs. Hawker receives this evening without ceremony; we have not yet sent our answer to Mrs. Jarvis, and might very well look in upon her for half an hour, after which we shall be in very good season for Mrs. Houston's ball."
10149{_}511{_}"Surely, Eve, you would not wish to take Sir George Templemore to such a house as that of Mrs.
10149{_}512{_}Jarvis!"
10149{_}513{_}"_I_ do not wish to take Sir George Templemore any where, for your Hajjis have opinions of their own on such subjects.
10149{_}514{_}But, as cousin Jack will accompany us, _he_ may very well confer that important favour.
10149{_}515{_}I dare say, Mrs. Jarvis will not look upon it as too great a liberty."
10149{_}516{_}"I will answer for it, that nothing Mr. John Effingham can do will be thought _mal a propos_ by Mrs. Jared Jarvis.
10149{_}517{_}His position in society is too well established, and hers is too equivocal, to leave any doubt on that head."
10149{_}518{_}"This, you perceive, settles the point of _coteries,_" said Eve to the baronet.
10149{_}519{_}"Volumes might be written to establish principles; but when one can do any thing he or she pleases, any where that he or she likes, it is pretty safe to say that he or she is privileged."
10149{_}520{_}"All very true, as to the fact, Miss Effingham; but I should like exceedingly to know the reason."
10149{_}521{_}"Half the time, such things are decided without a reason at all.
10149{_}522{_}You are a little exacting in requiring a reason in New-York for that which is done in London without even the pretence of such a thing.
10149{_}523{_}It is sufficient that Mrs. Jarvis will be delighted to see you without an invitation, and that Mrs. Houston would, at least, think it odd, were you to take the same liberty with her."
10149{_}524{_}"It follows," said Sir George, smiling, "that Mrs. Jarvis is much the most hospitable person of the two."
10149{_}525{_}"But, Eve, what shall be done with Captain Truck and Mr.
10149{_}526{_}Bragg?"
10149{_}527{_}asked Grace.
10149{_}528{_}"We cannot take _them_ to Mrs.
10149{_}529{_}Hawker's!"
10149{_}530{_}"Aristabulus would, indeed, be a little out of place in such a house, but as for our excellent, brave, straight-forward, old captain, he is worthy to go any where.
10149{_}531{_}I shall be delighted to present _him_ to Mrs. Hawker, myself."
10149{_}532{_}After a little consultation between the ladies, it was settled that nothing should be said of the two first visits to Mr. Bragg, but that Mr. Effingham should be requested to bring him to the ball, at the proper hour, and that the rest of the party should go quietly off to the other places, without mentioning their projects.
10149{_}533{_}As soon as this was arranged the ladies retired to dress, Sir George Templemore passing into the library to amuse himself with a book the while; where, however, he was soon joined by John Effingham.
10149{_}534{_}Here the former revived the conversation on distinctions in society, with the confusion of thought that usually marks a European's notions of such matters.
10149{_}535{_}Chapter IV.
10149{_}536{_}"Ready."
10149{_}537{_}"And I."
10149{_}538{_}"And I."
10149{_}539{_}"Where shall we go?"
10149{_}540{_}MIDSUMMER-NIGHT'S DREAM.
10149{_}541{_}Grace Van Cortlant was the first to make her appearance after the retreat from the drawing-room.
10149{_}542{_}It has often been said that, pretty as the American females incontestably are, as a whole they appear better in _demi-toilette,_ than when attired for a ball.
10149{_}543{_}With what would be termed high dress in other parts of the world, they are little acquainted; but reversing the rule of Europe, where the married bestow the most care on their personal appearance, and the single are taught to observe a rigid simplicity, Grace now seemed sufficiently ornamented in the eyes of the fastidious baronet, while, at the same time, he thought her less obnoxious to the criticism just mentioned, than most of her young countrywomen, in general.
10149{_}544{_}An _embonpoint_ that was just sufficient to distinguish her from most of her companions, a fine colour, brilliant eyes, a sweet smile, rich hair, and such feet and hands as Sir George Templemore had, somehow-- he scarcely knew how, himself--fancied could only belong to the daughters of peers and princes, rendered Grace so strikingly attractive this evening, that the young baronet began to think her even handsomer than her cousin.
10149{_}545{_}There was also a charm in the unsophisticated simplicity of Grace, that was particularly alluring to a man educated amidst the coldness and mannerism of the higher classes of England.
10149{_}546{_}In Grace, too, this simplicity was chastened by perfect decorum and _retenue_ of deportment; the exuberance of the new school of manners not having helped to impair the dignity of her character, or to weaken the charm of diffidence.
10149{_}547{_}She was less finished in her manners than Eve, certainly; a circumstance, perhaps, that induced Sir George Templemore to fancy her a shade more simple, but she was never unfeminine or unladylike; and the term vulgar, in despite of all the capricious and arbitrary rules of fashion, under no circumstances, could ever be applied to Grace Van Cortlandt.
10149{_}548{_}In this respect, nature seemed to have aided her; for had not her associations raised her above such an imputation, no one could believe that she would be obnoxious to the charge, had her lot in life been cast even many degrees lower than it actually was.
10149{_}549{_}It is well known that, after a sufficient similarity has been created by education to prevent any violent shocks to our habits or principles, we most affect those whose characters and dispositions the least resemble our own.
10149{_}550{_}This was probably one of the reasons why Sir George Templemore, who, for some time, had been well assured of the hopelessness of his suit with Eve, began to regard her scarcely less lovely cousin, with an interest of a novel and lively nature.
10149{_}551{_}Quick-sighted and deeply interested in Grace's happiness, Miss Effingham had already detected this change in the young baronet's inclinations, and though sincerely rejoiced on her own account, she did not observe it without concern; for she understood better than most of her countrywomen, the great hazards of destroying her peace of mind, that are incurred by transplanting an American woman into the more artificial circles of the old world.
10149{_}552{_}"I shall rely on your kind offices, in particular, Miss Van Cortlandt, to reconcile Mrs. Jarvis and Mrs. Hawker to the liberty I am about to take," cried Sir George, as Grace burst upon them in the library, in a blaze of beauty that, in her case, was aided by her attire; "and cold-hearted and unchristian-like women they must be, indeed, to resist such a mediator!"
10149{_}553{_}Grace was unaccustomed to adulation of this sort; for though the baronet spoke gaily, and like one half trifling, his look of admiration was too honest to escape the intuitive perception of woman.
10149{_}554{_}She blushed deeply, and then recovering herself instantly, said with a _naivete_ that had a thousand charms with her listener--  "I do not see why Miss Effingham and myself should hesitate about introducing you at either place.
10149{_}555{_}Mrs. Hawker is a relative and an intimate--an intimate of mine, at least--and as for poor Mrs. Jarvis, she is the daughter of an old neighbour, and will be too glad to see us, to raise objections.
10149{_}556{_}I fancy any one of a certain--" Grace hesitated and laughed.
10149{_}557{_}"Any one of a certain--?"
10149{_}558{_}said Sir George inquiringly.
10149{_}559{_}"Any one from this house," resumed the young lady, correcting the intended expression, "will be welcome in Spring street."
10149{_}560{_}"Pure, native aristocracy!"
10149{_}561{_}exclaimed the baronet with an air of affected triumph.
10149{_}562{_}"This you see, Mr. John Effingham, is in aid of my argument."
10149{_}563{_}"I am quite of your opinion," returned the gentleman addressed--"as much native aristocracy as you please, but no hereditary."
10149{_}564{_}The entrance of Eve and Mademoiselle Viefville interrupted this pleasantry, and the carriages being just then announced, John Effingham went in quest of Captain Truck, who was in the drawing-room with Mr. Effingham and Aristabulus.
10149{_}565{_}"I have left Ned to discuss trespass suits and leases with his land- agent," said John Effingham, as he followed Eve to the street-door.
10149{_}566{_}"By ten o'clock, they will have taxed a pretty bill of costs between them!"
10149{_}567{_}Mademoiselle Viefville followed John Effingham; Grace came next, and Sir George Templemore and the Captain brought up the rear.
10149{_}568{_}Grace wondered the young baronet did not offer her his arm, for she had been accustomed to receive this attention from the other sex, in a hundred situations in which it was rather an incumbrance than a service; while on the other hand, Sir George himself would have hesitated about offering such assistance, as an act of uncalled-for familiarity.
10149{_}569{_}Miss Van Cortlandt, being much in society, kept a chariot for her own use, and the three ladies took their seats in it, while the gentlemen took possession of Mr. Effingham's coach.
10149{_}570{_}The order was given to drive to Spring street, and the whole party proceeded.
10149{_}571{_}The acquaintance between the Effinghams and Mr. Jarvis had arisen from the fact of their having been near, and, in a certain sense, sociable neighbours in the country.
10149{_}572{_}Their town associations, however, were as distinct as if they dwelt in different hemispheres, with the exception of an occasional morning call, and, now and then, a family dinner given by Mr. Effingham.
10149{_}573{_}Such had been the nature of the intercourse previously to the family of the latter's having gone abroad, and there were symptoms of its being renewed on the same quiet and friendly footing as formerly.
10149{_}574{_}But no two beings could be less alike, in certain essentials, than Mr. Jarvis and his wife.
10149{_}575{_}The former was a plain pains-taking, sensible man of business, while the latter had an itching desire to figure in the world of fashion.
10149{_}576{_}The first was perfectly aware that Mr. Effingham, in education, habits, associations and manners, was, at least, of a class entirely distinct from his own; and without troubling himself to analyze causes, and without a feeling of envy, or unkindness of any sort, while totally exempt from any undue deference or unmanly cringing, he quietly submitted to let things take their course.
10149{_}577{_}His wife expressed her surprise that any one in New-York should presume to be _better_ than themselves; and the remark gave rise to the following short conversation, on the very morning of the day she gave the party, to which we are now conducting the reader.
10149{_}578{_}"How do you know, my dear, that any one does think himself our _better_?"
10149{_}579{_}demanded the husband.
10149{_}580{_}"Why do they not all visit us then!"
10149{_}581{_}"Why do you not visit everybody yourself?
10149{_}582{_}A pretty household we should have, if you did nothing but visit every one who lives even in this street!"
10149{_}583{_}"You surely would not have _me_ visiting the grocers' wives at the corners, and all the other rubbish of the neighbourhood.
10149{_}584{_}What I mean is that all the people of a certain sort ought to visit all the other people of a certain sort, in the same town."
10149{_}585{_}"You surely will make an exception, at least on account of numbers.
10149{_}586{_}I saw number three thousand six hundred and fifty this very day on a cart, and if the wives of all these carmen should visit one another, each would have to make ten visits daily in order to get through with the list in a twelvemonth."
10149{_}587{_}"I have always bad luck in making you comprehend these things, Mr.
10149{_}588{_}Jarvis."
10149{_}589{_}"I am afraid, my dear, it is because you do not very clearly comprehend them yourself.
10149{_}590{_}You first say that everybody ought to visit everybody, and then you insist on it, _you_ will visit none but those you think good enough to be visited by Mrs. Jared Jarvis."
10149{_}591{_}"What I mean is, that no one in New-York has a right to think himself, or herself, better than ourselves."
10149{_}592{_}"Better?--In what sense better?"
10149{_}593{_}"In such a sense as to induce them to think themselves too good to visit us."
10149{_}594{_}"That may be your opinion, my dear, but others may judge differently.
10149{_}595{_}You clearly think yourself too good to visit Mrs. Onion, the grocer's wife, who is a capital woman in her way; and how do we know that certain people may not fancy we are not quite refined enough for them?
10149{_}596{_}Refinement is a positive thing, Mrs. Jarvis, and one that has much more influence on the pleasures of association than money.
10149{_}597{_}We may want a hundred little perfections that escape our ignorance, and which those who are trained to such matters deem essentials."
10149{_}598{_}"I never met with a man of so little social spirit, Mr. Jarvis!
10149{_}599{_}Really, you are quite unsuited to be a citizen of a republican country."
10149{_}600{_}"Republican!--I do not really see what republican has to do with the question.
10149{_}601{_}In the first place, it is a droll word for _you_ to use in this sense at least; for, taking your own meaning of the term, you are as anti-republican as any woman I know.
10149{_}602{_}But a republic does not necessarily infer equality of condition, or even equality of rights,--it meaning merely the substitution of the right of the commonwealth for the right of a prince.
10149{_}603{_}Had you said a democracy there would have been some plausibility in using the word, though even then its application would have been illogical.
10149{_}604{_}If I am a freeman and a democrat, I hope I have the justice to allow others to be just as free and democratic as I am myself."
10149{_}605{_}"And who wishes the contrary?--all I ask is a claim to be considered a fit associate for anybody in this country--in these United States of America."
10149{_}606{_}"I would quit these United States of America next week, if I thought there existed any necessity for such an intolerable state of things."
10149{_}607{_}"Mr.
10149{_}608{_}Jarvis!--and you, too, one of the Committee of Tammany Hall!"
10149{_}609{_}"Yes, Mrs. Jarvis, and I one of the Committee of Tammany Hall!
10149{_}610{_}What, do you think I want the three thousand six hundred and fifty carmen running in and out of my house, with their tobacco saliva and pipes, all day long?"
10149{_}611{_}"Who is thinking of your carmen and grocers!--I speak now only of genteel people."
10149{_}612{_}"In other words, my dear, you are thinking only of those whom you fancy to have the advantage of you, and keep those who think of you in the same way, quite out of sight This is not my democracy and freedom.
10149{_}613{_}I believe that it requires two people to make a bargain, and although I may consent to dine with A----, if A---- will not consent to dine with me, there is an end of the matter."
10149{_}614{_}"Now, you have come to a case in point.
10149{_}615{_}You often dined with Mr. Effingham before he went abroad, and yet you would never allow me to ask Mr. Effingham to dine with us.
10149{_}616{_}That is what I call meanness."
10149{_}617{_}"It might be so, indeed, if it were done to save my money.
10149{_}618{_}I dined with Mr. Effingham because I like him; because he was an old neighbour; because he asked me, and because I found a pleasure in the quiet elegance of his table and society; and I did not ask him to dine with me, because I was satisfied he would be better pleased with such a tacit acknowledgement of his superiority in this respect, than by any bustling and ungraceful efforts to pay him in kind.
10149{_}619{_}Edward Effingham has dinners enough, without keeping a debtor and credit account with his guests, which is rather too New-Yorkish, even for me."
10149{_}620{_}"Bustling and ungraceful!"
10149{_}621{_}repeated Mrs. Jarvis, bitterly; "I do not know that you are at all more bustling and ungraceful than Mr. Effingham himself."
10149{_}622{_}"No, my dear, I am a quiet, unpretending man, like the great majority of my countrymen, thank God."
10149{_}623{_}"Then why talk of these sorts of differences in a country in which the law establishes none?"
10149{_}624{_}"For precisely the reason that I talk of the river at the foot of this street, or because there is a river.
10149{_}625{_}A thing may exist without there being a law for it.
10149{_}626{_}There is no law for building this house, and yet it is built.
10149{_}627{_}There is no law for making Dr. Verse a better preacher than Dr. Prolix, and yet he is a much better preacher; neither is there any law for making Mr. Effingham a more finished gentleman than I happen to be, and yet I am not fool enough to deny the fact.
10149{_}628{_}In the way of making out a bill of parcels, I will not turn my back to him, I can promise you."
10149{_}629{_}"All this strikes me as being very spiritless, and as particularly anti-republican," said Mrs. Jarvis, rising to quit the room; "and if the Effinghams do not come this evening, I shall not enter their house this winter.
10149{_}630{_}I am sure they have no right to pretend to be our betters, and I feel no disposition to admit the impudent claim."
10149{_}631{_}"Before you go, Jane, let me say a parting word," rejoined the husband, looking for his hat, "which is just this.
10149{_}632{_}If you wish the world to believe you the equal of any one, no matter whom, do not be always talking about it, lest they see you distrust the fact yourself.
10149{_}633{_}A positive thing will surely be seen, and they who have the highest claims are the least disposed to be always pressing them on the attention of the world.
10149{_}634{_}An outrage may certainly be done those social rights which have been established by common consent, and then it may be proper to resent it; but beware betraying a consciousness of your own inferiority, by letting every one see you are jealous of your station.
10149{_}635{_}'Now, kiss me; here is the money to pay for your finery this evening, and let me see you as happy to receive Mrs. Jewett from Albion Place, as you would be to receive Mrs. Hawker herself."
10149{_}636{_}"Mrs.
10149{_}637{_}Hawker!"
10149{_}638{_}cried the wife, with a toss of her head, "I would not cross the street to invite Mrs. Hawker and all her clan."
10149{_}639{_}Which was very true, as Mrs. Jarvis was thoroughly convinced the trouble would be unavailing, the lady in question being as near the head of fashion in New-York, as it was possible to be in a town that, in a moral sense, resembles an encampment, quite as much as it resembles a permanent and a long-existing capital.
10149{_}640{_}Notwithstanding a great deal of management on the part of Mrs. Jarvis to get showy personages to attend her entertainment, the simple elegance of the two carriages that bore the Effingham party, threw all the other equipages into the shade.
10149{_}641{_}The arrival, indeed, was deemed a matter of so much moment, that intelligence was conveyed to the lady, who was still at her post in the inner drawing-room, of the arrival of a party altogether superior to any thing that had yet appeared in her rooms.
10149{_}642{_}It is true, this was not expressed in words, but it was made sufficiently obvious by the breathless haste and the air of importance of Mrs. Jarvis' sister, who had received the news from a servant, and who communicated it _propria persona_ to the mistress of the house.
10149{_}643{_}The simple, useful, graceful, almost indispensable usage of announcing at the door, indispensable to those who receive much, and where there is the risk of meeting people known to us by name and not in person, is but little practised in America.
10149{_}644{_}Mrs. Jarvis would have shrunk from such an innovation, had she known that elsewhere the custom prevailed, but she was in happy ignorance on this point, as on many others that were more essential to the much-coveted social _eclat_ at which she aimed.
10149{_}645{_}When Mademoiselle Viefville appeared, therefore, walking unsupported, as if she were out of leading- strings, followed by Eve and Grace and the gentlemen of their party, she at first supposed there was some mistake, and that her visitors had got into the wrong house; there being an opposition party in the neighbourhood.
10149{_}646{_}"What brazen people!"
10149{_}647{_}whispered Mrs. Abijah Gross, who having removed from an interior New-England village, fully two years previously, fancied herself _an fait_ of all the niceties of breeding and social tact.
10149{_}648{_}"There are positively two young ladies actually walking about without gentlemen!"
10149{_}649{_}But it was not in the power of Mrs. Abijah Gross, with her audible whisper and obvious sneer and laugh, to put down two such lovely creatures as Eve and her cousin.
10149{_}650{_}The simple elegance of their attire, the indescribable air of polish, particularly in the former, and the surpassing beauty and modesty of mien of both, effectually silenced criticism, after this solitary outbreaking of vulgarity.
10149{_}651{_}Mrs. Jarvis recognized Eve and John Effingham, and her hurried compliments and obvious delight proclaimed to all near her, the importance she attached to their visit.
10149{_}652{_}Mademoiselle Viefville she had not recollected in her present dress, and even she was covered with expressions of delight and satisfaction.
10149{_}653{_}"I wish particularly to present to you a friend that we all prize exceedingly," said Eve, as soon as there was an opportunity of speaking.
10149{_}654{_}"This is Captain Truck, the gentleman who commands the Montauk, the ship of which you have heard so much.
10149{_}655{_}Ah!
10149{_}656{_}Mr. Jarvis," offering a hand to him with sincere cordiality, for Eve had known him from childhood, and always sincerely respected him--"_you_ will receive my friend with a cordial welcome, I am certain."
10149{_}657{_}She then explained to Mr. Jarvis who the honest captain was, when the former, first paying the proper respect to his other guests, led the old sailor aside, and began an earnest conversation on the subject of the recent passage.
10149{_}658{_}John Effingham presented the baronet, whom Mrs. Jarvis, out of pure ignorance of his rank in his own country, received with perfect propriety and self-respect.
10149{_}659{_}"We have very few people of note in town at present, I believe," said Mrs. Jarvis to John Effingham.
10149{_}660{_}"A great traveller, a most interesting man, is the only person of that sort I could obtain for this evening, and I shall have great pleasure in introducing you.
10149{_}661{_}He is there in that crowd, for he is in the greatest possible demand; he has seen so much.--Mrs.
10149{_}662{_}Snow, with your permission--really the ladies are thronging about him as if he were a Pawnee,--have the goodness to step a little this way, Mr. Effingham--Miss Effingham--Mrs.
10149{_}663{_}Snow, just touch his arm and let him know I wish to introduce a couple of friends.--Mr.
10149{_}664{_}Dodge, Mr. John Effingham, Miss Effingham, Miss Van Cortlandt.
10149{_}665{_}I hope you may succeed in getting him a little to yourselves, ladies, for he can tell you all about Europe--saw the king of France riding out to Nully, and has a prodigious knowledge of things on the other side of the water."
10149{_}666{_}It required a good deal of Eve's habitual self-command to prevent a smile, but she had the tact and discretion to receive Steadfast as an utter stranger.
10149{_}667{_}John Effingham bowed as haughtily as man can bow, and then it was whispered that he and Mr.
10149{_}668{_}Dodge were rival travellers.
10149{_}669{_}The distance of the former, coupled with an expression of countenance that did not invite familiarity, drove nearly all the company over to the side of Steadfast, who, it was soon settled, had seen much the most of the world, understood society the best, and had moreover travelled as far as Timbuctoo in Africa.
10149{_}670{_}The _clientele_ of Mr.
10149{_}671{_}Dodge increased rapidly, as these reports spread in the rooms, and those who had not read the "delightful letters published in the Active Inquirer," furiously envied those who had enjoyed that high advantage.
10149{_}672{_}"It is Mr.
10149{_}673{_}Dodge, the great traveller," said one young lady, who had extricated herself from the crowd around the 'lion,' and taken a station near Eve and Grace, and who, moreover, was a 'blue' in her own set; "his beautiful and accurate descriptions have attracted great attention in England, and it is said they have actually been republished!"
10149{_}674{_}"Have you read them, Miss Brackett?"
10149{_}675{_}"Not the letters themselves, absolutely; but all the remarks on them in the last week's Hebdomad.
10149{_}676{_}Most delightful letters, judging from those remarks; full of nature and point, and singularly accurate in all their facts.
10149{_}677{_}In this respect they are invaluable, travellers do fall into such extraordinary errors!"
10149{_}678{_}"I hope, ma'am," said John Effingham, gravely, "that the gentleman has avoided the capital mistake of commenting on things that actually exist.
10149{_}679{_}Comments on its facts are generally esteemed by the people of a country, impertinent and unjust; and your true way to succeed, is to treat as freely as possible its imaginary peculiarities."
10149{_}680{_}Miss Brackett had nothing to answer to this observation, the Hebdomad having, among its other profundities, never seen proper to touch on the subject.
10149{_}681{_}She went on praising the "Letters," however, not one of which had she read, or would she read; for this young lady had contrived to gain a high reputation in her own _coterie_ for taste and knowledge in books, by merely skimming the strictures of those who do not even skim the works they pretend to analyze.
10149{_}682{_}Eve had never before been in so close contact with so much flippant ignorance, and she could not but wonder at seeing a man like her kinsman overlooked, in order that a man like Mr.
10149{_}683{_}Dodge should be preferred.
10149{_}684{_}All this gave John Effingham himself no concern, but retiring a little from the crowd, he entered into a short conversation with the young baronet.
10149{_}685{_}"I should like to know your real opinions of this set," he said; "not that I plead guilty to the childish sensibility that is so common in all provincial circles to the judgments of strangers, but with a view to aid you in forming a just estimate of the real state of the country."
10149{_}686{_}"As I know the precise connexion between you and our host, there can be no objection to giving a perfectly frank reply.
10149{_}687{_}The women strike me as being singularly delicate and pretty; well dressed, too, I might add; but, while there is a great air of decency, there is very little high finish; and what strikes me as being quite odd, under such circumstances, scarcely any downright vulgarity, or coarseness."
10149{_}688{_}"A Daniel come to judgment!
10149{_}689{_}One who had passed a life here, would not have come so near the truth, simply because he would not have observed peculiarities, that require the means of comparison to be detected.
10149{_}690{_}You are a little too indulgent in saying there is no downright vulgarity; for some there is; though surprisingly little for the circumstances.
10149{_}691{_}But of the coarseness that would be so prominent elsewhere, there is hardly any.
10149{_}692{_}True, so great is the equality in all things, in this country, so direct the tendency to this respectable mediocrity, that what you now see here, to-night, may be seen in almost every village in the land, with a few immaterial exceptions in the way of furniture and other city appliances, and not much even in these."
10149{_}693{_}"Certainly, as a mediocrity, this is respectable though a fastidious taste might see a multitude of faults."
10149{_}694{_}"I shall not say that the taste would be merely fastidious, for much is wanting that would add to the grace and beauty of society, while much that is wanting would be missed only by the over-sophisticated.
10149{_}695{_}Those young-men, who are sniggering over some bad joke in the corner, for instance, are positively vulgar, as is that young lady who is indulging in practical coquetry; but, on the whole, there is little of this; and, even our hostess, a silly woman, devoured with the desire of being what neither her social position, education, habits nor notions fit her to be, is less obtrusive, bustling, and offensive, than a similar person, elsewhere."
10149{_}696{_}"I am quite of your way of thinking, and intended to ask you to account for it."
10149{_}697{_}"The Americans are an imitative people of necessity, and they are apt at this part of imitation, in particular.
10149{_}698{_}Then they are less artificial in all their practices, than older and more sophisticated nations; and this company has got that essential part of good breeding, simplicity, as it were _per force_.
10149{_}699{_}A step higher in the social scale, you will see less of it; for greater daring and bad models lead to blunders in matters that require to be exceedingly well done, if done at all.
10149{_}700{_}The faults here would be more apparent, by an approach near enough to get into the tone of mind, the forms of speech, and the attempts at wit."
10149{_}701{_}"Which I think we shall escape to-night, as I see the ladies are already making their apologies and taking leave.
10149{_}702{_}We must defer this investigation to another time."
10149{_}703{_}"It may be indefinitely postponed, as it would scarcely reward the trouble of an inquiry."
10149{_}704{_}The gentlemen now approached Mrs. Jarvis, paid their parting compliments, hunted up Captain Truck, whom they tore by violence from the good-natured hospitality of the master of the house, and then saw the ladies into their carriage.
10149{_}705{_}As they drove off, the worthy mariner protested that Mr. Jarvis was one of the honestest men he had ever met, and announced that he intended giving him a dinner on board the Montauk, the very next day.
10149{_}706{_}The dwelling of Mrs. Hawker was in Hudson Square; or in a portion of the city that the lovers of the grandiose are endeavouring to call St. John's Park; for it is rather an amusing peculiarity among a certain portion of the emigrants who have flocked into the Middle States, within the last thirty years, that they are not satisfied with permitting any family, or thing, to possess the name it originally enjoyed, if there exists the least opportunity to change it.
10149{_}707{_}There was but a carriage or two before the door, though the strong lights in the house showed that company had collected.
10149{_}708{_}"Mrs. Hawker is the widow and the daughter of men of long established New-York families; she is childless, affluent, and universally respected where known, for her breeding, benevolence, good sense, and heart," said John Effingham, while the party was driving from one house to the other.
10149{_}709{_}"Were you to go into most of the sets of this town, and mention Mrs. Hawker's name, not one person in ten would know there is such a being in their vicinity; the _pele mele_ of a migratory population keeping persons of her character and condition in life, quite out of view.
10149{_}710{_}The very persons who will prattle by the hour, of the establishments of Mrs. Peleg Pond, and Mrs. Jonah Twist, and Mrs. Abiram Wattles, people who first appeared on this island five or six years since, and, who having accumulated what to them are relatively large fortunes, have launched out into vulgar and uninstructed finery, would look with surprise at hearing Mrs. Hawker mentioned as one having any claims to social distinction.
10149{_}711{_}Her historical names are overshadowed in their minds by the parochial glories of certain local prodigies in the townships whence they emigrated; her manners would puzzle the comprehension of people whose imitation has not gone beyond the surface, and her polished and simple mind would find little sympathy among a class who seldom rise above a common-place sentiment without getting upon stilts."
10149{_}712{_}"Mrs. Hawker, then, is a lady," observed Sir George Templemore.
10149{_}713{_}"Mrs. Hawker is a lady, in every sense of the word; by position, education, manners, association, mind, fortune and birth.
10149{_}714{_}I do not know that we ever had more of her class than exist to-day, but certainly we once had them more prominent in society."
10149{_}715{_}"I suppose, sir," said Captain Truck, "that this Mrs. Hawker is of what is called the old school?"
10149{_}716{_}"Of a very ancient school, and one that is likely to continue, though it may not be generally attended."
10149{_}717{_}"I am afraid, Mr. John Effingham, that I shall be like a fish out of water in such a house.
10149{_}718{_}I can get along very well with your Mrs. Jarvis, and with the dear young lady in the other carriage; but the sort of woman you have described, will be apt to jam a plain mariner like myself.
10149{_}719{_}What in nature should I do, now, if she should ask me to dance a minuet?"
10149{_}720{_}"Dance it agreeably to the laws of nature," returned John Effingham, as the carriages stopped.
10149{_}721{_}A respectable, quiet, and an aged black admitted the party, though even he did not announce the visiters, while he held the door of the drawing-room open for them, with respectful attention.
10149{_}722{_}Mrs. Hawker arose, and advanced to meet Eve and her companions, and though she kissed the cousins affectionately, her reception of Mademoiselle Viefville was so simply polite as to convince the latter she was valued on account of her services.
10149{_}723{_}John Effingham, who was ten or fifteen years the junior of the old lady, gallantly kissed her hand, when he presented his two male companions.
10149{_}724{_}After paying the proper attention to the greatest stranger, Mrs. Hawker turned to Captain Truck and said--  "This, then, is the gentleman to whose skill and courage you all owe so much--_we_ all owe so much, I might better have said--the commander of the Montauk?"
10149{_}725{_}"I have the honour of commanding that vessel, ma'am," returned Captain Truck, who was singularly awed by the dignified simplicity of his hostess, although her quiet, natural, and yet finished manner, which extended even to the intonation of the voice, and the smallest movement, were as unlike what he had expected as possible; "and with such passengers as she had last voyage I can only say, it is a pity that she is not better off for one to take care of her."
10149{_}726{_}"Your passengers give a different account of the matter, but, in order that I may judge impartially, do me the favour to take this chair, and let me learn a few of the particulars from yourself."
10149{_}727{_}Observing that Sir George Templemore had followed Eve to the other side of the room, Mrs. Hawker now resumed her seat, and, without neglecting any to attend to one in particular, or attending to one in a way to make him feel oppressed, she contrived, in a few minutes, to make the captain forget all about the minuet, and to feel much more at his ease than would have been the case with Mrs. Jarvis, in a month's intercourse.
10149{_}728{_}In the mean time, Eve had crossed the room to join a lady whose smile invited her to her side.
10149{_}729{_}This was a young, slightly framed female, of a pleasing countenance, but who would not have been particularly distinguished, in such a place, for personal charms.
10149{_}730{_}Still, her smile was sweet, her eyes were soft, and the expression of her face was what might almost be called illuminated As Sir George Templemore followed her, Eve mentioned his name to her acquaintance, whom she addressed as Mrs. Bloomfield.
10149{_}731{_}"You are bent on perpetrating further gaiety to-night," said the latter, glancing at the ball-dresses of the two cousins; "are you in the colours of the Houston faction, or in those of the Peabody."
10149{_}732{_}"Not in pea-green, certainly," returned Eve, laughing--"as you may see; but in simple white."
10149{_}733{_}"You intend then to be 'led a measure' at Mrs. Houston's.
10149{_}734{_}It were more suitable than among the other faction."
10149{_}735{_}"Is fashion, then, faction, in New-York?"
10149{_}736{_}inquired Sir George.
10149{_}737{_}"Fractions would be a better word, perhaps.
10149{_}738{_}But we have parties in almost every thing, in America; in politics, religion, temperance, speculations, and taste; why not in fashion?"
10149{_}739{_}"I fear we are not quite independent enough to form parties on such a subject," said Eve.
10149{_}740{_}"Perfectly well said, Miss Effingham; one must think a little originally, let it be ever so falsely, in order to get up a fashion.
10149{_}741{_}I fear we shall have to admit our insignificance on this point.
10149{_}742{_}You are a late arrival, Sir George Templemore?"
10149{_}743{_}"As lately as the commencement of this month; I had the honour of being a fellow-passenger with Mr. Effingham and his family."
10149{_}744{_}"In which voyage you suffered shipwreck, captivity, and famine, if half we hear be true."
10149{_}745{_}"Report has a little magnified our risks; we encountered some serious dangers, but nothing amounting to the sufferings you have mentioned."
10149{_}746{_}"Being a married woman, and having passed the crisis in which deception is not practised, I expect to hear truth again," said Mrs. Bloomfield, smiling.
10149{_}747{_}"I trust, however, you underwent enough to qualify you all for heroes and heroines, and shall content myself with knowing that you are here, safe and happy--if," she added, looking inquiringly at Eve, "one who has been educated abroad _can_ be happy at home."
10149{_}748{_}"One educated abroad _may_ be happy at home, though possibly not in the modes most practised by the world," said Eve firmly.
10149{_}749{_}"Without an opera, without a court, almost without society!"
10149{_}750{_}"An opera would be desirable, I confess; of courts I know nothing, unmarried females being cyphers in Europe; and I hope better things than to think I shall be without society."
10149{_}751{_}"Unmarried females are considered cyphers too, here, provided there be enough of them with a good respectable digit at their head.
10149{_}752{_}I assure you no one quarrels with the cyphers under such circumstances.
10149{_}753{_}I think, Sir George Templemore, a town like this must be something of a paradox to you."
10149{_}754{_}"Might I venture to inquire the reason for this opinion!"
10149{_}755{_}"Merely because it is neither one thing nor another.
10149{_}756{_}Not a capital, nor yet merely a provincial place; with something more than commerce in its bosom, and yet with that something hidden under a bushel.
10149{_}757{_}A good deal more than Liverpool, and a good deal less than London.
10149{_}758{_}Better even than Edinburgh, in many respects, and worse than Wapping, in others."
10149{_}759{_}"You have been abroad, Mrs.
10149{_}760{_}Bloomfield?"
10149{_}761{_}"Not a foot out of my own country; scarcely a foot out of my own state.
10149{_}762{_}I have been at Lake George, the Falls, and the Mountain House; and, as one does not travel in a balloon, I saw some of the intermediate places.
10149{_}763{_}As for all else, I am obliged to go by report."
10149{_}764{_}"It is a pity Mrs. Bloomfield was not with us, this evening, at Mrs. Jarvis's," said Eve, laughing.
10149{_}765{_}"She might then have increased her knowledge, by listening to a few cantos from the epic of Mr.
10149{_}766{_}Dodge."
10149{_}767{_}"I have glanced at some of that author's wisdom," returned Mrs. Bloomfield, "but I soon found it was learning backwards.
10149{_}768{_}There is a never-failing rule, by which it is easy to arrive at a traveller's worth, in a negative sense, at least."
10149{_}769{_}"That is a rule which may be worth knowing," said the baronet, "as it would save much useless wear of the eyes."
10149{_}770{_}"When one betrays a profound ignorance of his own country, it is a fair presumption that he cannot be very acute in his observation of strangers.
10149{_}771{_}Mr.
10149{_}772{_}Dodge is one of these writers, and a single letter fully satisfied my curiosity.
10149{_}773{_}I fear, Miss Effingham, very inferior wares, in the way of manners, have been lately imported, in large quantities, into this country, as having the Tower mark on them."
10149{_}774{_}Eve laughed, but declared that Sir George Templemore was better qualified than herself to answer such a question.
10149{_}775{_}"We are said to be a people of facts, rather than a people of theories," continued Mrs. Bloomfield, without attending to the reference of the young lady, "and any coin that offers passes, until another that is better, arrives.
10149{_}776{_}It is a singular, but a very general mistake, I believe, of the people of this country, in supposing that they can exist under the present regime, when others would fail, because their opinions keep even pace with, or precede the actual condition of society; whereas, those who have thought and observed most on such subjects, agree in thinking the very reverse to be the case."
10149{_}777{_}"This would be a curious condition for a government so purely conventional," observed Sir George, with interest, "and it certainly is entirely opposed to the state of things all over Europe."
10149{_}778{_}"It is so, and yet there is no great mystery in it after all.
10149{_}779{_}Accident has liberated us from trammels that still fetter you.
10149{_}780{_}We are like a vehicle on the top of a hill, which, the moment it is pushed beyond the point of resistance, rolls down of itself, without the aid of horses.
10149{_}781{_}One may follow with the team, and hook on when it gets to the bottom, but there is no such thing as keeping company with it until it arrives there."
10149{_}782{_}"You will allow, then, that there is a bottom?'
10149{_}783{_}"There is a bottom to every thing--to good and bad; happiness and misery; hope, fear, faith and charity; even to a woman's mind, which I have sometimes fancied the most bottomless thing in nature.
10149{_}784{_}There may, therefore, well be a bottom even to the institutions of America."
10149{_}785{_}Sir George listened with the interest with which an Englishman of his class always endeavours to catch a concession that he fancies is about to favour his own political predilections, and he felt encouraged to push the subject further.
10149{_}786{_}"And you think the political machine is rolling downwards towards this bottom?"
10149{_}787{_}he said, with an interest in the answer that, living in the quiet and forgetfulness of his own home, he would have laughed at himself for entertaining.
10149{_}788{_}But our sensibilities become quickened by collision, and opposition is known even to create love.
10149{_}789{_}Mrs. Bloomfield was quick-witted, intelligent, cultivated and shrewd.
10149{_}790{_}She saw the motive at a glance, and, notwithstanding she saw and felt all its abuses, strongly attached to the governing principle of her country's social organization, as is almost universally the case with the strongest minds and most generous hearts of the nation, she was not disposed to let a stranger carry away a false impression of her sentiments on such a point.
10149{_}791{_}"Did you ever study logic, Sir George Templemore?"
10149{_}792{_}she asked, archly.
10149{_}793{_}"A little, though not enough I fear to influence my mode of reasoning, or even to leave me familiar with the terms."
10149{_}794{_}"Oh!
10149{_}795{_}I am not about to assail you with _sequiturs_ and _non sequiturs_ dialectics and all the mysteries of _Denk-Lehre,_ but simply to remind you there is such a thing as the bottom of a subject.
10149{_}796{_}When I tell you we are flying towards the bottom of our institutions, it is in the intellectual sense, and not, as you have erroneously imagined, in an unintellectual sense.
10149{_}797{_}I mean that we are getting to understand them, which, I fear, we did not absolutely do at the commencement of the 'experiment.'"
10149{_}798{_}"But I think you will admit, that as the civilization of the country advances, some material changes must occur; your people cannot always remain stationary; they must either go backwards or forward."
10149{_}799{_}"Up or down, if you will allow me to correct your phraseology.
10149{_}800{_}The civilization of the country, in one sense at least, is retrogressive, and the people, as they cannot go 'up,' betray a disposition to go 'down.'"
10149{_}801{_}"You deal in enigmas, and I am afraid to think I understand you."
10149{_}802{_}"I mean, merely, that gallowses are fast disappearing, and that the people--_le peuple_ you will understand--begin to accept money.
10149{_}803{_}In both particulars, I think there is a sensible change for the worse, within my own recollection."
10149{_}804{_}Mrs. Bloomfield then changed her manner, and from using that light- hearted gaiety with which she often rendered her conversation _piquante_, and even occasionally brilliant, she became more grave and explicit.
10149{_}805{_}The subject soon turned to that of punishments, and few men could have reasoned more sensibly, justly or forcibly, on such a subject, than this slight and fragile-looking young woman.
10149{_}806{_}Without the least pedantry, with a beauty of language that the other sex seldom attains, and with a delicacy of discrimination, and a sentiment that were strictly feminine, she rendered a theme interesting, that, however important in itself, is forbidding, veiling all its odious and revolting features in the refinement and finesse of her own polished mind.
10149{_}807{_}Eve could have listened all night, and, at every syllable that fell from the lips of her friend, she felt a glow of triumph; for she was proud of letting an intelligent foreigner see that America did contain women worthy to be ranked with the best of other countries, a circumstance that they who merely frequented what is called the world, she thought might be reasonably justified in distrusting.
10149{_}808{_}In one respect, she even fancied Mrs. Bloomfield's knowledge and cleverness superior to those which she had so often admired in her own sex abroad.
10149{_}809{_}It was untrammelled, equally by the prejudices incident to a factitious condition of society, or by their reaction; two circumstances that often obscured the sense and candour of those to whom she had so often listened with pleasure in other countries.
10149{_}810{_}The singularly feminine tone, too, of all that Mrs. Bloomfield said or thought, while it lacked nothing in strength, added to the charm of her conversation, and increased the pleasure of those that listened.
10149{_}811{_}"Is the circle large to which Mrs. Hawker and her friends belong?"
10149{_}812{_}asked Sir George, as he assisted Eve and Grace to cloak, when they had taken leave.
10149{_}813{_}"A town which can boast of half-a-dozen such houses need not accuse itself of wanting society."
10149{_}814{_}"Ah!
10149{_}815{_}there is but one Mrs. Hawker in New-York," answered Grace, "and not many Mrs. Bloomfields in the world.
10149{_}816{_}It would be too much to say, we have even half-a-dozen such houses."
10149{_}817{_}"Have you not been struck with the admirable tone of this drawing- room," half whispered Eve.
10149{_}818{_}"It may want a little of that lofty ease that one sees among the better portion of the old _Princesses et Duchesses_, which is a relic of a school that, it is to be feared, is going out; but in its place there is a winning nature, with as much dignity as is necessary, and a truth that gives us confidence in the sincerity of those around us."
10149{_}819{_}"Upon my word, I think Mrs. Hawker quite fit for a Duchess."
10149{_}820{_}"You mean a _Duchesse_" said Eve, "and yet she is without the manner that we understand by such a word.
10149{_}821{_}Mrs. Hawker is a lady, and there can be no higher term."
10149{_}822{_}"She is a delightful old woman," cried John Effingham, "and if twenty years younger and disposed to change her condition, I should really be afraid to enter the house."
10149{_}823{_}"My dear sir," put in the captain, "I will make her Mrs. Truck to- morrow, and say nothing of years, if she could be content to take up with such an offer.
10149{_}824{_}Why, sir, she is no woman, but a saint in petticoats!
10149{_}825{_}I felt the whole time as if talking to my own mother, and as for ships, she knows more about them than I do!"
10149{_}826{_}The whole party laughed at the strength of the captain's admiration, and getting into the carriages proceeded to the last of the houses they intended visiting that night.
10149{_}827{_}Chapter V.    "So turns she every man the wrong side out; And never gives to   truth and virtue, that Which simpleness and merit purchaseth."
10149{_}828{_}MUCH ADO ABOUT NOTHING.
10149{_}829{_}Mrs. Houston was what is termed a fashionable woman in New-York.
10149{_}830{_}She, too, was of a family of local note, though of one much less elevated in the olden time than that of Mrs. Hawker.
10149{_}831{_}Still her claims were admitted by the most fastidious on such points, for a few do remain who think descent indisputable to gentility; and as her means were ample, and her tastes perhaps superior to those of most around her, she kept what was thought a house of better tone than common, even in the highest circle.
10149{_}832{_}Eve had but a slight acquaintance with her; but in Grace's eyes, Mrs. Houston's was the place of all others that she thought might make a favourable impression on her cousin.
10149{_}833{_}Her wish that this should prove to be the case was so strong, that, as they drove towards the door, she could not forbear from making an attempt to prepare Eve for what she was to meet.
10149{_}834{_}"Although Mrs. Houston has a very large house for New-York, and lives in a uniform style, you are not to expect ante-chambers, and vast suites of rooms, Eve," said Grace; "such as you have been accustomed to see abroad."
10149{_}835{_}"It is not necessary, my dear cousin, to enter a house of four or five windows in front, to see it is not a house of twenty or thirty.
10149{_}836{_}I should be very unreasonable to expect an Italian palazzo, or a Parisian hotel, in this good town."
10149{_}837{_}"We are not old enough for that yet, Eve; a hundred years hence, Mademoiselle Viefville, such things may exist here."
10149{_}838{_}"_Bien sur.
10149{_}839{_}C'est naturel._"  "A hundred years hence, as the world tends, Grace, they are not likely to exist any where, except as taverns, or hospitals, or manufactories.
10149{_}840{_}But what have we to do, coz, with a century ahead of us?
10149{_}841{_}young as we both are, we cannot hope to live that time."
10149{_}842{_}Grace would have been puzzled to account satisfactorily to herself, for the strong desire she felt that neither of her companions should expect to see such a house as their senses so plainly told them did not exist in the place; but her foot moved in the bottom of the carriage, for she was not half satisfied with her cousin's answer.
10149{_}843{_}"All I mean.
10149{_}844{_}Eve," she said, after a pause, "is, that one ought not to expect in a town as new as this, the improvements that one sees in an older state of society."
10149{_}845{_}"And have Mademoiselle Viefville, or I, ever been so weak as to suppose, that New-York is Paris, or Rome, or Vienna?"
10149{_}846{_}Grace was still less satisfied, for, unknown to herself, she _had_ hoped that Mrs. Houston's ball might be quite equal to a ball in either of those ancient capitals; and she was now vexed that her cousin considered it so much a matter of course that it should not be.
10149{_}847{_}But there was no time for explanations, as the carriage now stopped.
10149{_}848{_}The noise, confusion, calling out, swearing, and rude clamour before the house of Mrs. Houston, said little for the out-door part of the arrangements.
10149{_}849{_}Coachmen are nowhere a particularly silent and civil class; but the uncouth European peasants, who have been preferred to the honours of the whip in New-York, to the usual feelings of competition and contention, added that particular feature of humility which is known to distinguish "the beggar on horseback."
10149{_}850{_}The imposing equipages of our party, however, had that effect on most of these rude brawlers, which a display of wealth is known to produce on the vulgar-minded; and the ladies got into the house, through a lane of coachmen, by yielding a little to a _chevau de frise_ of whips, without any serious calamity.
10149{_}851{_}"One hardly knows which is the most terrific," said Eve, involuntarily, as soon as the door closed on them--"the noise within, or the noise without!"
10149{_}852{_}This was spoken rapidly, and in French, to Mademoiselle Viefville, but Grace heard and understood it, and for the first time in her life, she perceived that Mrs. Houston's company was not composed of nightingales.
10149{_}853{_}The surprise is that the discovery should have come so late.
10149{_}854{_}"I am delighted at having got into this house," said Sir George, who, having thrown his cloak to his own servant, stood with the two other gentlemen waiting the descent of the ladies from the upper room, where the bad arrangements of the house compelled them to uncloak and to put aside their shawls, "as I am told it is the best house in town to see the other sex."
10149{_}855{_}"To _hear them_, would be nearer the truth, perhaps," returned John Effingham.
10149{_}856{_}"As for pretty women, one can hardly go amiss in New-York; and your ears now tell you, that they do not come into the world to be seen only."
10149{_}857{_}The baronet smiled, but he was too well bred to contradict or to assent.
10149{_}858{_}Mademoiselle Viefville, unconscious that she was violating the proprieties, walked into the rooms by herself, as soon as she descended, followed by Eve; but Grace shrank to the side of John Effingham, whose arm she took as a step necessary even to decorum.
10149{_}859{_}Mrs. Houston received her guests with ease and dignity.
10149{_}860{_}She was one of those females that the American world calls gay; in other words, she opened her own house to a very promiscuous society, ten or a dozen times in a winter, and accepted the greater part of the invitations she got to other people's.
10149{_}861{_}Still, in most other countries, as a fashionable woman, she would have been esteemed a model of devotion to the duties of a wife and a mother, for she paid a personal attention to her household, and had actually taught all her children the Lord's prayer, the creed, and the ten commandments.
10149{_}862{_}She attended church twice every Sunday, and only staid at home from the evening lectures, that the domestics might have the opportunity of going (which, by the way, they never did) in her stead.
10149{_}863{_}Feminine, well-mannered, rich, pretty, of a very positive social condition, and naturally kind-hearted and disposed to sociability, Mrs. Houston, supported by an indulgent husband, who so much loved to see people with the appearance of happiness, that he was not particular as to the means, had found no difficulty in rising to the pinnacle of fashion, and of having her name in the mouths of all those who find it necessary to talk of somebodies, in order that they may seem to be somebodies themselves.
10149{_}864{_}All this contributed to Mrs. Houston's happiness, or she fancied it did; and as every passion is known to increase by indulgence, she had insensibly gone on in her much-envied career until, as has just been said, she reached the summit.
10149{_}865{_}"These rooms are very crowded," said Sir George, glancing his eyes around two very pretty little narrow drawing-rooms, that were beautifully, not to say richly, furnished; "one wonders that the same contracted style of building should be so very general, in a town that increases as rapidly as this, and where fashion has no fixed abode, and land is so abundant."
10149{_}866{_}"Mrs. Bloomfield would tell you," said Eve, "that these houses are types of the social state of the country, in which no one is permitted to occupy more than his share of ground."
10149{_}867{_}"But there are reasonably large dwellings in the place.
10149{_}868{_}Mrs. Hawker has a good house, and your father's for instance, would be thought so, too, in London even; and yet I fancy you will agree with me in thinking that a good room is almost unknown in New-York."
10149{_}869{_}"I do agree with you, in this particular, certainly, for to meet with a good room, one must go into the houses built thirty years ago.
10149{_}870{_}We have inherited these snuggeries, however, England not having much to boast of in the way of houses."
10149{_}871{_}"In the way of town residences, I agree with you entirely, as a whole, though we have some capital exceptions.
10149{_}872{_}Still, I do not think we are quite as compact as this--do you not fancy the noise increased in consequence of its being so confined?"
10149{_}873{_}Eve laughed and shook her head quite positively.
10149{_}874{_}"What would it be if fairly let out!"
10149{_}875{_}she said.
10149{_}876{_}"But we will not waste the precious moments, but turn our eyes about us in quest of the _belles_.
10149{_}877{_}Grace, you who are so much at home, must be our cicerone, and tell us which are the idols we are to worship."
10149{_}878{_}"_Dites moi premierement; que veut dire une belle a New-York?_" demanded Mademoiselle Viefville.
10149{_}879{_}"_Apparemment, tout le monde est joli._"  "A _belle_, Mademoiselle," returned John Effingham, "is not necessarily beautiful, the qualifications for the character, being various and a little contradictory.
10149{_}880{_}One may be a _belle_ by means of money, a tongue, an eye, a foot, teeth, a laugh, or any other separate feature, or grace; though no woman was ever yet a _belle_, I believe, by means of the head, considered collectively.
10149{_}881{_}But why deal in description, when the thing itself confronts us?
10149{_}882{_}The young lady standing directly before us, is a _belle_ of the most approved stamp and silvery tone.
10149{_}883{_}Is it not Miss Ring, Grace?"
10149{_}884{_}The answer was in the affirmative, and the eyes of the whole party turned towards the subject of this remark.
10149{_}885{_}The young lady in question was about twenty, rather tall for an American woman, not conspicuously handsome, but like most around her of delicate features and frame, and with such a _physique_, as, under proper training, would have rendered her the _beau ideal_ of feminine delicacy and gentleness.
10149{_}886{_}She had natural spirit, likewise, as appeared in her clear blue eye, and moreover she had the spirit to be a _belle_.
10149{_}887{_}Around this young creature were clustered no less than five young men, dressed in the height of the fashion, all of whom seemed to be entranced with the words that fell from her lips, and each of whom appeared anxious to say something clever in return.
10149{_}888{_}They all laughed, the lady most, and sometimes all spoke at once.
10149{_}889{_}Notwithstanding these outbreakings, Miss Ring did most of the talking, and once or twice, as a young man would gape after a most exhilarating show of merriment, and discover an inclination to retreat, she managed to recall him to his allegiance, by some remark particularly pertinent to himself, or his feelings.
10149{_}890{_}"_Qui est cette dame?_" asked Mademoiselle Viefville, very much as one would put a similar question, on seeing a man enter a church during service with his hat on.
10149{_}891{_}"_Elle est demoiselle_," returned Eve.
10149{_}892{_}"_Quelle horreur!_"  "Nay, nay, Mademoiselle, I shall not allow you to set up France as immaculate on this point, neither--" said John Effingham, looking at the last speaker with an affected frown--"A young lady may have a tongue, and she may even speak to a young gentleman, and not be guilty of felony; although I will admit that five tongues are unnecessary, and that five listeners are more than sufficient, for the wisdom of twenty in petticoats."
10149{_}893{_}"_C'est une horreur!_"  "I dare say Miss Ring would think it a greater horror to be obliged to pass an evening in a row of girls, unspoken to, except to be asked to dance, and admired only in the distance.
10149{_}894{_}But let us take seats on that sofa, and then we may go beyond the pantomime, and become partakers in the sentiment of the scene."
10149{_}895{_}Grace and Eve were now led off to dance, and the others did as John Effingham had suggested.
10149{_}896{_}In the eyes of the _belle_ and her admirers, they who had passed thirty were of no account, and our listeners succeeded in establishing themselves quietly within ear-shot--this was almost at duelling distance, too,--without at all interrupting the regular action of the piece.
10149{_}897{_}We extract a little of the dialogue, by way of giving a more dramatic representation of the scene.
10149{_}898{_}"Do you think the youngest Miss Danvers beautiful?"
10149{_}899{_}asked the _belle_, while her eye wandered in quest of a sixth gentleman to "entertain," as the phrase is.
10149{_}900{_}"In my opinion, she is absolutely the prettiest female in Mrs. Houston's rooms this night."
10149{_}901{_}The young men, one and all, protested against this judgment, and with perfect truth, for Miss Ring was too original to point out charms that every one could see.
10149{_}902{_}"They say it will not be a match between her and Mr. Egbert, after every body has supposed it settled so long.
10149{_}903{_}What is your opinion, Mr.
10149{_}904{_}Edson?"
10149{_}905{_}This timely question prevented Mr. Edson's retreat, for he had actually got so far in this important evolution, as to have gaped and turned his back.
10149{_}906{_}Recalled, as it were by the sound of the bugle, Mr. Edson was compelled to say something, a sore affliction to him always.
10149{_}907{_}"Oh!
10149{_}908{_}I'm quite of your way of thinking; they have certainly courted too long to think of marrying."
10149{_}909{_}"I detest long courtships; they must be perfect antidotes to love; are they not, Mr.
10149{_}910{_}Moreland?"
10149{_}911{_}A truant glance of Mr. Moreland's eye was rebuked by this appeal, and instead of looking for a place of refuge, he now merely looked sheepish.
10149{_}912{_}He, however, entirely agreed with the young lady, as the surer way of getting out of the difficulty.
10149{_}913{_}"Pray, Mr. Summerfield, how do you like the last Hajji--Miss Eve Effingham?
10149{_}914{_}To my notion, she is prettyish, though by no means as well as her cousin, Miss Van Cortlandt, who is really rather good- looking."
10149{_}915{_}As Eve and Grace were the two most truly lovely young women in the rooms, this opinion, as well as the loud tone in which it was given, startled Mademoiselle Viefville quite as much as the subjects that the belle had selected for discussion.
10149{_}916{_}She would have moved, as listening to a conversation that was not meant for their ears; but John Effingham quietly assured her that Miss Ring seldom spoke in company without intending as many persons as possible to hear her.
10149{_}917{_}"Miss Effingham is very plainly dressed for an only daughter" continued the young lady, "though that lace of her cousin's is real point!
10149{_}918{_}I'll engage it cost every cent of ten dollars a yard!
10149{_}919{_}They are both engaged to be married, I hear."
10149{_}920{_}"_Ciel!_" exclaimed Mademoiselle Viefville.
10149{_}921{_}"Oh!
10149{_}922{_}That is nothing," observed John Effingham coolly.
10149{_}923{_}"Wait a moment, and you'll hear that they have been privately married these six months, if, indeed, you hear no more."
10149{_}924{_}"Of course this is but an idle tale?"
10149{_}925{_}said Sir George Templemore with a concern, which, in despite of his good breeding, compelled him to put a question that, under other circumstances, would scarcely have been permissible.
10149{_}926{_}"As true as the gospel.
10149{_}927{_}But listen to the _bell_, it is _ringing_ for the good of the whole parish."
10149{_}928{_}"The affair between Miss Effingham and Mr. Morpeth, who knew her abroad, I understand is entirely broken off; some say the father objected to Mr. Morpeth's want of fortune; others that the lady was fickle, while some accuse the gentleman of the same vice.
10149{_}929{_}Don't you think it shocking to jilt, in either sex, Mr.
10149{_}930{_}Mosely?"
10149{_}931{_}The _retiring_ Mr. Mosely was drawn again within the circle, and was obliged to confess that he thought it was very shocking, in either sex, to jilt.
10149{_}932{_}"If I were a man," continued the _belle_, "I would never think of a young woman who had once jilted a lover.
10149{_}933{_}To my mind, it bespeaks a bad heart, and a woman with a bad heart cannot make a very amiable wife."
10149{_}934{_}"What an exceedingly clever creature she is," whispered Mr. Mosely to Mr. Moreland, and he now made up his mind to remain and be 'entertained' some time longer.
10149{_}935{_}"I think poor Mr. Morpeth greatly to be pitied; for no man would be so silly as to be attentive seriously to a lady without encouragement.
10149{_}936{_}Encouragement is the _ne plus ultra_ of courtship; are you not of my opinion, Mr.
10149{_}937{_}Walworth?"
10149{_}938{_}Mr. Walworth was number five of the entertainees, and he did understand Latin, of which the young lady, though fond of using scraps, knew literally nothing.
10149{_}939{_}He smiled an assent, therefore, and the _belle_ felicitated herself in having 'entertained' _him_ effectually; nor was she mistaken.
10149{_}940{_}"Indeed, they say Miss Effingham had several affairs of the heart, while in Europe, but it seems she was unfortunate in them all."
10149{_}941{_}"_Mais, ceci est trop fort!
10149{_}942{_}Je ne peux plus ecouter._"  "My dear Mademoiselle, compose yourself.
10149{_}943{_}The crisis is not yet arrived, by any means."
10149{_}944{_}"I understand she still corresponds with a German Baron, and an Italian Marquis, though both engagements are absolutely broken off.
10149{_}945{_}Some people say she walks into company alone, unsupported by any gentleman, by way of announcing a firm determination to remain single for life."
10149{_}946{_}A common exclamation from the young men proclaimed their disapprobation; and that night three of them actually repeated the thing, as a well established truth, and two of the three, failing of something better to talk about, also announced that Eve was actually engaged to be married.
10149{_}947{_}"There is something excessively indelicate in a young lady's moving about a room without having a gentleman's arm to lean on!
10149{_}948{_}I always feel as if such a person was out of her place, and ought to be in the kitchen."
10149{_}949{_}"But, Miss Ring, what well-bred person does it?"
10149{_}950{_}sputtered Mr. Moreland.
10149{_}951{_}"No one ever heard of such a thing in good society.
10149{_}952{_}'Tis quite shocking!
10149{_}953{_}Altogether unprecedented."
10149{_}954{_}"It strikes me as being excessively coarse!"
10149{_}955{_}"Oh!
10149{_}956{_}manifestly; quite rustic!"
10149{_}957{_}exclaimed Mr. Edson.
10149{_}958{_}"What can possibly be more vulgar?"
10149{_}959{_}added Mr. Walworth.
10149{_}960{_}"I never heard of such a thing among the right sort!"
10149{_}961{_}said Mr. Mosely.
10149{_}962{_}"A young lady who can be so brazen as to come into a room without a gentleman's arm to lean on, is, in my judgment at least, but indifferently educated, Hajji or no Hajji.
10149{_}963{_}Mr. Edson, have you ever felt the tender passion?
10149{_}964{_}I know you have been desperately in love, once, at least; do describe to me some of the symptoms, in order that I may know when I am seriously attacked myself by the disease."
10149{_}965{_}"_Mais, ceci est ridicule!
10149{_}966{_}L'enfant s'est sauvee du Charenton de New- York._"  "From the nursery rather, Mademoiselle; you perceive she does not yet know how to walk alone."
10149{_}967{_}Mr. Edson now protested that he was too stupid to feel a passion as intellectual as love, and that he was afraid he was destined by nature to remain as insensible as a block.
10149{_}968{_}"One never knows, Mr. Edson," said the young lady, encouragingly.
10149{_}969{_}"Several of my acquaintances, who thought themselves quite safe, have been seized suddenly, and, though none have actually died, more than one has been roughly treated, I assure you."
10149{_}970{_}Here the young men, one and all, protested that she was excessively clever.
10149{_}971{_}Then succeeded a pause, for Miss Ring was inviting, with her eyes, a number six to join the circle, her ambition being dissatisfied with five entertainees, as she saw that Miss Trumpet, a rival belle, had managed to get exactly that number, also, in the other room.
10149{_}972{_}All the gentlemen availed themselves of the cessation in wit to gape, and Mr. Edson took the occasion to remark to Mr. Summerfield that he understood "lots had been sold in seven hundredth street that morning, as high as two hundred dollars a lot."
10149{_}973{_}The _quadrille_ now ended, and Eve returned towards her friends.
10149{_}974{_}As she approached, the whole party compared her quiet, simple, feminine, and yet dignified air, with the restless, beau-catching, and worldly look of the belle, and wondered by what law of nature, or of fashion, the one could possibly become the subject of the other's comments.
10149{_}975{_}Eve never appeared better than that evening.
10149{_}976{_}Her dress had all the accuracy and finish of a Parisian toilette, being equally removed from exaggeration and neglect; and it was worn with the ease of one accustomed to be elegantly attired, and yet never decked with finery.
10149{_}977{_}Her step even was that of a lady, having neither the mincing tread of a Paris grisette, a manner that sometimes ascends even to the _bourgeoise_ the march of a cockneyess, nor the tiptoe swing of a _belle_; but it was the natural though regulated step, of a trained and delicate woman.
10149{_}978{_}Walk alone she could certainly, and always did, except on those occasions of ceremony that demanded a partner.
10149{_}979{_}Her countenance, across which an unworthy thought had never left a trace, was an index, too, to the purity, high principles and womanly self- respect that controlled all her acts, and, in these particulars was the very reverse of the feverish, half-hoydenish half-affected expression of that of Miss Ring.
10149{_}980{_}"They may say what they please," muttered Captain Truck, who had been a silent but wondering listener of all that passed; "she is worth as many of them as could be stowed in the Montauk's lower hold."
10149{_}981{_}Miss Ring perceiving Eve approach, was desirous of saying something to her, for there was an _eclat_ about a Hajji, after all, that rendered an acquaintance, or even an intimacy desirable, and she smiled and curtsied.
10149{_}982{_}Eve returned the salutation, but as she did not care to approach a group of six, of which no less than five were men, she continued to move towards her own party.
10149{_}983{_}This reserve compelled Miss Ring to advance a step or two, when Eve was obliged to stop Curtsying to her partner, she thanked him for his attention, relinquished his arm, and turned to meet the lady.
10149{_}984{_}At the same instant the five 'entertainees' escaped in a body, equally rejoiced at their release, and proud of their captivity.
10149{_}985{_}"I have been dying to come and speak to you, Miss Effingham," commenced Miss Ring, "but these _five_ giants (she emphasized the word we have put in italics) so beset me, that escape was quite impossible.
10149{_}986{_}There ought to be a law that but one gentleman should speak to a lady at a time."
10149{_}987{_}"I thought there was such a law already;" said Eve, quietly.
10149{_}988{_}"You mean in good breeding; but no one thinks of those antiquated laws now-a-days.
10149{_}989{_}Are you beginning to be reconciled, a little, to your own country?"
10149{_}990{_}"It is not easy to effect a reconciliation where there has been no misunderstanding.
10149{_}991{_}I hope I have never quarrelled with my country, or my country with me."
10149{_}992{_}"Oh!
10149{_}993{_}it is not exactly that I mean.
10149{_}994{_}Cannot one need a reconciliation without a quarrel?
10149{_}995{_}What do you say to this, Mr.
10149{_}996{_}Edson?"
10149{_}997{_}Miss Ring having detected some symptoms of desertion in the gentleman addressed, had thrown in this question by way of recal; when turning to note its effect, she perceived that all of her _clientelle_ had escaped.
10149{_}998{_}A look of surprise and mortification and vexation it was not in her power to suppress, and then came one of horror.
10149{_}999{_}"How conspicuous we have made ourselves, and it is all my fault!"
10149{_}1000{_}she said, for the first time that evening permitting her voice to fall to a becoming tone.
10149{_}1001{_}'Why, here we actually are, two ladies conversing together, and no gentleman near us!"
10149{_}1002{_}"Is that being conspicuous?"
10149{_}1003{_}asked Eve, with a simplicity that was entirely natural.
10149{_}1004{_}"I am sure, Miss Effingham, one who has seen as much of society as you, can scarcely ask that question seriously.
10149{_}1005{_}I do not think I have done so improper a thing, since I was fifteen; and, dear me!
10149{_}1006{_}dear me!
10149{_}1007{_}how to escape is the question.
10149{_}1008{_}You have permitted your partner to go, and I do not see a gentleman of my acquaintance near us, to give me his arm!"
10149{_}1009{_}"As your distress is occasioned by my company," said Eve, "it is fortunately in my power to relieve it."
10149{_}1010{_}Thus saying, she quietly walked across the room, and took her seat next to Mademoiselle Viefville.
10149{_}1011{_}Miss Ring held up her hands in amazement, and then fortunately perceiving one of the truants gaping at no great distance, she beckoned him to her side.
10149{_}1012{_}"Have the goodness to give me your arm, Mr. Summerfield," she said, "I am dying to get out of this unpleasantly conspicuous situation; but you are the first gentleman that has approached me this twelvemonth.
10149{_}1013{_}I would not for the world do so brazen a thing as Miss Effingham has just achieved; would you believe it, she positively went from this spot to her seat, quite alone!"
10149{_}1014{_}"The Hajjis are privileged."
10149{_}1015{_}"They make themselves so.
10149{_}1016{_}But every body knows how bold and unwomanly the French females are.
10149{_}1017{_}One could wish, notwithstanding, that our own people would not import their audacious usages into this country."
10149{_}1018{_}"It is a thousand pities that Mr. Clay, in his compromise, neglected to make an exception against that article.
10149{_}1019{_}A tariff on impudence would not be at all sectional."
10149{_}1020{_}"It might interfere with the manufacture at home, notwithstanding," said John Effingham; for the lungs were strong, and the rooms of Mrs. Houston so small, that little was said that evening, which was not heard by any who chose to listen.
10149{_}1021{_}But Miss Ring never listened, it being no part of the vocation of a _belle_ to perform that inferior office, and sustained by the protecting arm of Mr. Summerfield, she advanced more boldly into the crowd, where she soon contrived to catch another group of even six "entertainees."
10149{_}1022{_}As for Mr. Summerfield, he lived a twelvemonth on the reputation of the exceedingly clever thing he had just uttered.
10149{_}1023{_}"There come Ned and Aristabulus," said John Effingham, as soon as the tones of Miss Ring's voice were lost in the din of fifty others, pitched to the same key.
10149{_}1024{_}"_A present, Mademoiselle, je vais nous venger_."
10149{_}1025{_}As John Effingham uttered this, he took Captain Truck by the arm, and went to meet his cousin and the land agent.
10149{_}1026{_}The latter he soon separated from Mr. Effingham, and with this new recruit, he managed to get so near to Miss Ring as to attract her attention.
10149{_}1027{_}Although fifty, John Effingham was known to be a bachelor, well connected, and to have twenty thousand a year.
10149{_}1028{_}In addition, he was well preserved and singularly handsome, besides having an air that set all pretending gentility at defiance.
10149{_}1029{_}These were qualities that no _belle_ despised, and ill-assorted matches were, moreover, just coming into fashion in New-York.
10149{_}1030{_}Miss Ring had an intuitive knowledge that he wished to speak to her, and she was not slow in offering the opportunity.
10149{_}1031{_}The superior tone of John Effingham, his caustic wit and knowledge of the world, dispersed the five _beaux_, incontinently; these persons having a natural antipathy to every one of the qualities named.
10149{_}1032{_}"I hope you will permit me to presume on an acquaintance that extends back as far as your grandfather, Miss Ring," he said, "to present two very intimate friends; Mr. Bragg and Mr. Truck; gentlemen who will well reward the acquaintance."
