10149{_}3048{_}No one can care less than myself, Mr. Bragg, for the opinions of those who have sufficiently demonstrated that their opinions are of no value, by the heedless manner in which they have permitted themselves to fall into this error; but it is proceeding too far, when a few members of the community presume to take these liberties with a private individual, and that, moreover, in a case affecting a pretended claim of their own; and I desire you to tell those concerned, that if they dare to publish their resolution declaring me to be odious, I will teach them what they now do not appear to know, that we live in a country of laws.
10149{_}3049{_}I shall not prosecute them, but I shall indict them for the offence, and I hope this is plainly expressed."
10149{_}3050{_}Aristabulus stood aghast!
10149{_}3051{_}To indict the public was a step he had never heard of before, and he began to perceive that the question actually had two sides.
10149{_}3052{_}Still, his awe of public meetings, and his habitual regard for popularity, induced him not to give up the matter, without another struggle.
10149{_}3053{_}"They have already ordered their proceedings to be published, Mr.
10149{_}3054{_}Effingham!"
10149{_}3055{_}he said, as if such an order were not to be countermanded.
10149{_}3056{_}"I fancy, sir, that when it comes to the issue, and the penalties of a prosecution present themselves, their readers will begin to recollect their individuality, and to think less of their public character.
10149{_}3057{_}They who hunt in droves, like wolves, are seldom very valiant when singled out from their pack.
10149{_}3058{_}The end will show."
10149{_}3059{_}"I heartily wish this unpleasant affair might be amicably settled," added Aristabulus.
10149{_}3060{_}"One might, indeed, fancy so," observed John Effingham, "since no one likes to be persecuted."
10149{_}3061{_}"But, Mr. John, the public thinks _itself_ persecuted, in this affair."
10149{_}3062{_}"The term, as applied to a body that not only makes, but which executes, the law, is so palpably absurd, that I am surprised any man can presume to use it.
10149{_}3063{_}But, Mr. Bragg, you have seen documents that cannot err, and know that the public has not the smallest right to this bit of land."
10149{_}3064{_}"All very true, sir; but you will please to remember, that the people do not know what I now know."
10149{_}3065{_}"And you will please to remember, sir, that when people choose to act affirmatively, in so high-handed a manner as this, they are _bound_ to know what they are about.
10149{_}3066{_}Ignorance in such a matter, is like the drunkard's plea of intoxication; it merely makes the offence worse."
10149{_}3067{_}"Do you not think, Mr. John, that Mr. Effingham might have acquainted these citizens with the real state of the case?
10149{_}3068{_}Are the people so very wrong that they have fallen into a mistake?"
10149{_}3069{_}"Since you ask this question plainly, Mr. Bragg, it shall be answered with equal sincerity.
10149{_}3070{_}Mr. Effingham is a man of mature years; the known child, executor, and heir of one who, it is admitted all round, was the master of the controverted property.
10149{_}3071{_}Knowing his own business, this Mr. Effingham, in sight of the grave of his fathers, beneath the paternal roof, has the intolerable impudence--"  "Arrogance is the word, Jack," said Mr. Effingham, smiling.
10149{_}3072{_}"Aye, the intolerable arrogance to suppose that his own is his own; and this he dares to affirm, without having had the politeness to send his title-deeds, and private papers, round to those who have been so short a time in the place, that they might well know every thing that has occurred in it for the last half century.
10149{_}3073{_}Oh thou naughty, arrogant fellow, Ned!"
10149{_}3074{_}"Mr. John, you appear to forget that the public has more claims to be treated with attention, than a single individual.
10149{_}3075{_}If it has fallen into error, it ought to be undeceived."
10149{_}3076{_}"No doubt, sir; and I advise Mr. Effingham to send you, his agent, to every man, woman and child in the county, with the Patent of the King, all the mesne conveyances and wills, in your pocket, in order that you may read them at length to each individual, with a view that every man, woman and child, may be satisfied that he or she is not the owner of Edward Effingham's lands!"
10149{_}3077{_}"Nay, sir, a shorter process might be adopted."
10149{_}3078{_}"It might, indeed, sir, and such a process has been adopted by my cousin, in giving the usual notice, in the newspaper, against trespassing.
10149{_}3079{_}But, Mr. Bragg, you must know that I took great pains, three years since, when repairing this house, to correct the mistake on this very point, into which I found that your immaculate public had fallen, through its disposition to know more of other people's affairs, than those concerned knew of themselves."
10149{_}3080{_}Aristabulus said no more, but gave the matter up in despair.
10149{_}3081{_}On quitting the house, he proceeded forthwith, to inform those most interested of the determination of Mr. Effingham, not to be trampled on by any pretended meeting of the public.
10149{_}3082{_}Common sense, not to say common honesty, began to resume its sway, and prudence put in its plea, by way of applying the corrective.
10149{_}3083{_}Both he and Mr.
10149{_}3084{_}Dodge, however, agreed that there was an unheard-of temerity in thus resisting the people, and this too without a commensurate object, as the pecuniary value of the disputed point was of no material consequence to either party.
10149{_}3085{_}The reader is not, by any means, to suppose that Aristabulus Bragg and Steadfast Dodge belonged to the same variety of the human species, in consequence of their unity of sentiment in this affair, and certain other general points of resemblance in their manner and modes of thinking.
10149{_}3086{_}As a matter of necessity each partook of those features of caste, condition, origin, and association that characterize their particular set; but when it came to the nicer distinctions that mark true individuality, it would not have been easy to find two men more essentially different in character.
10149{_}3087{_}The first was bold, morally and physically, aspiring, self-possessed, shrewd, singularly adapted to succeed in his schemes where he knew the parties, intelligent, after his tastes, and apt.
10149{_}3088{_}Had it been his fortune to be thrown earlier into a better sphere, the same natural qualities that rendered him so expert in his present situation, would have conduced to his improvement, and most probably would have formed a gentleman, a scholar, and one who could have contributed largely to the welfare and tastes of his fellow-creatures.
10149{_}3089{_}That such was not his fate, was more his misfortune than his fault, for his plastic character had readily taken the impression of those things that from propinquity alone, pressed hardest on it.
10149{_}3090{_}On the other hand Steadfast was a hypocrite by nature, cowardly, envious, and malignant; and circumstances had only lent their aid to the natural tendencies of his disposition.
10149{_}3091{_}That two men so differently constituted at their births, should meet, as it might be in a common centre, in so many of their habits and opinions, was merely the result of accident and education.
10149{_}3092{_}Among the other points of resemblance between these two persons, was that fault of confounding the cause with the effects of the peculiar institutions under which they had been educated and lived.
10149{_}3093{_}Because the law gave to the public, that authority which, under other systems, is entrusted either to one, or to the few they believed the public was invested with far more power than a right understanding of their own principles would have shown.
10149{_}3094{_}In a word, both these persons made a mistake which is getting to be too common in America, that of supposing the institutions of the country were all means and no end.
10149{_}3095{_}Under this erroneous impression they saw only the machinery of the government, becoming entirely forgetful that the power which was given to the people collectively, was only so given to secure to them as perfect a liberty as possible, in their characters of individuals.
10149{_}3096{_}Neither had risen sufficiently above vulgar notions, to understand that public opinion, in order to be omnipotent, or even formidable beyond the inflictions of the moment, must be right; and that, if a solitary man renders himself contemptible by taking up false notions inconsiderately and unjustly, bodies of men, falling into the same error, incur the same penalties, with the additional stigma of having acted as cowards.
10149{_}3097{_}There was also another common mistake into which Messrs. Bragg and Dodge had permitted themselves to fall, through the want of a proper distinction between principles.
10149{_}3098{_}Resisting the popular will, on the part of an individual, they considered arrogance and aristocracy, _per se_, without at all entering into the question of the right, or the wrong.
10149{_}3099{_}The people, rightly enough in the general signification of the term, they deemed to be sovereign; and they belonged to a numerous class, who view disobedience to the sovereign in a democracy, although it be in his illegal caprices, very much as the subject of a despot views disobedience to his prince.
10149{_}3100{_}It is scarcely necessary to say, that Mr. Effingham and his cousin viewed these matters differently.
10149{_}3101{_}Clear headed, just-minded, and liberal in all his practices, the former, in particular, was greatly pained by the recent occurrence; and he paced his library in silence, for several minutes after Mr. Bragg and his companion had withdrawn, really too much grieved to speak.
10149{_}3102{_}"This is, altogether, a most extraordinary procedure, John," he at length observed, "and, it strikes me, that it is but an indifferent reward for the liberality with which I have permitted others to use my property, these thirty years; often, very often, as you well know, to my own discomfort, and to that of my friends."
10149{_}3103{_}"I have told you, Ned, that you were not to expect the America on your return, that you left behind you on your departure for Europe.
10149{_}3104{_}I insist that no country has so much altered for the worse, in so short a time."
10149{_}3105{_}"That unequalled pecuniary prosperity should sensibly impair the manners of what is termed the world, By introducing suddenly lame bodies of uninstructed and untrained men and women into society, is a natural consequence of obvious causes; that it should corrupt morals, even, we have a right to expect, for we are taught to believe it the most corrupting influence under which men can live; but, I confess, I did not expect to see the day, when a body of strangers, birds of passage, creatures of an hour, should assume a right to call on the old and long-established inhabitants of a country, to prove their claims to their possessions, and this, too, in an unusual and unheard-of manner, under the penalty of being violently deprived of them!"
10149{_}3106{_}"Long established!"
10149{_}3107{_}repeated John Effingham, laughing; "what do you term long established?
10149{_}3108{_}Have you not been absent a dozen years, and do not these people reduce everything to the level of their own habits.
10149{_}3109{_}I suppose, now, you fancy you can go to Rome or Jerusalem, or Constantinople, and remain four or five lustres, and then come coolly back to Templeton.
10149{_}3110{_}and, on taking possession of this house again, call yourself an old resident."
10149{_}3111{_}"I certainly do suppose I have that right.
10149{_}3112{_}How many English, Russians, and Germans, did we meet in Italy, the residents of years, who still retained all their natural and local right and feelings!"
10149{_}3113{_}"Ay, that is in countries where society is permanent, and men get accustomed to look on the same objects, hear the same names, and see the same faces for their entire lives.
10149{_}3114{_}I have had the curiosity to inquire, and have ascertained that none of the old, permanent families have been active in this affair of the Point, but that all the clamour has been made by those you call the birds of passage.
10149{_}3115{_}But what of that?
10149{_}3116{_}These people fancy everything reduced to the legal six months required to vote; and that rotation in persons is as necessary to republicanism as rotation in office."
10149{_}3117{_}"Is is not extraordinary that persons who can know so little on the subject, should be thus indiscreet and positive?"
10149{_}3118{_}"It is not extraordinary in America.
10149{_}3119{_}Look about you, Ned, and you will see adventurers uppermost everywhere; in the government, in your towns, in your villages, in the country, even.
10149{_}3120{_}We are a nation of changes.
10149{_}3121{_}Much of this, I admit, is the fair consequence of legitimate causes, as an immense region, in forest, cannot be peopled on any other conditions.
10149{_}3122{_}But this necessity has infected the entire national character, and men get to be impatient of any sameness, even though it be useful.
10149{_}3123{_}Everything goes to confirm this feeling, instead of opposing it.
10149{_}3124{_}The constant recurrences of the elections accustom men to changes in their public functionaries; the great increase in the population brings new faces; and the sudden accumulations of property place new men in conspicuous stations.
10149{_}3125{_}The architecture of the country is barely becoming sufficiently respectable to render it desirable to preserve the buildings, without which we shall have no monuments to revere.
10149{_}3126{_}In short, everything contributes to produce such a state of things, painful as it may be to all of any feeling, and little to oppose it."
10149{_}3127{_}"You colour highly, Jack; and no picture loses in tints, in being retouched by you."
10149{_}3128{_}"Look into the first paper that offers, and you will see the _young men_ of the country hardily invited to meet by themselves, to consult concerning public affairs, as if they were impatient of the counsels and experience of their fathers.
10149{_}3129{_}No country can prosper, where the ordinary mode of transacting the business connected with the root of the government, commences with this impiety."
10149{_}3130{_}"This is a disagreeable feature in the national character, certainly; but we must remember the arts employed by the designing to practise on the inexperienced."
10149{_}3131{_}"Had I a son, who presumed to denounce the wisdom and experience of his father, in this disrespectful mariner, I would disinherit the rascal!"
10149{_}3132{_}"Ah, Jack, bachelor's children are notoriously well educated, and well mannered.
10149{_}3133{_}We will hope, however, that time will bring its changes also, and that one of them will be a greater constancy in persons, things, and the affections."
10149{_}3134{_}"Time _will_ bring its changes, Ned; but all of them that are connected with individual rights, as opposed to popular caprice, or popular interests, are likely to be in the wrong direction."
10149{_}3135{_}"The tendency is certainly to substitute popularity for the right, but we must take the good with the bad; Even you, Jack, would not exchange this popular oppression for any other system under which you have lived."
10149{_}3136{_}"I don't know that--I don't know that.
10149{_}3137{_}Of all tyranny, a vulgar tyranny is to me the most odious."
10149{_}3138{_}"You used to admire the English system, but I think observation has lessened your particular admiration in that quarter;" said Mr. Effingham, smiling in a way that his cousin perfectly understood.
10149{_}3139{_}"Harkee, Ned; we all take up false notions in youth, and this was one of mine; but, of the two, I should prefer the cold, dogged domination of English law, with its fruits, the heartlessness of a sophistication without parallel, to being trampled on by every arrant blackguard that may happen to traverse this valley, in his wanderings after dollars.
10149{_}3140{_}There is one thing you yourself must admit; the public is a little too apt to neglect the duties it ought to discharge, and to assume duties it has no right to fulfil."
10149{_}3141{_}This remark ended the discourse.
10149{_}3142{_}Chapter XVI.
10149{_}3143{_}Her breast was a brave palace, a broad street, Where all heroic,   ample thoughts did meet, Where nature such a tenement had ta'en,   That other souls, to hers, dwelt in 'a lane.
10149{_}3144{_}JOHN NORTON.
10149{_}3145{_}The village of Templeton, it has been already intimated, was a miniature town.
10149{_}3146{_}Although it contained within the circle of its houses, half-a-dozen residences with grounds, and which were dignified with names, as has been also said, it did not cover a surface of more than a mile square; that disposition to concentration, which is as peculiar to an American town, as the disposition to diffusion is peculiar to the country population, and which seems almost to prescribe that a private dwelling shall have but three windows in front, and a _facade_ of twenty-five feet, having presided at the birth of this spot, as well as at the birth of so many of its predecessors and contemporaries.
10149{_}3147{_}In one of its more retired streets (for Templeton had its publicity and retirement, the latter after a very village fashion, however,) dwelt a widow-- bewitched of small worldly means, five children, and of great capacity for circulating intelligence.
10149{_}3148{_}Mrs. Abbott, for so was this demi-relict called, was just on the verge of what is termed the "good society" of the village, the most uneasy of all positions for an ambitious and _ci-devant_ pretty woman to be placed in.
10149{_}3149{_}She had not yet abandoned the hope of obtaining a divorce and its _suites_; was singularly, nay, rabidly devout, if we may coin the adverb; in her own eyes she was perfection, in those of her neighbours slightly objectionable; and she was altogether a droll, and by no means an unusual compound of piety, censoriousness, charity, proscription, gossip, kindness, meddling, ill-nature, and decency.
10149{_}3150{_}The establishment of Mrs. Abbott, like her house, was necessarily very small, and she kept no servant but a girl she called her help, a very suitable appellation, by the way, as they did most of the work of the _menage_ in common.
10149{_}3151{_}This girl, in addition to cooking and washing, was the confidant of all her employer's wandering notions of mankind in general, and of her neighbours in particular; as often, helping her mistress in circulating her comments on the latter, as in anything else.
10149{_}3152{_}Mrs. Abbott knew nothing of the Effinghams, except by a hearsay that got its intelligence from her own school, being herself a late arrival in the place.
10149{_}3153{_}She had selected Templeton as a residence on account of its cheapness, and, having neglected to comply with the forms of the world, by hesitating about making the customary visit to the Wigwam, she began to resent, in her spirit at least, Eve's delicate forbearance from obtruding herself, where, agreeably to all usage, she had a perfect right to suppose she was not desired.
10149{_}3154{_}It was in this spirit, then, that she sat, conversing with Jenny, as the maid of all work was called, the morning after the conversation related in the last chapter, in her snug little parlour, sometimes plying her needle, and oftener thrusting her head out of a window which commanded a view of the principal street of the place, in order to see what her neighbours might be about.
10149{_}3155{_}"This is a most extraordinary course Mr. Effingham has taken concerning the Point," said Mrs. Abbott, "and I _do_ hope the people will bring him to his senses.
10149{_}3156{_}Why, Jenny, the public has used that place ever since I can remember, and I have now lived in Templeton quite fifteen months.--What _can_ induce Mr. Howel to go so often to that barber's shop, which stands directly opposite the parlour windows of Mrs. Bennett--one would think the man was all beard."
10149{_}3157{_}"I suppose Mr. Howel gets shaved sometimes," said the logical Jenny.
10149{_}3158{_}"Not he; or if he does, no decent man would think of posting himself before a lady's window to do such a thing.--Orlando Furioso," calling to her eldest son, a boy of eleven, "run over to Mr. Jones's store, and listen to what the people are talking about, and bring me back the news, as soon as any thing worth hearing drops from any body; and stop as you come back, my son, and borrow neighbour Brown's gridiron.
10149{_}3159{_}Jenny, it is most time to think of putting over the potatoes."
10149{_}3160{_}"Ma'--" cried Orlando Furioso, from the front door, Mrs. Abbott being very rigid in requiring that all her children should call her 'ma',' being so much behind the age as actually not to know that 'mother' had got to be much the genteeler term of the two; "Ma'," roared Orlando Furioso, "suppose there is no news at Mr. Jones's store?"
10149{_}3161{_}"Then go to the nearest tavern; something must be stirring this fine morning, and I'm dying to know what it can possibly be.
10149{_}3162{_}Mind you bring something besides the gridiron back with you.
10149{_}3163{_}Hurry, or never come home again as long as you live!
10149{_}3164{_}As I was saying, Jenny, the right of the public, which is our right, for we are a part of the public, to this Point, is as clear as day, and I am only astonished at the impudence of Mr. Effingham in pretending to deny it.
10149{_}3165{_}I dare say his French daughter has put him up to it.
10149{_}3166{_}They say she is monstrous arrogant!"
10149{_}3167{_}"Is Eve Effingham, French," said Jenny, studiously avoiding any of the usual terms of civility and propriety, by way of showing her breeding--"well, I had always thought her nothing but Templeton born!"
10149{_}3168{_}"What signifies where a person was born?
10149{_}3169{_}where they _live_, is the essential thing; and Eve Effingham has lived so long in France, that she speaks nothing but broken English; and Miss Debby told me last week, that in drawing up a subscription paper for a new cushion to the reading-desk of her people, she actually spelt 'charity' 'carrotty.'"
10149{_}3170{_}"Is that French, Miss Abbott?"
10149{_}3171{_}"I rather think it is, Jenny; the French are very niggardly, and give their poor carrots to live on, and so they have adopted the word, I suppose.
10149{_}3172{_}You, Byansy-Alzumy-Ann, (Bianca-Alzuma-Ann!)"
10149{_}3173{_}"Marm!"
10149{_}3174{_}"Byansy-Alzumy-Ann!
10149{_}3175{_}who taught you to call me marm!
10149{_}3176{_}Is this the way you have learned your catechism?
10149{_}3177{_}Say, ma', this instant."
10149{_}3178{_}"Ma'."
10149{_}3179{_}"Take your bonnet, my child, and run down to Mrs. Wheaton's, and ask her if any thing new has turned up about the Point, this morning; and, do you hear, Byansy-Alzumy-Ann Abbott--how the child starts away, as if she were sent on a matter of life and death!"
10149{_}3180{_}"Why, ma', I want to hear the news, too."
10149{_}3181{_}"Very likely, my dear, but, by stopping to get your errand, you may learn more than by being in such a hurry.
10149{_}3182{_}Stop in at Mrs. Green's, and ask how the people liked the lecture of the strange parson, last evening--and ask her if she can lend me a watering-pot, Now, run, and be back as soon as possible.
10149{_}3183{_}Never loiter when you carry news, child."
10149{_}3184{_}"No one has a right to stop the man, I believe, Miss Abbott," put in Jenny, very appositely.
10149{_}3185{_}"That, indeed, have they not, or else we could not calculate the consequences.
10149{_}3186{_}You may remember, Jenny, the pious, even, had to give up that point, public convenience being; too strong for them.
10149{_}3187{_}Roger- Demetrius-Benjamin!"
10149{_}3188{_}--calling to a second boy, two years younger than his brother--"your eyes are better than mine--who are all those people collected together in the street.
10149{_}3189{_}Is not Mr. Howel among them?"
10149{_}3190{_}"I do not know, ma'!"
10149{_}3191{_}answered Roger-Demetrius-Benjamin, gaping.
10149{_}3192{_}"Then run, this minute, and see, and don't stop to look for your hat.
10149{_}3193{_}As you come back, step into the tailor's shop and ask if your new jacket is most done, and what the news is?
10149{_}3194{_}I rather think, Jenny, we shall find out something worth hearing, in the course of the day.
10149{_}3195{_}By the way, they do say that Grace Van Cortlandt, Eve Effingham's cousin, is under concern."
10149{_}3196{_}"Well, she is the last person I should think would be troubled about any thing, for every body says she is so desperate rich she might eat off of silver, if she liked; and she is sure of being married, some time or other."
10149{_}3197{_}"That ought to lighten her concern, you think.
10149{_}3198{_}Oh!
10149{_}3199{_}it does my heart good when I see any of those flaunty people right well exercised!
10149{_}3200{_}Nothing would make me happier than to see Eve Effingham groaning fairly in the spirit!
10149{_}3201{_}That would teach her to take away the people's Points."
10149{_}3202{_}"But, Miss Abbott, then she would become almost as good a woman as you are yourself,"  "I am a miserable, graceless, awfully wicked sinner!
10149{_}3203{_}Twenty times a day do I doubt whether I am actually converted or not.
10149{_}3204{_}Sin has got such a hold of my very heart-strings, that I sometimes think they will crack before it lets go.
10149{_}3205{_}Rinaldo-Rinaldini-Timothy, my child, do you toddle across the way, and give my compliments to Mrs. Hulbert, and inquire if it be true that young Dickson, the lawyer, is really engaged to Aspasia Tubbs or not?
10149{_}3206{_}and borrow a skimmer, or a tin pot, or any thing you can carry, for we may want something of the sort in the course of the day.
10149{_}3207{_}I do believe, Jenny, that a worse creature than myself is hardly to be found in Templeton."
10149{_}3208{_}"Why, Miss Abbott," returned Jenny, who had heard too much of this self-abasement to be much alarmed at it, "this is giving almost as bad an account of yourself, as I heard somebody, that I won't name, give of you last week."
10149{_}3209{_}"And who is your somebody, I should like to know?
10149{_}3210{_}I dare say, one no better than a formalist, who thinks that reading prayers out of a book, kneeling, bowing, and changing gowns, is religion!
10149{_}3211{_}Thank Heaven, I'm pretty indifferent to the opinions of such people.
10149{_}3212{_}Harkee, Jenny; if I thought I was no better than some persons I could name, I'd give the point of salvation up, in despair!"
10149{_}3213{_}"Miss Abbott," roared a rugged, dirty-faced, bare-footed boy, who entered without knocking, and stood in the middle of the room, with his hat on, with a suddenness that denoted great readiness in entering other people's possessions; "Miss Abbott, ma' wants to know if you are likely to go from home this week?"
10149{_}3214{_}"Why, what in nature can she want to know that for, Ordeal Bumgrum?"
10149{_}3215{_}Mrs. Abbott pronounced this singular name, however, "Ordeel."
10149{_}3216{_}"Oh!
10149{_}3217{_}she _warnts_ to know."
10149{_}3218{_}"So do I _warnt_ to know; and know I will.
10149{_}3219{_}Run home this instant, and ask your mother why she has sent you here with this message.
10149{_}3220{_}Jenny, I am much exercised to find out the reason Mrs. Bumgrum should have sent Ordeal over with such a question."
10149{_}3221{_}"I did hear that Miss Bumgrum intended to make a journey herself, and she may want your company."
10149{_}3222{_}"Here comes Ordeal back, and we shall soon be out of the clouds.
10149{_}3223{_}What a boy that is for errands.
10149{_}3224{_}He is worth all my sons put together.
10149{_}3225{_}You never see him losing time by going round by the streets, but away he goes over the garden fences like a cat, or he will whip through a house, if standing in his way, as if he were its owner, should the door happen to be open.
10149{_}3226{_}Well, Ordeal?"
10149{_}3227{_}But Ordeal was out of breath, and although Jenny shook him, as if to shake the news out of him, and Mrs. Abbott actually shook her fist, in her impatience to be enlightened, nothing could induce the child to speak, until he had recovered his wind.
10149{_}3228{_}"I believe he does it on purpose," said the provoked maid.
10149{_}3229{_}"It's just like him!"
10149{_}3230{_}cried the mistress; "the very best news-carrier in the village is actually spoilt because he is thick-winded."
10149{_}3231{_}"I wish folks wouldn't make their fences so high," Ordeal exclaimed, the instant he found breath.
10149{_}3232{_}"I can't see of what use it is to make a fence people can't climb!"
10149{_}3233{_}"What does your mother say?"
10149{_}3234{_}cried Jenny repeating her shake, _con amore_.
10149{_}3235{_}"Ma, wants to know, Miss Abbott, if you don't intend to use it yourself, if you will lend her your name for a few days, to go to Utica with?
10149{_}3236{_}She says folks don't treat her half as well when she is called Bumgrum, as when she has another name, and she thinks she'd like to try yours, this time."
10149{_}3237{_}"Is that all!--You needn't have been so hurried about such a trifle, Ordeal.
10149{_}3238{_}Give my compliments to your mother, and tell her she is quite welcome to my name, and I hope it will be serviceable to her."
10149{_}3239{_}"She says she is willing to pay for the use of it, if you will tell her what the damage will be."
10149{_}3240{_}"Oh!
10149{_}3241{_}it's not worth while to speak of such a trifle I dare say she will bring it back quite as good as when she took it away.
10149{_}3242{_}I am no such unneighbourly or aristocratical person as to wish to keep my name all to myself.
10149{_}3243{_}Tell your mother she is welcome to mine, and to keep it as long as she likes, and not to say any thing about pay; I may want to borrow hers, or something else, one of these days, though, to say the truth, my neighbours _are_ apt to complain of me as unfriendly and proud for not borrowing as much as a good neighbour ought."
10149{_}3244{_}Ordeal departed, leaving Mrs. Abbot in some such condition as that of the man who had no shadow.
10149{_}3245{_}A rap at the door interrupted the further discussion of the old subject, and Mr.
10149{_}3246{_}Steadfast Dodge appeared in answer to the permission to enter.
10149{_}3247{_}Mr.
10149{_}3248{_}Dodge and Mrs. Abbott were congenial spirits, in the way of news, he living by it, and she living on it.
10149{_}3249{_}"You are very welcome, Mr.
10149{_}3250{_}Dodge," the mistress of the house commenced; "I hear you passed the day, yesterday, up at the Effinghamses."
10149{_}3251{_}"Why, yes, Mrs. Abbott, the Effinghams insisted on it, and I could not well get over the sacrifice, after having been their shipmate so long.
10149{_}3252{_}Besides it is a little relief to talk French, when one has been so long in the daily practice of it."
10149{_}3253{_}"I hear there is company at the house?"
10149{_}3254{_}"Two of our fellow-travellers, merely.
10149{_}3255{_}An English baronet, and a young man of whom less is known than one could wish.
10149{_}3256{_}He is a mysterious person, and I hate mystery, Mrs.
10149{_}3257{_}Abbott."
10149{_}3258{_}"In that, then, Mr.
10149{_}3259{_}Dodge, you and I are alike.
10149{_}3260{_}I think every thing should be known.
10149{_}3261{_}Indeed, that is not a free country in which there are any secrets.
10149{_}3262{_}I keep nothing from my neighbours, and, to own the truth, I do not like my neighbours to keep any thing from me."
10149{_}3263{_}"Then you'll hardly like the Effinghams, for I never yet met with a more close-mouthed family.
10149{_}3264{_}Although I was so long in the ship with Miss Eve, I never heard her once speak of her want of appetite; of sea-sickness, or of any thing relating to her ailings even: no?
10149{_}3265{_}can you imagine how close she is on the subject of the beaux; I do not think I ever heard her use the word, or so much as allude to any walk or ride she ever took with a single man.
10149{_}3266{_}I set her down, Mrs. Abbott, as unqualifiedly artful!"
10149{_}3267{_}"That you may with certainty, sir, for there is no more sure sign that a young woman is all the while thinking of the beaux, than her never mentioning them."
10149{_}3268{_}"That I believe to be human nature; no ingenuous person ever thinks much of the particular subject of conversation.
10149{_}3269{_}What is your opinion, Mrs. Abbott, of the contemplated match at the Wigwam?"
10149{_}3270{_}"Match!"
10149{_}3271{_}exclaimed Mrs.
10149{_}3272{_}Abbott.--"What, already!
10149{_}3273{_}It is the most indecent thing I ever heard of!
10149{_}3274{_}Why, Mr.
10149{_}3275{_}Dodge, the family has not been home a fortnight, and to think so soon of getting married!
10149{_}3276{_}It is quite as bad as a widower's marrying within the month."
10149{_}3277{_}Mrs. Abbott made a distinction, habitually, between the cases of widowers and widows, as the first, she maintained, might get married whenever they pleased, and the latter only when they got offers; and she felt just that sort of horror of a man's thinking of marrying too soon after the death of his wife, as might be expected in one who actually thought of a second husband before the first was dead.
10149{_}3278{_}"Why, yes," returned Steadfast, "it is a little premature, perhaps, though they have been long acquainted.
10149{_}3279{_}Still, as you say, it would be more decent to wait and see what may turn up in a country, that, to them, may be said to be a foreign land."
10149{_}3280{_}"But, who are the parties, Mr.
10149{_}3281{_}Dodge."
10149{_}3282{_}"Miss Eve Effingham, and Mr. John Effingham"  "Mr. John Effingham!"
10149{_}3283{_}exclaimed the lady, who had lent her name to a neighbour, aghast, for this was knocking one of her own day-dreams in the head, "well this is too much!
10149{_}3284{_}But he shall not marry her, sir; the law will prevent it, and we live in a country of laws.
10149{_}3285{_}A man cannot marry his own niece."
10149{_}3286{_}"It is excessively improper, and ought to be put a stop to.
10149{_}3287{_}And yet these Effinghams do very much as they please."
10149{_}3288{_}"I am very sorry to hear that; they are extremely disagreeable," said Mrs. Abbott, with a look of eager inquiry, as if afraid the answer might be in the negative.
10149{_}3289{_}"As much so as possible; they have hardly a way that you would like, my dear ma'am; and are as close-mouthed as if they were afraid of committing themselves."
10149{_}3290{_}"Desperate bad news-carriers, I am told, Mr.
10149{_}3291{_}Dodge.
10149{_}3292{_}There is Dorindy (Dorinda) Mudge, who was employed there by Eve and Grace one day; she tells me she tried all she could to get them to talk, by speaking of the most common things; things that one of my children knew all about; such as the affairs of the neighbourhood, and how people are getting on; and, though they would listen a little, and that is something, I admit, not a syllable could she get in the way of answer, or remark.
10149{_}3293{_}She tells me that, several times, she had a mind to quit, for it is monstrous unpleasant to associate with your tongue-tied folks."
10149{_}3294{_}"I dare say Miss Effingham could throw out a hint now and then, concerning the voyage and her late fellow-travellers," said Steadfast, casting an uneasy glance at his companion.
10149{_}3295{_}"Not she.
10149{_}3296{_}Dorindy maintains that it is impossible to get a sentiment out of her concerning a single fellow-creature.
10149{_}3297{_}When she talked of the late unpleasant affair of poor neighbour Bronson's family--a melancholy transaction that, Mr.
10149{_}3298{_}Dodge, and I shouldn't wonder if it went to nigh break Mrs. Bronson's heart--but when Dorindy mentioned this, which is bad enough to stir the sensibility of a frog, neither of my young ladies replied, or put a single question.
10149{_}3299{_}In this respect Grace is as bad as Eve, and Eve is as bad as Grace, they say.
10149{_}3300{_}Instead of so much as seeming to wish to know any more, what does my Miss Eve do, but turn to some daubs of paintings, and point out to her cousin what she was pleased to term peculiarities in Swiss usages.
10149{_}3301{_}Then the two hussies would talk of nature, 'our beautiful nature' Dorindy says Eve had the impudence to call it, and, as if human nature and its failings and backsliding wore not a fitter subject for a young woman's discourse, than a silly conversation about lakes, and rocks, and trees, and as if she _owned_ the nature about Templeton.
10149{_}3302{_}It is my opinion, Mr.
10149{_}3303{_}Dodge, that downright ignorance is at the bottom of it all, for Dorindy says that they actually know no more of the intricacies of the neighbourhood than if they lived in Japan."
10149{_}3304{_}"All pride, Mrs. Abbott; rank pride.
10149{_}3305{_}They feel themselves too great to enter into the minutiae of common folks' concerns.
10149{_}3306{_}I often tried Miss Effingham coming from England; and things touching private interests, that I know she did and must understand, she always disdainfully refused to enter into.
10149{_}3307{_}Oh!
10149{_}3308{_}she is, a real Tartar, in her way; and what she does not wish to do, you never can make her do!"
10149{_}3309{_}"Have you heard that Grace is under concern?"
10149{_}3310{_}"Not a breath of it; under whose preaching was she sitting, Mrs.
10149{_}3311{_}Abbott?"
10149{_}3312{_}"That is more than I can tell you; not under the church parson's, I'll engage; no one ever heard of a real, active, regenerating, soul- reviving, spirit-groaning and fruit-yielding conversion under _his_ ministry."
10149{_}3313{_}"No, there is very little unction in that persuasion generally.
10149{_}3314{_}How cold and apathetic they are, in these soul-stirring times!
10149{_}3315{_}Not a sinner has been writhing on _their_ floor, I'll engage, nor a wretch transferred into a saint, in the twinkling of an eye, by _that_ parson.
10149{_}3316{_}Well, _we_ have every reason to be grateful, Mrs.
10149{_}3317{_}Abbott."
10149{_}3318{_}"That we have, for most glorious have been our privileges!
10149{_}3319{_}To be sure that is a sinful pride that can puff up a wretched, sinful being like Eve Effingham to such a pass of conceit, as to induce her to think she is raised above thinking of, and taking an interest in the affairs of her neighbours.
10149{_}3320{_}Now, for my part, conversion has so far opened _my_ heart, that I do actually feel as if I wanted to know all about the meanest creature in Templeton."
10149{_}3321{_}"That's the true spirit, Mrs. Abbott; stick to that, and your redemption is secure.
10149{_}3322{_}I only edit a newspaper, by way of showing an interest in mankind."
10149{_}3323{_}"I hope, Mr.
10149{_}3324{_}Dodge, the press does not mean to let this matter of the Point sleep; the press is the true guardian of the public rights, and I can tell you the whole community looks to it for support, in this crisis."
10149{_}3325{_}"We shall not fail to do our duty," said Mr.
10149{_}3326{_}Dodge, looking over his shoulder, and speaking lower.
10149{_}3327{_}"What!
10149{_}3328{_}shall one insignificant individual, who has not a single right above that of the meanest citizen in the county, oppress this great and powerful community!
10149{_}3329{_}What if Mr. Effingham does own this point of land--"  "But he does _not_ own it," interrupted Mrs. Abbott.
10149{_}3330{_}"Ever since I have known Templeton, the public has owned it.
10149{_}3331{_}The public, moreover, says it owns it, and what the public says, in this happy country, is law."
10149{_}3332{_}"But, allowing that the public does not own--"  "It _does_ own it, Mr.
10149{_}3333{_}Dodge," the nameless repeated, positively.
10149{_}3334{_}"Well, ma'am, own or no own, this is not a country in which the press ought to be silent, when a solitary individual undertakes to trample on the public.
10149{_}3335{_}Leave that matter to us, Mrs. Abbott; it is in good hands, and shall be well taken care of."
10149{_}3336{_}"I'm piously glad of it!"
10149{_}3337{_}"I mention this to you, as to a friend," continued Mr.
10149{_}3338{_}Dodge, cautiously drawing from his pocket a manuscript, which he prepared to read to his companion who sat with a devouring curiosity, ready to listen.
10149{_}3339{_}The manuscript of Mr.
10149{_}3340{_}Dodge contained a professed account of the affair of the Point.
10149{_}3341{_}It was written obscurely, and was not without its contradictions, but the imagination of Mrs. Abbott supplied all the vacuums, and reconciled all the contradictions.
10149{_}3342{_}The article was so liberal of its professions of contempt for Mr. Effingham, that every rational man was compelled to wonder, why a quality, that is usually so passive, should, in this particular instance, be aroused to so sudden and violent activity.
10149{_}3343{_}In the way of facts, not one was faithfully stated; and there were several deliberate, unmitigated falsehoods, which went essentially to colour the whole account.
10149{_}3344{_}"I think this will answer the purpose," said Steadfast, "and we have taken means to see that it shall be well circulated."
10149{_}3345{_}"This will do them good," cried Mrs. Abbott; almost breathless with delight.
10149{_}3346{_}"I hope folks will believe it."
10149{_}3347{_}"No fear of that.
10149{_}3348{_}If it were a party thing, now, one half would believe it, as a matter of course, and the other half would not believe it, as a matter of course; but, in a private matter, lord bless you, ma'am, people are always ready to believe any thing that will give them something to talk about."
10149{_}3349{_}Here the _tete a tete_ was interrupted by the return of Mrs. Abbott's different messengers, all of whom, unlike the dove sent forth from the ark, brought back something in the way of hopes.
10149{_}3350{_}The Point was a general theme, and, though the several accounts flatly contradicted each other, Mrs. Abbott, in the general benevolence of her pious heart, found the means to extract corroboration of her wishes from each.
10149{_}3351{_}Mr.
10149{_}3352{_}Dodge was as good as his word, and the account appeared.
10149{_}3353{_}The press throughout the country seized with avidity on any thing that helped to fill its columns.
10149{_}3354{_}No one appeared disposed to inquire into the truth of the account, or after the character of the original authority.
10149{_}3355{_}It was in print, and that struck the great majority of the editors and their readers, as a sufficient sanction.
10149{_}3356{_}Few, indeed, were they, who lived so much under a proper self-control, as to hesitate; and this rank injustice was done a private citizen, as much without moral restraint, as without remorse, by those, who, to take their own accounts of the matter, were the regular and habitual champions of human rights!
10149{_}3357{_}John Effingham pointed out this extraordinary scene of reckless wrong, to his wondering cousin, with the cool sarcasm, with which he was apt to assail the weaknesses and crimes of the country.
10149{_}3358{_}His firmness, united to that of his cousin, however, put a stop to the publication of the resolutions of Aristabulus's meeting, and when a sufficient time had elapsed to prove that these prurient denouncers of their fellow-citizens had taken wit in their anger, he procured them, and had them published himself, as the most effectual means of exposing the real character of the senseless mob, that had thus disgraced liberty, by assuming its professions and its usages.
10149{_}3359{_}To an observer of men, the end of this affair presented several strong points for comment.
10149{_}3360{_}As soon as the truth became generally known, in reference to the real ownership, and the public came to ascertain that instead of hitherto possessing a right, it had, in fact been merely enjoying a favour, those who had commit ted themselves by their arrogant assumptions of facts, and their indecent outrages, fell back on their self-love, and began to find excuses for their conduct in that of the other party.
10149{_}3361{_}Mr. Effingham was loudly condemned for not having done the very thing, he, in truth, had done, viz: telling the public it did not own his property; and when this was shown to be an absurdity, the complaint followed that what he had done, had been done in precisely such a mode, although it was the mode constantly used by every one else.
10149{_}3362{_}From these vague and indefinite accusations, those most implicated in the wrong, began to deny all their own original assertions, by insisting that they had known all along, that Mr. Effingham owned the property, but that they did not choose he, or any other man, should presume to tell them what they knew already.
10149{_}3363{_}In short, the end of this affair exhibited human nature in its usual aspects of prevarication, untruth, contradiction, and inconsistency, notwithstanding the high profession of liberty made by those implicated; and they who had been the most guilty of wrong, were loudest in their complaints, as if they alone had suffered.
10149{_}3364{_}"This is not exhibiting the country to us, certainly, after so long an absence, in its best appearance," said Mr. Effingham, "I must admit, John; but error belongs to all regions, and to all classes of institutions."
10149{_}3365{_}"Ay, Ned, make the best of it, as usual; but, if you do not come round to my way of thinking, before you are a twelvemonth older, I shall renounce prophesying.
10149{_}3366{_}I wish we could get at the bottom of Miss Effingham's thoughts, on this occasion."
10149{_}3367{_}"Miss Effingham has been grieved, disappointed, nay, shocked," said Eve, "but, still she will not despair of the republic.
10149{_}3368{_}None of our respectable neighbours, in the first place, have shared in this transaction, and that is something; though I confess I feel some surprise that any considerable portion of a community, that respects itself, should quietly allow an ignorant fragment of its own numbers, to misrepresent it so grossly, in an affair that so nearly touches its own character for common sense and justice."
10149{_}3369{_}"You have yet to learn, Miss Effingham, that men can get to be so saturated with liberty, that they become insensible to the nicer feelings.
10149{_}3370{_}The grossest enormities are constantly committed in this good republic of ours, under the pretence of being done by the public, and for the public.
10149{_}3371{_}The public have got to bow to that bugbear, quite as submissively as Gesler would have wished the Swiss to bow to his own cap, as to the cap of Rodolph's substitute.
10149{_}3372{_}Men will have idols, and the Americans have merely set up themselves."
10149{_}3373{_}"And you, cousin Jack, you would be wretched were you doomed to live under a system less free.
10149{_}3374{_}I fear you have the affectation of sometimes saying that which you do not exactly feel."
10149{_}3375{_}Chapter XVII.
10149{_}3376{_}"Come, these are no times to think of dreams--   We'll talk of dreams hereafter."
10149{_}3377{_}SHAKSPEARE.
10149{_}3378{_}The day succeeding that in which the conversation just mentioned occurred, was one of great expectation and delight in the Wigwam.
10149{_}3379{_}Mrs. Hawker and the Bloomfields were expected, and the morning passed away rapidly, under the gay buoyancy of the feelings that usually accompany such anticipations in a country-house.
10149{_}3380{_}The travellers were to leave town the previous evening, and, though the distance was near two hundred and thirty miles, they were engaged to arrive by the usual dinner hour.
10149{_}3381{_}In speed, the Americans, so long as they follow the great routes, are unsurpassed; and even Sir George Templemore, coming, as he did, from a country of MacAdamized roads and excellent posting, expressed his surprise, when given to understand that a journey of this length, near a hundred miles of which were by land, moreover, was to be performed in twenty-four hours, the stops included.
10149{_}3382{_}"One particularly likes this rapid travelling," he remarked, "when it is to bring us such friends as Mrs.
10149{_}3383{_}Hawker."
10149{_}3384{_}"And Mrs. Bloomfield," added Eve, quickly.
10149{_}3385{_}"I rest the credit of the American females on Mrs.
10149{_}3386{_}Bloomfield."
10149{_}3387{_}"More so, than on Mrs. Hawker, Miss Effingham."
10149{_}3388{_}"Not in all that is amiable, respectable, feminine, and lady-like; but certainly more so, in the way of mind.
10149{_}3389{_}I know, Sir George Templemore, as a European, what your opinion is of our sex in this country."
10149{_}3390{_}"Good heaven, my dear Miss Effingham!--My opinion of your sex, in America!
10149{_}3391{_}It is impossible for any one to entertain a higher opinion of your country-women--as I hope to show--as, I trust, my respect and admiration have always proved--nay, Powis, you, as an American, will exonerate me from this want of taste--judgment--feeling--"  Paul laughed, but told the embarrassed and really distressed baronet, that he should leave him in the very excellent hands into which he had fallen.
10149{_}3392{_}"You see that bird, that is sailing so prettily above the roofs of the village," said Eve, pointing with her parasol in the direction she meant; for the three were walking together on the little lawn, in waiting for the appearance of the expected guests; "and I dare say you are ornithologist enough to tell its vulgar name."
10149{_}3393{_}"You are in the humour to be severe this morning--the bird is but a common swallow."
10149{_}3394{_}"One of which will not make a summer, as every one knows.
10149{_}3395{_}Our cosmopolitism is already forgotten, and with it, I fear, our frankness."
10149{_}3396{_}"Since Powis has hoisted his national colours, I do not feel as free on such subjects as formerly," returned Sir George, smiling.
10149{_}3397{_}"When I thought I had a secret ally in him, I was not afraid to concede a little in such things, but his avowal of his country has put me on my guard.
10149{_}3398{_}In no case, however, shall I admit my insensibility to the qualities of your countrywomen.
10149{_}3399{_}Powis, as a native, may take that liberty; but, as for myself, I shall insist they are, at least, the equals of any females I know."
10149{_}3400{_}"In _naivete_, prettiness, delicacy of appearance, simplicity, and sincerity--"  "In sincerity, think you, dear Miss Effingham?"
10149{_}3401{_}"In sincerity, above all things, dear Sir George Templemore.
10149{_}3402{_}Sincerity--nay, frankness is the last quality I should think of denying them."
10149{_}3403{_}"But to return to Mrs. Bloomfield--she is clever, exceedingly clever, I allow; in what is her cleverness to be distinguished from that of one of her sex, on the other side of the ocean?"
10149{_}3404{_}"In nothing, perhaps, did there exist no differences in national characteristics.
10149{_}3405{_}Naples and New-York are in the same latitude, and yet, I think you will agree with me, that there is little resemblance in their populations."
10149{_}3406{_}"I confess I do not understand the allusion--are you quicker witted, Powis?"
10149{_}3407{_}"I will not say that," answered Paul; "but I think I do comprehend Miss Effingham's meaning.
10149{_}3408{_}You have travelled enough to know, that, as a rule, there is more aptitude in a southern, than in a northern people.
10149{_}3409{_}They receive impressions more readily, and are quicker in all their perceptions."
10149{_}3410{_}"I believe this to be true; but, then, you will allow that they are less constant, and have less perseverance?"
10149{_}3411{_}"In that we are agreed, Sir George Templemore," resumed Eve, "though we might differ as to the cause.
10149{_}3412{_}The inconstancy of which you speak, is more connected with moral than physical causes, perhaps, and we, of this region, might claim an exemption from some of them.
10149{_}3413{_}But, Mrs. Bloomfield is to be distinguished from her European rivals, by a frame so singularly feminine as to appear fragile, a delicacy of exterior, that, were it not for that illumined face of hers, might indicate a general feebleness, a sensitiveness and quickness of intellect that amount almost to inspiration; and yet all is balanced by a practical common sense, that renders her as safe a counsellor as she is a warm friend.
10149{_}3414{_}This latter quality causes you sometimes to doubt her genius, it is so very homely and available.
10149{_}3415{_}Now it is in this, that I think the American woman, when she does rise above mediocrity, is particularly to be distinguished from the European.
10149{_}3416{_}The latter, as a genius, is almost always in the clouds, whereas, Mrs. Bloomfield, in her highest flights, is either all heart, or all good sense.
10149{_}3417{_}The nation is practical, and the practical qualities get to be imparted even to its highest order of talents."
10149{_}3418{_}"The English women are thought to be less excitable, and not so much under the influence of sentimentalism, as some of their continental neighbours."
10149{_}3419{_}"And very justly--but----"  "But, what, Miss Effingham--there is, in all this, a slight return to the cosmopolitism, that reminds me of our days of peril and adventure.
10149{_}3420{_}Do not conceal a thought, if you wish to preserve that character."
10149{_}3421{_}"Well, to be sincere, I shall say that your women live under a system too sophisticated and factitious to give fair play to common sense, at all times.
10149{_}3422{_}What, for instance, can be the habitual notions of one, who, professing the doctrines of Christianity, is accustomed to find money placed so very much in the ascendant, as to see it daily exacted in payment for the very first of the sacred offices of the church?
10149{_}3423{_}It would be as rational to contend that a mirror which had been cracked into radii, by a bullet, like those we have so often seen in Paris, would reflect faithfully, as to suppose a mind familiarized to such abuses would be sensitive on practical and common sense things."
10149{_}3424{_}"But, my dear Miss Effingham, this is all habit."
10149{_}3425{_}"I know it is all habit, Sir George Templemore, and a very bad habit it is.
10149{_}3426{_}Even your devoutest clergymen get so accustomed to it, as not to see the capital mistake they make.
10149{_}3427{_}I do not say it is absolutely sinful, where there is no compulsion; but, I hope you agree with me, Mr. Powis, when I say I think a clergyman ought to be so sensitive on such a subject, as to refuse even the little offerings for baptisms, that it is the practice of the wealthy of this country to make."
10149{_}3428{_}"I agree with you entirely, for it would denote a more just perception of the nature of the office they are performing; and they who wish to give can always make occasions."
10149{_}3429{_}"A hint might be taken from Franklin, who is said to have desired his father to ask a blessing on the pork-barrel, by way of condensation," put in John Effingham, who joined them as he spoke, and who had heard a part of the conversation.
10149{_}3430{_}"In this instance an average might be struck in the marriage fee, that should embrace all future baptisms.
10149{_}3431{_}But here comes neighbour Howel to favour us with his opinion.
10149{_}3432{_}Do you like the usages of the English church, as respects baptisms, Howel?"
10149{_}3433{_}"Excellent, the best in the world, John Effingham."
10149{_}3434{_}"Mr. Howel is so true an Englishman," said Eve, shaking hands cordially with their well-meaning neighbour, "that he would give a certificate in favour of polygamy, if it had a British origin."
10149{_}3435{_}"And is not this a more natural sentiment for an American than that which distrusts so much, merely because it comes from the little island?"
10149{_}3436{_}asked Sir George, reproachfully.
10149{_}3437{_}"That is a question I shall leave Mr. Howel himself to answer."
10149{_}3438{_}"Why, Sir George," observed the gentleman alluded to, "I do not attribute my respect for your country, in the least, to origin.
10149{_}3439{_}I endeavour to keep myself free from all sorts of prejudices.
10149{_}3440{_}My admiration of England arises from conviction, and I watch all her movements with the utmost jealousy, in order to see if I cannot find her tripping, though I feel bound to say I have never yet detected her in a single error.
10149{_}3441{_}What a very different picture, France--I hope your governess is not within hearing, Miss Eve; it is not her fault; she was born a French woman, and we would not wish to hurt her feelings--but what a different picture France presents!
10149{_}3442{_}I have watched her narrowly too, these forty years, I may say, and I have never yet found her right; and this, you must allow, is a great deal to be said by one who is thoroughly impartial."
10149{_}3443{_}"This is a terrible picture, indeed, Howel, to come from an unprejudiced man," said John Effingham; "and I make no doubt Sir George Templemore will have a better opinion of himself for ever after--he for a valiant lion, and you for a true prince.
10149{_}3444{_}But yonder is the 'exclusive extra,' which contains our party."
10149{_}3445{_}The elevated bit of lawn on which they were walking commanded a view of the road that led into the village, and the travelling, vehicle engaged by Mrs. Hawker and her friends, was now seen moving along it at a rapid pace.
10149{_}3446{_}Eve expressed her satisfaction, and then all resumed their walk, as some minutes must still elapse previously to the arrival.
10149{_}3447{_}"Exclusive extra!"
10149{_}3448{_}repeated Sir George; "that is a peculiar phrase, and one that denotes any thing but democracy."
10149{_}3449{_}"In any other part of the world a thing would be sufficiently marked, by being 'extra,' but here it requires the addition of 'exclusive,' in order to give it the 'tower stamp,'" said John Effingham, with a curl of his handsome lip.
10149{_}3450{_}"Any thing may be as exclusive as it please, provided it bear the public impress.
10149{_}3451{_}A stagecoach being intended for every body, why, the more exclusive it is, the better.
10149{_}3452{_}The next thing we shall hear of will be exclusive steamboats, exclusive railroads, and both for the uses of the exclusive people."
10149{_}3453{_}Sir George now seriously asked an explanation of the meaning of the term, when Mr. Howel informed him that an 'extra' in America meant a supernumerary coach, to carry any excess of the ordinary number of passengers; whereas an 'exclusive extra' meant a coach expressly engaged by a particular individual.
10149{_}3454{_}"The latter, then, is American posting," observed Sir George.
10149{_}3455{_}"You have got the best idea of it that can be given," said Paul.
10149{_}3456{_}"It is virtually posting with a coachman, instead of postillions, few persons in this country, where so much of the greater distances is done by steam, using their own travelling carriages.
10149{_}3457{_}The American 'exclusive extra' is not only posting, but, in many of the older parts of the country, it is posting of a very good quality."
10149{_}3458{_}"I dare say, now, this is all wrong, if we only knew it," said the simple-minded Mr. Howel.
10149{_}3459{_}"There is nothing exclusive in England, ha, Sir George?"
10149{_}3460{_}Every body laughed except the person who put this question, but the rattling of wheels and the tramping of horses on the village bridge, announced the near approach of the travellers.
10149{_}3461{_}By the time the party had reached the great door in front of the house, the carriage was already in the grounds, and at the next moment, Eve was in the arms of Mrs. Bloomfield.
10149{_}3462{_}It was apparent, at a glance, that more than the expected number of guests was in the vehicle; and as its contents were slowly discharged, the spectators stood around it, with curiosity, to observe who would appear.
10149{_}3463{_}The first person that descended, after the exit of Mrs. Bloomfield, was Captain Truck, who, however, instead of saluting his friends, turned assiduously to the door he had just passed through, to assist Mrs. Hawker to alight.
10149{_}3464{_}Not until this office had been done, did he even look for Eve; for, so profound was the worthy captain's admiration and respect for this venerable lady, that she actually had got to supplant our heroine, in some measure, in his heart.
10149{_}3465{_}Mr. Bloomfield appeared next, and an exclamation of surprise and pleasure proceeded from both Paul and the baronet, as they caught a glimpse of the face of the last of the travellers that got out.
10149{_}3466{_}"Ducie!"
10149{_}3467{_}cried Sir George.
10149{_}3468{_}"This is even better than we expected."
10149{_}3469{_}"Ducie!"
10149{_}3470{_}added Paul, "you are several days before the expected time, and in excellent company."
10149{_}3471{_}The explanation, however, was very simple Captain Ducie had found the facilities for rapid motion much greater than he had expected, and he reached Fort Plain, in the eastward cars, as the remainder of the party arrived in the westward.
10149{_}3472{_}Captain Truck-who had met Mrs. Hawker's party in the river boat, had been intrusted with the duty of making the arrangements, and recognizing Captain Ducie, to their mutual surprise, while engaged in this employment, and ascertaining his destination, the latter was very cordially received into the "exclusive extra."
10149{_}3473{_}Mr. Effingham welcomed all his guests with the hospitality and kindness for which he was distinguished.
10149{_}3474{_}We are no great admirers of the pretension to peculiar national virtues, having ascertained, to our own satisfaction, by tolerably extensive observation, that the moral difference between men is of no great amount; but we are almost tempted to say, on this occasion, that Mr. Effingham received his guests with American hospitality; for if there be one quality that this people can claim to possess in a higher degree than that of most other Christian nations, it is that of a simple, sincere, confiding hospitality.
10149{_}3475{_}For Mrs. Hawker, in common with all who knew her, the owner of the Wigwam entertained a profound respect; and though his less active mind did not take as much pleasure as that of his daughter, in the almost intuitive intelligence of Mrs. Bloomfield, he also felt for this lady a very friendly regard.
10149{_}3476{_}It gave him pleasure to see Eve surrounded by persons of her own sex, of so high a tone of thought and breeding; a tone of thought and breeding, moreover, that was as far removed as possible from anything strained or artificial: and his welcomes were cordial in proportion.
10149{_}3477{_}Mr. Bloomfield was a quiet, sensible, gentleman-like man, whom his wife fervently loved, without making any parade of her attachment and he was also one who had the good sense to make himself agreeable wherever he went.
10149{_}3478{_}Captain Ducie, who, Englishman-like, had required some urging to be induced to present himself before the precise hour named in his own letter, and who had seriously contemplated passing several days in a tavern, previously to showing himself at the Wigwam, was agreeably disappointed at a reception, that would have been just as frank and warm, had he come without any notice at all: for the Effinghams knew that the usages which sophistication and a crowded population perhaps render necessary in older countries, were not needed in their own; and then the circumstance that their quondam pursuer was so near a kinsman of Paul Powis', did not fail to act essentially in his favour.
10149{_}3479{_}"We can offer but little, in these retired mountains, to interest a traveller and a man of the world, Captain Ducie," said Mr. Effingham, when he went to pay his compliments more particularly, after the whole party was in the house; "but there is a common interest in our past adventures to talk about, after all other topics fail.
10149{_}3480{_}When, we met on the ocean, and you deprived us so unexpectedly of our friend Powis, we did not know that you had the better claim of affinity to his company."
10149{_}3481{_}Captain Ducie coloured slightly, but he made his answer with a proper degree of courtesy and gratitude.
10149{_}3482{_}"It is very true," he added, "Powis and myself are relatives, and I shall place all my claims to your hospitality to his account; for I feel that I have been the unwilling cause of too much suffering to your party to bring with me any very pleasant recollections, notwithstanding your kindness in including me as a friend in the adventures of which you speak."
10149{_}3483{_}"Dangers that are happily past, seldom bring very unpleasant recollections, more especially when they were connected with scenes of excitement, I understand, sir, that the unhappy young man, who was the principal cause of all that passed, anticipated the sentence of the law, by destroying himself."
10149{_}3484{_}"He was his own executioner, and the victim of a silly weakness that, I should think, your state of society was yet too young and simple to encourage.
10149{_}3485{_}The idle vanity of making an appearance, a vanity, by the way, that seldom besets gentlemen, or the class to which it may be thought more properly to belong, ruins hundreds of young men in England, and this poor creature was of the number.
10149{_}3486{_}I never was more rejoiced than when he quitted my ship, for the sight of so much weakness sickened one of human nature.
10149{_}3487{_}Miserable as his fate proved to be, and pitiable as his condition really was while in my charge, his case has the alleviating circumstance with me, of having made me acquainted with those whom it might not otherwise have been my good fortune to meet!"
10149{_}3488{_}This civil speech was properly acknowledged, and Mr. Effingham addressed himself to Captain Truck, to whom, in the hurry of the moment, he had not yet said half that his feelings dictated.
10149{_}3489{_}"I am rejoiced to see you under my roof, my worthy friend," taking the rough hand of the old seaman between his own whiter and more delicate fingers, and shaking it with cordiality, "for this _is_ being under my roof, while those town residences have less the air of domestication and familiarity.
10149{_}3490{_}You will spend many of your holidays here, I trust; and when we get a few years older, we will begin to prattle about the marvels we have seen in company."
10149{_}3491{_}The eye of Captain Truck glistened, and, as he return ed the shake by another of twice the energy, and the gentle pressure of Mr. Effingham by a squeeze like that of a vice, he said in his honest off-hand manner--  "The happiest hour I ever knew was that in which I discharged the pilot, the first time out, as a ship-master; the next great event of my life, in the way of happiness, was the moment I found myself on the deck of the Montauk, after we had given those greasy Arabs a him that their room was better than their company; and I really think this very instant must be set down as the third.
10149{_}3492{_}I never knew, my dear sir, how much I truly loved you and your daughter, until both were out of sight."
10149{_}3493{_}"That is so kind and gallant a speech, that it ought not to be lost on the person most concerned.
10149{_}3494{_}Eve, my love, our worthy friend has just made a declaration which will be a novelty to you, who have not been much in the way of listening to speeches of this nature."
10149{_}3495{_}Mr. Effingham then acquainted his daughter with what Captain Truck had just said.
10149{_}3496{_}"This is certainly the first declaration of the sort I ever heard, and with the simplicity of an unpractised young woman, I here avow that the attachment is reciprocal," said the smiling Eve.
10149{_}3497{_}"If there is an indiscretion in this hasty acknowledgement, it must be ascribed to surprise, and to the suddenness with which I have learned my power, for your _parvenues_ are not always perfectly regulated."
10149{_}3498{_}"I hope Mamselle V.A.V.
10149{_}3499{_}is well," returned the Captain, cordially shaking the hand the young lady had given him, "and that she enjoys herself to her liking in this outlandish country?"
10149{_}3500{_}"Mademoiselle Viefville will return you her thanks in person, at dinner; and I believe she does not yet regret _la belle France_ unreasonably; as I regret it myself, in many particulars, it would be unjust not to permit a native of the country some liberty in that way."
10149{_}3501{_}"I perceive a strange face in the room--one of the family, my dear young lady?"
10149{_}3502{_}"Not a relative, but a very old friend.--Shall I have the pleasure of introducing you, Captain?"
10149{_}3503{_}"I hardly dared to ask it, for I know you must have been overworked in this way, lately, but I confess I _should_ like an introduction; I have neither introduced, nor been introduced since I left New-York, with the exception of the case of Captain Ducie, whom I made properly acquainted with Mrs. Hawker and her party as you may suppose.
10149{_}3504{_}They know each other regularly now, and you are saved the trouble of going through the ceremony yourself."
10149{_}3505{_}"And how is it with you and the Bloomfields?
10149{_}3506{_}Did Mrs. Hawker name you to them properly?"
10149{_}3507{_}"That is the most extraordinary thing of the sort I ever knew!
10149{_}3508{_}Not a word was said in the way of introduction, and yet I slid into an acquaintance with Mrs. Bloomfield so easily, that I could not tell how it was done, if my life depended on it.
10149{_}3509{_}But this very old friend of yours, my dear young lady----"  "Captain Truck, Mr. Howel; Mr. Howel, Captain Truck;" said Eve, imitating the most approved manner of the introductory spirit of the day with admirable self-possession and gravity.
10149{_}3510{_}"I am fortunate in having it in my power to make two persons whom I so much esteem acquainted."
10149{_}3511{_}"Captain Truck is the gentleman who commands the Montauk?"
10149{_}3512{_}said Mr. Howel, glancing at Eve, as much as to say, "am I right?"
10149{_}3513{_}"The very same, and the brave seaman to whom we are all indebted for the happiness of standing here at this moment."
10149{_}3514{_}"You are to be envied, Captain Truck; of all the men in your calling, you are exactly the one I should most wish to supplant.
10149{_}3515{_}I understand you actually go to England twice every year!"
10149{_}3516{_}"Three times, sir, when the winds permit.
10149{_}3517{_}I have even seen the old island four times, between January and January."
10149{_}3518{_}"What a pleasure!
10149{_}3519{_}It must be the very acme of navigation to sail between America and England!"
10149{_}3520{_}"It is not unpleasant, sir, from April to November, but the long nights, thick weather, and heavy winds knock off a good deal of the satisfaction for the rest of the year."
10149{_}3521{_}"But I speak of the country; of old England itself; not of the passages."
10149{_}3522{_}"Well, England has what I call a pretty fair coast.
10149{_}3523{_}It is high, and great attention is paid to the lights; but of what account is either coast or lights, if the weather is so thick, you cannot see the end of your flying-jib-boom!"
10149{_}3524{_}"Mr. Howel alludes more particularly to the country, inland," said Eve; "to the towns, the civilization and the other proofs of cultivation and refinement.
10149{_}3525{_}To the government, especially."
10149{_}3526{_}"In my judgment, sir, the government is much too particular about tobacco, and some other trifling things I could name.
10149{_}3527{_}Then it restricts pennants to King's ships, whereas, to my notion, my dear young lady, a New-York packet is as worthy of wearing a pennant as any vessel that floats.
10149{_}3528{_}I mean, of course, ships of the regular European lines, and not the Southern traders."
10149{_}3529{_}"But these are merely spots on the sun, my good sir," returned Mr. Howel; "putting a few such trifles out of the question, I think you will allow that England is the most delightful country in the world?"
10149{_}3530{_}"To be frank with you, Mr. Howel, there is a good deal of hang-dog weather, along in October, November and December.
10149{_}3531{_}I have known March any thing but agreeable, and then April is just like a young girl with one of your melancholy novels, now smiling, and now blubbering."
10149{_}3532{_}"But the morals of the country, my dear sir; the moral features of England must be a source of never-dying delight to a true philanthropist," resumed Mr. Howel, as Eve, who perceived that the discourse was likely to be long, went to join the ladies.
10149{_}3533{_}"An Englishman has most reason to be proud of the moral excellencies of his country!"
10149{_}3534{_}"Why, to be frank with you, Mr. Howel, there are some of the moral features of London, that are any thing but very beautiful.
10149{_}3535{_}If you could pass twenty-four hours in the neighbourhood of St. Catharine's, would see sights that would throw Templeton into fits.
10149{_}3536{_}The English are a handsome people, I allow; but their morality is none of the best-featured."
10149{_}3537{_}"Let us be seated, sir; I am afraid we are not exactly agreed on our terms, and, in order that we may continue this subject, I beg you will let me take a seat next you, at table."
10149{_}3538{_}To this Captain Truck very cheerfully assented, and then the two took chairs, continuing the discourse very much in the blind and ambiguous manner in which it had been commenced; the one party insisting on seeing every thing through the medium of an imagination that had got to be diseased on such subjects, or with a species of monomania; while the other seemed obstinately determined to consider the entire country as things had been presented to his limited and peculiar experience, in the vicinity of the docks.
10149{_}3539{_}"We have had a very unexpected, and a very agreeable attendant in Captain Truck," said Mrs Hawker, when Eve had placed herself by her side, and respectfully taken one of her hands.
10149{_}3540{_}"I really think if I were to suffer shipwreck, or to run the hazard of captivity, I should choose to have both occur in his good company."
10149{_}3541{_}"Mrs. Hawker makes so many conquests," observed Mrs. Bloomfield, "that we are to think nothing of her success with this mer-man; but what will you say, Miss Effingham, when you learn that I am also in favour, in the same high quarter.
10149{_}3542{_}I shall think the better of masters, and boatswains, and Trinculos and Stephanos, as long as I live, for this specimen of their craft."
10149{_}3543{_}"Not Trinculos and Stephanos, dear Mrs. Bloom field; for, _a l' exception pres de_ Saturday-nights, and sweethearts and wives, a more exemplary person in the way of libations does not exist than our excellent Captain Truck.
10149{_}3544{_}He is much too religious and moral for so vulgar an excess as drinking."
10149{_}3545{_}"Religious!"
10149{_}3546{_}exclaimed Mrs, Bloomfield, in sur prise.
10149{_}3547{_}"This is a merit to which I did not know he possessed the smallest claims.
10149{_}3548{_}One might imagine a little superstition, and some short-lived repentances in gales of wind; but scarcely any thing as much like a trade wind, as religion!"
10149{_}3549{_}"Then you do not know him; for a more sincerely devout man, though I acknowledge it is after a fashion that is perhaps peculiar to the ocean, is not often met with.
10149{_}3550{_}At any rate, you found him attentive to our sex?"
10149{_}3551{_}"The pink of politeness, and, not to embellish, there is a manly deference about him, that is singularly agreeable to our frail vanity.
10149{_}3552{_}This comes of his packet-training, I suppose, and we may thank you for some portion of his merit, His tongue never tires in your praises, and did I not feel persuaded that your mind is made up never to be the wife of any republican American, I should fear this visit exceedingly.
10149{_}3553{_}Notwithstanding the remark I made concerning my being in favour, the affair lies between Mrs. Hawker and yourself.
10149{_}3554{_}I know it is not your habit to trifle even on that very popular subject with young ladies, matrimony; but this case forms so complete an exception to the vulgar passion, that I trust you will overlook the indiscretion.
10149{_}3555{_}Our _golden_ captain, for _copper_ he is not, protests that Mrs. Hawker is the most delightful old lady he ever knew, and that Miss Eve Effingham is the most delightful young lady he ever knew.
10149{_}3556{_}Here, then, each may see the ground she occupies, and play her cards accordingly.
10149{_}3557{_}I hope to be forgiven for touching on a subject so delicate."
10149{_}3558{_}"In the first place," said Eve, smiling, "I should wish to hear Mrs. Hawker's reply."
10149{_}3559{_}"I have no more to say, than to express my perfect gratitude," answered that lady, "to announce a determination not to change my condition, on account of extreme youth, and a disposition to abandon the field to my younger, if not fairer, rival."
10149{_}3560{_}"Well, then," resumed Eve, anxious to change the subject, for she saw that Paul was approaching their group, "I believe it will be wisest in me to suspend a decision, circumstances leaving so much at my disposal.
10149{_}3561{_}Time must show what that decision will be."
10149{_}3562{_}"Nay," said Mrs. Bloomfield, who saw no feeling involved in the trifling, "this is unjustifiable coquetry, and I feel bound to ascertain how the land lies.
10149{_}3563{_}You will remember I am the Captain's confidant, and you know the fearful responsibility of a friend in an affair of this sort; that of a friend in the duello being insignificant in comparison.
10149{_}3564{_}That I may have testimony at need, Mr. Powis shall be made acquainted with the leading facts.
10149{_}3565{_}Captain Truck is a devout admirer of this young lady, sir, and I am endeavouring to discover whether he ought to hang himself on her father's lawn, this evening, as soon as the moon rises, or live another week.
10149{_}3566{_}In order to do this, I shall pursue the categorical and inquisitorial method--and so defend yourself Miss Effingham.
10149{_}3567{_}Do you object to the country of your admirer?"
10149{_}3568{_}Eve, though inwardly vexed at the turn this pleasantry had taken, maintained a perfectly composed manner, for she knew that Mrs. Bloomfield had too much feminine propriety to say any thing improper, or any thing that might seriously embarrass her.
10149{_}3569{_}"It would, indeed, be extraordinary, should I object to a country which is not only my own, but which has so long been that of my ancestors," she answered steadily.
10149{_}3570{_}"On this score, my knight has nothing to fear."
10149{_}3571{_}"I rejoice to hear this," returned Mrs. Bloomfield, glancing her eyes, unconsciously to herself, however, towards Sir George Templemore, "and, Mr. Powis, you, who I believe are a European, will learn humility in the avowal.
10149{_}3572{_}Do you object to your swain that he is a seaman?"
10149{_}3573{_}Eve blushed, notwithstanding a strong effort to appear composed, and, for the first time since their acquaintance, she felt provoked with Mrs. Bloomfield.
