10149{_}5081{_}"What is the point in immediate controversy, gentlemen?"
10149{_}5082{_}asked Mrs. Bloomfield, taking a seat.
10149{_}5083{_}"Why here is a review of a late American work, ma'am, and I insist that the author is skinned alive, whereas, Mr. John insists that the reviewer exposes only his own rage, the work having a national character, and running counter to the reviewer's feelings and interests."
10149{_}5084{_}"Nay, I protest against this statement of the case, for I affirm that the reviewer exposes a great deal more than his rage, since his imbecility, ignorance, and dishonesty, are quite as apparent as any thing else."
10149{_}5085{_}"I have read the article," said Mrs. Bloomfield, after glancing her eye at the periodical, "and I must say that I take sides with Mr. John Effingham in his opinion of its character."
10149{_}5086{_}"But do you not perceive, ma'am, that this is the idol of the nobility and gentry; the work that is more in favour with people of consequence in England than any other.
10149{_}5087{_}Bishops are said to write for it!"
10149{_}5088{_}"I know it is a work expressly established to sustain one of the most factitious political systems that ever existed, and that it sacrifices every high quality to attain its end."
10149{_}5089{_}"Mrs. Bloomfield, you amaze me!
10149{_}5090{_}The first writers of Great Britain figure in its pages."
10149{_}5091{_}"That I much question, in the first place; but even if it were so, it would be but a shallow mystification.
10149{_}5092{_}Although a man of character might write one article in a work of this nature, it does not follow that a man of no character does not write the next.
10149{_}5093{_}The principles of the communications of a periodical are as different as their talents."
10149{_}5094{_}"But the editor is a pledge for all.--The editor of this review is an eminent writer himself."
10149{_}5095{_}"An eminent writer may be a very great knave, in the first place, and one fact is worth a thousand conjectures in such a matter.
10149{_}5096{_}But we do not know that there is any responsible editor to works of this nature at all, for there is no name given in the title-page, and nothing is more common than vague declarations of a want of this very responsibility.
10149{_}5097{_}But if I can prove to you that this article _cannot_ have been written by a man of common honesty, Mr. Howel, what will you then say to the responsibility of your editor?"
10149{_}5098{_}"In that case I shall be compelled to admit that he had no connexion with it."
10149{_}5099{_}"Any thing in preference to giving up the beloved idol!"
10149{_}5100{_}said John Effingham laughing.
10149{_}5101{_}"Why not add at once, that he is as great a knave as the writer himself?
10149{_}5102{_}I am glad, however, that Tom Howel has fallen into such good hands, Mrs. Bloomfield, and I devoutly pray you may not spare him."
10149{_}5103{_}We have said that Mrs. Bloomfield had a rapid perception of things and principles, that amounted almost to intuition.
10149{_}5104{_}She had read the article in question, and, as she glanced her eyes through its pages, had detected its fallacies and falsehoods, in almost every sentence.
10149{_}5105{_}Indeed, they had not been put together with ordinary skill, the writer having evidently presumed on the easiness of the class of readers who generally swallowed his round assertions, and were so clumsily done that any one who had not the faith to move mountains would have seen through most of them without difficulty.
10149{_}5106{_}But Mr. Howel belonged to another school, and he was so much accustomed to shut his eyes to palpable mystification mentioned by Mrs. Bloomfield, that a lie, which, advanced in most works, would have carried no weight with it, advanced in this particular periodical became elevated to the dignity of truth.
10149{_}5107{_}Mrs. Bloomfield turned to an article on America, in the periodical in question, and read from it several disparaging expressions concerning Mr. Howel's native country, one of which was, "The American's first plaything is the rattle-snake's tail."
10149{_}5108{_}"Now, what do you think of this assertion in particular, Mr.
10149{_}5109{_}Howel?"
10149{_}5110{_}she asked, reading the words we have just quoted.
10149{_}5111{_}"Oh!
10149{_}5112{_}that is said in mere pleasantry--it is only wit."
10149{_}5113{_}"Well, then, what do you think of it as wit?"
10149{_}5114{_}"Well, well, it may not be of a very pure water, but the best of men are unequal at all times, and more especially in their wit."
10149{_}5115{_}"Here," continued Mrs. Bloomfield, pointing to another paragraph, "is a positive statement or misstatement, which makes the cost of the 'civil department of the United States Government,' about six times more than it really is."
10149{_}5116{_}"Our government is so extremely mean, that I ascribe that error to generosity."
10149{_}5117{_}"Well," continued the lady, smiling, "here the reviewer asserts that Congress passed a law _limiting_ the size of certain ships, in order to please the democracy; and that the Executive privately evaded this law, and built vessels of a much greater size; whereas the provision of the law is just the contrary, or that the ships should not be _less_ than of seventy-four guns; a piece of information, by the way, that I obtained from Mr.
10149{_}5118{_}Powis."
10149{_}5119{_}"Ignorance, ma'am; a stranger cannot be supposed to know all the laws of a foreign country."
10149{_}5120{_}"Then why make bold and false assertions about them, that are intended to discredit the country?
10149{_}5121{_}Here is another assertion--'ten thousand of the men that fought at Waterloo would have marched through North America?'
10149{_}5122{_}Do you believe that, Mr.
10149{_}5123{_}Howel?"
10149{_}5124{_}"But that is merely an opinion, Mrs. Bloomfield; any man may be wrong in his opinion."
10149{_}5125{_}"Very true, but it is an opinion uttered in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and twenty-eight; and after the battles of Bunker Hill, Cowpens, Plattsburg, Saratoga, and New-Orleans!
10149{_}5126{_}And, moreover, after it had been proved that something very like ten thousand of the identical men who fought at Waterloo, could not march even ten miles into the country."
10149{_}5127{_}"Well, well, all this shows that the reviewer is sometimes mistaken."
10149{_}5128{_}"Your pardon Mr. Howel; I think it shows, according to your own admission, that his wit, or rather its wit, for there is no _his_ about it--that its wit is of a very indifferent quality as witticisms even; that it is ignorant of what it pretends to know; and that its opinions are no better than its knowledge: all of which, when fairly established against one who, by his very pursuit, professes to know more than other people, is very much like making it appear contemptible."
10149{_}5129{_}"This is going back eight or ten years--let us look more particularly at the article about which the discussion commences."
10149{_}5130{_}"_Volontiers_"  Mrs. Bloomfield now sent to the library for the work reviewed, and opening the review she read some of its strictures; and then turning to the corresponding passages in the work itself, she pointed out the unfairness of the quotations, the omissions of the context, and, in several flagrant instances, witticisms of the reviewer, that were purchased at the expense of the English language.
10149{_}5131{_}She next showed several of those audacious assertions, for which the particular periodical was so remarkable, leaving no doubt with any candid person, that they were purchased at the expense of truth.
10149{_}5132{_}"But here is an instance that will scarce admit of cavilling or objection on your part, Mr. Howel," she continued; "do me the favour to read the passage in the review."
10149{_}5133{_}Mr. Howel complied, and when he had done, he looked expectingly at the lady.
10149{_}5134{_}"The effect of the reviewer's statement is to make it appear that the author has contradicted himself, is it not?"
10149{_}5135{_}"Certainly, nothing can be plainer."
10149{_}5136{_}"According to your favourite reviewer, who accuses him of it, in terms.
10149{_}5137{_}Now let us look at the fact.
10149{_}5138{_}Here is the passage in the work itself.
10149{_}5139{_}In the first place you will remark that this sentence, which contains the alleged contradiction, is mutilated; the part which is omitted, giving a directly contrary meaning to it, from that it bears under the reviewer's scissors."
10149{_}5140{_}"It has some such appearance, I do confess."
10149{_}5141{_}"Here you perceive that the closing sentence of the same paragraph, and which refers directly to the point at issue, is displaced, made to appear as belonging to a separate paragraph, and as conveying a different meaning from what the author has actually expressed."
10149{_}5142{_}"Upon my word, I do not know but you are right!"
10149{_}5143{_}"Well, Mr. Howel, we have had wit of no very pure water, ignorance as relates to facts, and mistakes as regards very positive assertions.
10149{_}5144{_}In what category, as Captain Truck would say, do you place this?"
10149{_}5145{_}"Why does not the author reviewed expose this?"
10149{_}5146{_}"Why does not a gentleman wrangle with a detected pick-pocket?"
10149{_}5147{_}"It is literary swindling," said John Effingham, "and the man who did it, is inherently a knave."
10149{_}5148{_}"I think both these facts quite beyond dispute," observed Mrs. Bloomfield, laying down Mr. Howel's favourite review with an air of cool contempt; "and I must say I did not think it necessary to prove the general character of the work, at this late date, to any American of ordinary intelligence; much less to a sensible man, like Mr.
10149{_}5149{_}Howel."
10149{_}5150{_}"But, ma'am, there may be much truth and justice in the rest of its remarks," returned the pertinacious Mr. Howel, "although it has fallen into these mistakes."
10149{_}5151{_}"Were you ever on a jury, Howel?"
10149{_}5152{_}asked John Effingham, in his caustic manner.
10149{_}5153{_}"Often; and on grand juries, too."
10149{_}5154{_}"Well, did the judge never tell you, when a witness is detected in lying on one point, that his testimony is valueless on all others?"
10149{_}5155{_}"Very true; but this is a review, and not testimony."
10149{_}5156{_}"The distinction is certainly a very good one," resumed Mrs. Bloomfield, laughing, "as nothing, in general, can be less like honest testimony than a review!"
10149{_}5157{_}"But I think, my dear ma'am, you will allow that all this is excessively biting and severe--I can't say I ever read any thing sharper in my life."
10149{_}5158{_}"It strikes me, Mr. Howel, as being nothing but epithets, the cheapest and most contemptible of all species of abuse.
10149{_}5159{_}Were two men, in your presence, to call each other such names, I think it would excite nothing but disgust in your mind.
10149{_}5160{_}When the thought is clear and poignant, there is little need to have recourse to mere epithets; indeed, men never use the latter, except when there is a deficiency of the first."
10149{_}5161{_}"Well, well, my friends," cried Mr. Howel, as he walked away towards Grace and Sir George, "this is a different thing from what I at first thought it, but still I think you undervalue the periodical."
10149{_}5162{_}"I hope this little lesson will cool some of Mr. Howel's faith in foreign morality," observed Mrs. Bloomfield, as soon as the gentleman named was out of hearing; "a more credulous and devout worshipper of the idol, I have never before met."
10149{_}5163{_}"The school is diminishing, but it is still large.
10149{_}5164{_}Men like Tom Howel, who have thought in one direction all their lives, are not easily brought to change their notions, especially when the admiration which proceeds from distance, distance 'that lends enchantment to the view,' is at the bottom of their faith.
10149{_}5165{_}Had this very article been written and printed round the corner of the street in which he lives, Howel would be the first to say that it was the production of a fellow without talents or principles, and was unworthy of a second thought."
10149{_}5166{_}"I still think he will be a wiser, if not a better man, by the exposure of its frauds."
10149{_}5167{_}"Not he.
10149{_}5168{_}If you will excuse a homely and a coarse simile, 'he will return like a dog to his vomit, or the sow to its wallowing in the mire.'
10149{_}5169{_}I never knew one of that school thoroughly cured, until he became himself the subject of attack, or, by a close personal communication, was made to feel the superciliousness of European superiority.
10149{_}5170{_}It is only a week since I had a discussion with him on the subject of the humanity and the relish for liberty in his beloved model; and when I cited the instance of the employment of the tomahawk, in the wars between England and this country, he actually affirmed that the Indian savages killed no women and children, but the wives and offspring of their enemies; and when I told him that the English, like most other people, cared very little for any liberty but their own, he coolly affirmed that their own was the only liberty worth caring for!"
10149{_}5171{_}"Oh yes," put in young Mr. Wenham, who had overheard the latter portion of the conversation, "Mr. Howel is so thoroughly English, that he actually denies that America is the most civilized country in the world, or that we speak our language better than any nation was ever before known to speak its own language."
10149{_}5172{_}"This is so manifest an act of treason," said Mrs. Bloomfield, endeavouring to look grave, for Mr. Wenham was any thing but accurate in the use of words himself, commonly pronouncing "been," "ben," "does," "dooze," "nothing," "nawthing," "few," "foo," &c. &c. &c., "that, certainly, Mr. Howel should be arraigned at the bar of public opinion for the outrage."
10149{_}5173{_}"It is commonly admitted, even by our enemies, that our mode of speaking is the very best in the world, which, I suppose, is the real reason why our literature has so rapidly reached the top of the ladder."
10149{_}5174{_}"And is that the fact?"
10149{_}5175{_}asked Mrs. Bloomfield, with a curiosity that was not in the least feigned.
10149{_}5176{_}"I believe no one denies _that.
10149{_}5177{_}You_ will sustain me in this, I fancy, Mr.
10149{_}5178{_}Dodge?"
10149{_}5179{_}The editor of the Active Inquirer had approached, and was just in time to catch the subject in discussion.
10149{_}5180{_}Now the modes of speech of these two persons, while they had a great deal in common, had also a great deal that was not in common.
10149{_}5181{_}Mr. Wenham was a native of New- York, and his dialect was a mixture that is getting to be sufficiently general, partaking equally of the Doric of New England, the Dutch cross, and the old English root; whereas, Mr.
10149{_}5182{_}Dodge spoke the pure, unalloyed Tuscan of his province, rigidly adhering to all its sounds and significations.
10149{_}5183{_}"Dissipation," he contended, meant "drunkenness;" "ugly," "vicious;" "clever," "good-natured;" and "humbly," (homely) "ugly."
10149{_}5184{_}In addition to this finesse in significations, he had a variety of pronunciations that often put strangers at fault, and to which he adhered with a pertinacity that obtained some of its force from the fact, that it exceeded his power to get rid of them.
10149{_}5185{_}Notwithstanding all these little peculiarities, peculiarities as respects every one but those who dwelt in his own province, Mr.
10149{_}5186{_}Dodge had also taken up the notion of his superiority on the subject of language, and always treated the matter as one that was placed quite beyond dispute, by its publicity and truth.
10149{_}5187{_}"The progress of American Literature," returned the editor, "is really astonishing the four quarters of the world.
10149{_}5188{_}I believe it is very generally admitted, now, that our pulpit and bar are at the very summit of these two professions.
10149{_}5189{_}Then we have much the best poets of the age, while eleven of our novelists surpass any of all other countries.
10149{_}5190{_}The American Philosophical Society is, I believe, generally considered the most acute learned body now extant, unless, indeed, the New-York Historical Society may compete with it, for that honour.
10149{_}5191{_}Some persons give the palm to one, and some to the other; though I myself think it would be difficult to decide between them.
10149{_}5192{_}Then to what a pass has the drama risen of late years!
10149{_}5193{_}Genius is getting to be quite a drug in America!"
10149{_}5194{_}"You have forgotten to speak of the press, in particular," put in the complacent Mr. Wenham.
10149{_}5195{_}"I think we may more safely pride ourselves on the high character of the press, than any thing else."
10149{_}5196{_}"Why, to tell you the truth, sir," answered Steadfast, taking the other by the arm, and leading him so slowly away, that a part of what followed was heard by the two amused listeners, "modesty is so infallibly the companion of merit, that _we_ who are engaged in that high pursuit do not like to say any thing in our own favour.
10149{_}5197{_}You never detect a newspaper in the weakness of extolling itself; but, between ourselves, I may say, after a close examination of the condition of the press in other countries, I have come to the conclusion, that, for talents, taste, candour, philosophy, genius, honesty, and truth, the press of the United States stands at the very----"  Here Mr.
10149{_}5198{_}Dodge passed so far from the listeners, that the rest of the speech became inaudible, though from the well-established modesty of the man and the editor, there can be little doubt of the manner in which he concluded the sentence.
10149{_}5199{_}"It is said in Europe," observed Johr Effingham, his fine face expressing the cool sarcasm in which he was so apt to indulge, "that there are _la vieille_ and _la Jeune France_.
10149{_}5200{_}I think we have now had pretty fair specimens of _old_ and _young_ America; the first distrusting every thing native, even to a potatoe: and the second distrusting nothing, and least of all, itself."
10149{_}5201{_}"There appears to be a sort of pendulum-uneasiness in mankind," said Mrs. Bloomfield, "that keeps opinion always vibrating around the centre of truth, for I think it the rarest thing in the world to find man or woman who has not a disposition, as soon as an error is abandoned, to fly off into its opposite extreme.
10149{_}5202{_}From believing we had nothing worthy of a thought, there is a set springing up who appear to have jumped to the conclusion that we have every thing."
10149{_}5203{_}"Ay, this is _one_ of the reasons that all the rest of the world laugh at us."
10149{_}5204{_}"Laugh at us, Mr. Effingham!
10149{_}5205{_}Even _I_ had supposed the American name had, at last, got to be in good credit in other parts of the world."
10149{_}5206{_}"Then even _you_, my dear Mrs. Bloomfield, are notably mistaken.
10149{_}5207{_}Europe, it is true, is beginning to give us credit for not being quite as bad as she once thought us; but we are far, very far, from being yet admitted to the ordinary level of nations, as respects goodness."
10149{_}5208{_}"Surely they give us credit for energy, enterprize, activity----"  "Qualities that they prettily term, rapacity, cunning, and swindling!
10149{_}5209{_}I am far, very far, however, from giving credit to all that it suits the interests and prejudices of Europe, especially of our venerable kinswoman, Old England, to circulate and think to the prejudice of this country, which, in my poor judgment, has as much substantial merit to boast of as any nation on earth; though, in getting rid of a set of ancient vices and follies, it has not had the sagacity to discover that it is fast falling into pretty tolerable--or if you like it better--intolerable substitutes."
10149{_}5210{_}"What then do _you_ deem our greatest error--our weakest point?"
10149{_}5211{_}"Provincialisms, with their train of narrow prejudices, and a disposition to set up mediocrity as perfection, under the double influence of an ignorance that unavoidably arises from a want of models, and of the irresistible tendency to mediocrity, in a nation where the common mind so imperiously rules."
10149{_}5212{_}"But does not the common mind rule every where?
10149{_}5213{_}Is not public opinion always stronger than law?"
10149{_}5214{_}"In a certain sense, both these positions may be true.
10149{_}5215{_}But in a nation like this, without a capital, one _that is all provinces_, in which intelligence and tastes are scattered, this common mind wants the usual direction, and derives its impulses from the force of numbers, rather than from the force of knowledge.
10149{_}5216{_}Hence the fact, that the public opinion never or seldom rises to absolute truth.
10149{_}5217{_}I grant you that _as_ a mediocrity, it is well; much better than common even; but it is still a mediocrity."
10149{_}5218{_}"I see the justice of your remark, and I suppose we are to ascribe the general use of superlatives, which is so very obvious, to these causes."
10149{_}5219{_}"Unquestionably; men have gotten to be afraid to speak the truth, when that truth is a little beyond the common comprehension; and thus it is that you see the fulsome flattery that all the public servants, as they call themselves, resort to, in order to increase their popularity, instead of telling the wholesome facts that are needed."
10149{_}5220{_}"And what is to be the result?"
10149{_}5221{_}"Heaven knows.
10149{_}5222{_}While America is so much in advance of other nations, in a freedom from prejudices of the old school, it is fast substituting a set of prejudices of its own, that are not without serious dangers.
10149{_}5223{_}We may live through it, and the ills of society may correct themselves, though there is one fact that men aces more evil than any thing I could have feared."
10149{_}5224{_}"You mean the political struggle between money and numbers, that has so seriously manifested itself of late!"
10149{_}5225{_}exclaimed the quick-minded and intelligent Mrs. Bloomfield.
10149{_}5226{_}"_That_ has its dangers; but there is still another evil of greater magnitude.
10149{_}5227{_}I allude to the very general disposition to confine political discussions to political men.
10149{_}5228{_}Thus, the private citizen, who should presume to discuss a political question, would be deemed fair game for all who thought differently from himself.
10149{_}5229{_}He would be injured in his pocket, reputation, domestic happiness, if possible; for, in this respect, America is much the most intolerant nation I have ever visited.
10149{_}5230{_}In all other countries, in which discussion is permitted at all, there is at least the _appearance_ of fair play, whatever may be done covertly; but here, it seems to be sufficient to justify falsehood, frauds, nay, barefaced rascality, to establish that the injured party has had the audacity to meddle with public questions, not being what the public chooses to call a public man.
10149{_}5231{_}It is scarcely necessary to say that, when such an opinion gets to be effective, it must entirely defeat the real intentions of a popular government."
10149{_}5232{_}"Now you mention it," said Mrs. Bloomfield, "I think I have witnessed instances of what you mean."
10149{_}5233{_}"Witnessed, dear Mrs. Bloomfield!
10149{_}5234{_}Instances are to be seen as often as a man is found freeman enough to have an opinion independent of party.
10149{_}5235{_}It is not for connecting himself with party that a man is denounced in this country, but for daring to connect himself with truth.
10149{_}5236{_}Party will bear with party, but party will not bear with truth.
10149{_}5237{_}It is in politics as in war, regiments or individuals may desert, and they will be received by their late enemies with open arms, the honour of a soldier seldom reaching to the pass of refusing succour of any sort; but both sides will turn and fire on the countrymen who wish merely to defend their homes and firesides."
10149{_}5238{_}"You draw disagreeable pictures of human nature, Mr.
10149{_}5239{_}Effingham."
10149{_}5240{_}"Merely because they are true, Mrs. Bloomfield.
10149{_}5241{_}Man is worse than the beasts, merely because he has a code of right and wrong, which he never respects.
10149{_}5242{_}They talk of the variation of the compass, and even pretend to calculate its changes, though no one can explain the principle that causes the attraction or its vagaries at all.
10149{_}5243{_}So it is with men; they pretend to look always at the right, though their eyes are constantly directed obliquely; and it is a certain calculation to allow of a pretty wide variation--but here comes Miss Effingham, singularly well attired, and more beautiful than I have ever before seen her!"
10149{_}5244{_}The two exchanged quick glances, and then, as if fearful of betraying to each other their thoughts, they moved towards our heroine, to do the honours of the reception.
10149{_}5245{_}Chapter XXVI.
10149{_}5246{_}"Haply, when I shall wed, That lord, whose hand must take   my plight, shall carry Half my love with him, half my care and   duty."
10149{_}5247{_}CORDELIA.
10149{_}5248{_}As no man could be more gracefully or delicately polite than John Effingham, when the humour seized him, Mrs. Bloomfield was struck with the kind and gentleman-like manner with which he met his young kinswoman on this trying occasion, and the affectionate tones of his voice, and the winning expression of his eye, as he addressed her.
10149{_}5249{_}Eve herself was not unobservant of these peculiarities, nor was she slow in comprehending the reason.
10149{_}5250{_}She perceived at once that he was acquainted with the state of things between her and Paul.
10149{_}5251{_}As she well knew the womanly fidelity of Mrs. Bloomfield, she rightly enough conjectured that the long observation of her cousin, coupled with the few words accidentally overheard that evening had even made him better acquainted with the true condition of her feelings, than was the case with the friend with whom she had so lately been conversing on the subject.
10149{_}5252{_}Still Eve was not embarrassed by the conviction that her secret was betrayed to so many persons.
10149{_}5253{_}Her attachment to Paul was not the impulse of girlish caprice, but the warm affection of a woman, that had grown with time, was sanctioned by her reason, and which, if it was tinctured with the more glowing imagination and ample faith of youth, was also sustained by her principles and her sense of right.
10149{_}5254{_}She knew that both her father and cousin esteemed the man of her own choice, nor did she believe the little cloud that, hung over his birth could do more than have a temporary influence on his own sensitive feelings.
10149{_}5255{_}She met John Effingham, therefore, with a frank composure, returned the kind pressure of his hand, with a smile such as a daughter might bestow on an affectionate parent, and turned to salute the remainder of the party, with that lady-like ease which had got to be a part of her nature.
10149{_}5256{_}"There goes one of the most attractive pictures that humanity can offer," said John Effingham to Mrs. Bloomfield, as Eve walked away; "a young, timid, modest, sensitive girl, so strong in her principles, so conscious of rectitude, so pure of thought, and so warm in her affections, that she views her selection of a husband, as others view their acts of duty and religious faith.
10149{_}5257{_}With her love has no shame, as it has no weakness."
10149{_}5258{_}"Eve Effingham is as faultless as comports with womanhood; and yet I confess ignorance of my own sex, if she receive Mr. Powis as calmly as she received her cousin."
10149{_}5259{_}"Perhaps not, for in that case, she could scarcely feel the passion.
10149{_}5260{_}You perceive that he avoids oppressing her with his notice, and that the meeting passes off without embarrassment.
10149{_}5261{_}I do believe there is an elevating principle in love, that, by causing us to wish to be worthy of the object most prized, produces the desired effects by stimulating exertion.
10149{_}5262{_}There, now, are two as perfect beings as one ordinarily meets with, each oppressed by a sense of his or her unworthiness to be the choice of the other."
10149{_}5263{_}"Does love, then, teach humility; successful love too?"
10149{_}5264{_}"Does it not?
10149{_}5265{_}It would be hardly fair to press this matter on you, a married woman; for, by the pandects of American society, a man may philosophize on love, prattle about it, trifle on the subject, and even analyze the passion with, a miss in her teens, and yet he shall not allude to it, in a discourse with a matron.
10149{_}5266{_}Well, _chacun a son gout_; we are, indeed, a little peculiar in our usages, and have promoted a good deal of village coquetry, and the flirtations of the may-pole, to the drawing-room."
10149{_}5267{_}"Is it not better that such follies should be confined to youth, than that they should invade the sanctity of married life, as I understand is too much the case elsewhere?"
10149{_}5268{_}"Perhaps so; though I confess it is easier to dispose of a straight- forward proposition from a mother, a father, or a commissioned friend, than to get rid of a young lady, who, _propria persona_, angles on her own account.
10149{_}5269{_}While abroad, I had a dozen proposals--"  "Proposals!"
10149{_}5270{_}exclaimed Mrs. Bloomfield, holding up both hands, and shaking her head incredulously.
10149{_}5271{_}"Proposals!
10149{_}5272{_}Why not, ma'am?--am I more than fifty?
10149{_}5273{_}am I not reasonably youthful for that period of life, and have I not six or eight thousand a year--"  "Eighteen, or you are much scandalized."
10149{_}5274{_}"Well, eighteen, if you will," coolly returned the other, in whose eyes money was no merit, for he was born to a fortune, and always treated it as a means, and not as the end of life; "every dollar is a magnet, after one has turned forty.
10149{_}5275{_}Do you suppose that a single man, of tolerable person, well-born, and with a hundred thousand francs of _rentes_, could entirely escape proposals from the ladies in Europe?"
10149{_}5276{_}"This is so revolting to all our American notions, that, though I have often heard of such things, I have always found it difficult to believe them!"
10149{_}5277{_}"And is it more revolting for the friends of young ladies to look out for them, on such occasions, than that the young ladies should take the affair into their own hands, as is practised quite as openly, here?"
10149{_}5278{_}"It is well you are a confirmed bachelor, or declarations like these would mar your fortunes.
10149{_}5279{_}I will admit that the school is not as retiring and diffident as formerly; for we are all ready enough to say that no times are egual to our own times; but I shall strenuously protest against your interpretation of the nature and artlessness of an American girl."
10149{_}5280{_}"Artlessness!"
10149{_}5281{_}repeated John Effingham, with a slight lifting of the eye-brows; "we live in an age when new dictionaries and vocabularies are necessary to understand each other's meaning.
10149{_}5282{_}It is artlessness, with a vengeance, to beset an old fellow of fifty, as one would besiege a town.
10149{_}5283{_}Hist!--Ned is retiring with his daughter, my dear Mrs. Bloomfield, and it will not be long before I shall be summoned to a family council.
10149{_}5284{_}Well, we will keep the secret until it is publicly proclaimed."
10149{_}5285{_}John Effingham was right, for his two cousins left the room together, and retired to the library, but in a way to attract no particular attention, except in those who were enlightened on the subject of what had already passed that evening.
10149{_}5286{_}When they were alone, Mr. Effingham turned the key, and then he gave a free vent to his paternal feelings.
10149{_}5287{_}Between Eve and her parent, there had always existed a confidence exceeding that which it is common to find between father and daughter.
10149{_}5288{_}In one sense, they had been all in all to each other, and Eve had never hesitated about pouring those feelings into his breast, which, had she possessed another parent, would more naturally have been confided to the affection of a mother.
10149{_}5289{_}When their eyes first met, therefore, they were mutually beaming with an expression of confidence and love, such as might, in a measure, have been expected between two of the gentler sex.
10149{_}5290{_}Mr Effingham folded his child to his heart, pressed her there tenderly for near a minute in silence, and then kissing her burning cheek he permitted her to look up.
10149{_}5291{_}"This answers all my fondest hopes, Eve"--he exclaimed; "fulfils my most cherished wishes for thy sake."
10149{_}5292{_}"Dearest sir!"
10149{_}5293{_}"Yes, my love, I have long secretly prayed that such might be your good fortune; for, of all the youths we have met, at home or abroad, Paul Powis is the one to whom I can consign you with the most confidence that he will cherish and love you as you deserve to be cherished and loved!"
10149{_}5294{_}"Dearest father, nothing but this was wanting to complete my perfect happiness."
10149{_}5295{_}Mr. Effingham kissed his daughter again, and he was then enabled to pursue the conversation with greater composure.
10149{_}5296{_}"Powis and I have had a full explanation," he said, "though in order to obtain it, I have been obliged to give him strong encouragement"  "Father!"
10149{_}5297{_}"Nay, my love, your delicacy and feelings nave been sufficiently respected, but he has so much diffidence of himself, and permits the unpleasant circumstances connected with his birth to weigh so much on his mind, that I have been compelled to tell him, what I am sure you will approve, that we disregard family connections, and look only to the merit of the individual."
10149{_}5298{_}"I hope, father, nothing was said to give Mr. Powis reason to suppose we did not deem him every way our equal."
10149{_}5299{_}"Certainly not.
10149{_}5300{_}He is a gentleman, and I can claim to be no more.
10149{_}5301{_}There is but one thing in which connections ought to influence an American marriage, where the parties are suited to each other in the main requisites, and that is to ascertain that neither should be carried, necessarily, into associations for which their habits have given them too much and too good tastes to enter into.
10149{_}5302{_}A _woman_, especially, ought never to be transplanted from a polished to an unpolished circle; for, when this is the case, if really a lady, there will be a dangerous clog on her affection for her husband.
10149{_}5303{_}This one great point assured, I see no other about which a parent need feel concern."
10149{_}5304{_}"Powis, unhappily, has no connections in this country; or none with whom he has any communications; and those he has in England are of a class to do him credit."
10149{_}5305{_}"We have been conversing of this, and he has manifested so much proper feeling that it has even raised him in my esteem.
10149{_}5306{_}I knew his father's family, and must have known his father, I think, though there were two or three Asshetons of the name of John.
10149{_}5307{_}It is a highly respectable family of the middle states, and belonged formerly to the colonial aristocracy.
10149{_}5308{_}Jack Effingham's mother was an Assheton."
10149{_}5309{_}"Of the same blood, do you think, sir?
10149{_}5310{_}I remembered this when Mr. Powis mentioned his father's name, and intended to question cousin Jack on the subject."
10149{_}5311{_}"Now you speak of it, Eve, there _must_ be a relationship between them.
10149{_}5312{_}Do you suppose that our kinsman is acquainted with the fact that Paul is, in truth, an Assheton?"
10149{_}5313{_}Eve told her father that she had never spoken with their relative on the subject, at all.
10149{_}5314{_}Then ring the bell and we will ascertain at once how far my conjecture is true.
10149{_}5315{_}You can have no false delicacy, my child, about letting your engagement be known to one as near and as dear to us, as John."
10149{_}5316{_}"Engagement, father!"
10149{_}5317{_}"Yes, engagement," returned the smiling parent, "for such I already deem it.
10149{_}5318{_}I have ventured, in your behalf, to plight your troth to Paul Powis, or what is almost equal to it; and in return I can give you back as many protestations of unequalled fidelity, and eternal constancy, as any reasonable girl can ask."
10149{_}5319{_}Eve gazed at her lather in a way to show that reproach was mingled with fondness, for she felt that, in this instance, too much of the precipitation of the other sex had been manifested in her affairs; still, superior to coquetry and affectation, and much too warm in her attachments to be seriously hurt, she kissed the hand she held, shook her head reproachfully, even while she smiled, and did as had been desired.
10149{_}5320{_}"You have, indeed, rendered it important to us to know more of Mr. Powis, my beloved father," she said, as she returned to her seat, "though I could wish matters had not proceeded quite so fast."
10149{_}5321{_}"Nay, all I promised was conditional, and dependent on yourself.
10149{_}5322{_}You have nothing to do, if I have said too much, but to refuse to ratify the treaty made by your negotiator."
10149{_}5323{_}"You propose an impossibility,", said Eve, taking the hand, again, that she had so lately relinquished, and pressing it warmly between her own; "the negotiator is too much revered, has too strong a right to command, and is too much confided in to be thus dishonoured.
10149{_}5324{_}Father, I _will_, I _do_, ratify all you _have_, all you _can_ promise in my behalf."
10149{_}5325{_}"Even, if I annul the treaty, darling?"
10149{_}5326{_}"Even, in that case, father.
10149{_}5327{_}I will marry none without your consent, and have so absolute a confidence in your tender care of me, that I do not even hesitate to say, I will marry him to whom you contract me."
10149{_}5328{_}"Bless you, bless you, Eve; I do believe you, for such have I ever found you, since thought has had any control over your actions.
10149{_}5329{_}Desire Mr. John Effingham to come hither"--then, as the servant closed the door, he continued,--"and such I believe you will continue to be until your dying day."
10149{_}5330{_}"Nay, reckless, careless father, you forget that you yourself have been instrumental in transferring my duty and obedience to another.
10149{_}5331{_}What if this sea-monster should prove a tyrant, throw off the mask, and show himself in his real colours?
10149{_}5332{_}Are you prepared, then, thoughtless, precipitate, parent"--Eve kissed Mr, Effingham's cheek with childish playfulness, as she spoke, her heart swelling with happiness the whole time, "to preach obedience where obedience would then be due?"
10149{_}5333{_}"Hush, precious--I hear the step of Jack; he must not catch us fooling in this manner."
10149{_}5334{_}Eve rose; and when her kinsman entered the room, she held out her hand kindly to him, though it was with an averted face and a tearful eye.
10149{_}5335{_}"It is time I was summoned," said John Effingham, after he had drawn the blushing girl to him and kissed her forehead, "for what between _tete a tetes_ with young fellows, and _tete a tetes_ with old fellows, this evening, I began to think myself neglected.
10149{_}5336{_}I hope I am still in time to render my decided disapprobation available?"
10149{_}5337{_}"Cousin Jack!"
10149{_}5338{_}exclaimed Eve, with a look of reproachful mockery, "_you_ are the last person who ought to speak of disapprobation, for you have done little else but sing the praises of the applicant, since you first met him."
10149{_}5339{_}"Is it even so?
10149{_}5340{_}then, like others, I must submit to the consequences of my own precipitation and false conclusions.
10149{_}5341{_}Am I summoned to inquire how many thousands a year I shall add to the establishment of the new couple?
10149{_}5342{_}As I hate business, say five at once: and when the papers are ready, I will sign them, without reading,"  "Most generous cynic," cried Eve, "I would I dared, now, to ask a single question!"
10149{_}5343{_}"Ask it without scruple, young lady, for this is the day of your independence and power.
10149{_}5344{_}I am mistaken in the man, if Powis do not prove to be the captain of his own ship, in the end."
10149{_}5345{_}"Well, then, in whose behalf is this liberality really meant; mine, or that of the gentleman?"
10149{_}5346{_}"Fairly enough put," said John Effingham, laughing, again drawing Eve towards him and saluting her cheek; "for if I were on the rack, I could scarcely say which I love best, although you have the consolation of knowing, pert one, that you get the most kisses."
10149{_}5347{_}"I am almost in the same state of feeling myself, John, for a son of my own could scarcely be dearer to me than Paul."
10149{_}5348{_}"I see, indeed, that I _must_ marry," said Eve hastily, dashing the tears of delight from her eyes, for what could give more delight than to hear the praises of her beloved, "if I wish to retain my place in your affections.
10149{_}5349{_}But, father, we forget the question you were to put to cousin Jack."
10149{_}5350{_}"True, love.
10149{_}5351{_}John, your mother was an Assheton?"
10149{_}5352{_}"Assuredly, Ned; you are not to learn my pedigree at this time of day, I trust."
10149{_}5353{_}"We are anxious to make out a relationship between you and Paul; can it not be done?"
10149{_}5354{_}"I would give half my fortune, Eve consenting, were it so!--What reason is there for supposing it probable, or even possible?"
10149{_}5355{_}"You know that he bears the name of his friend, and adopted parent, while that of his family is really Assheton."
10149{_}5356{_}"Assheton!"
10149{_}5357{_}exclaimed the other, in a way to show that this was the first he had ever heard of the fact.
10149{_}5358{_}"Certainly; and as there is but one family of this name, which is a little peculiar in the spelling--for here it is spelt by Paul himself, on this card--we have thought that he must be a relation of yours.
10149{_}5359{_}I hope we are not to be disappointed."
10149{_}5360{_}"Assheton!--It is, as you say, an unusual name; nor is there more than one family that bears it in this country, to my knowledge.
10149{_}5361{_}Can it be possible that Powis is truly an Assheton?"
10149{_}5362{_}"Out of all doubt," Eve eagerly exclaimed; "we have it from his own mouth.
10149{_}5363{_}His father was an Assheton, and his mother was--"  "Who!"
10149{_}5364{_}demanded John Effingham, with a vehemence that startled his companions.
10149{_}5365{_}"Nay, that is more than I can tell you, for he did not mention the family name of his mother; as she was a sister of Lady Dunluce, however, who is the wife of General Ducie, the father of our guest, it is probable her name was Dunluce."
10149{_}5366{_}"I remember no relative that has made such a marriage, or who _can_ have made such a marriage; and yet do I personally and intimately know every Assheton in the country."
10149{_}5367{_}Mr. Effingham and his daughter looked at each other, for it at once struck them all painfully, that there must be Asshetons of another family.
10149{_}5368{_}"Were it not for the peculiar manner in which this name is spelled," said Mr. Effingham, "I could suppose that there are Asshetons of whom we know nothing, but it is difficult to believe that there can be such persons of a respectable family of whom we never heard, for Powis said his relatives were of the Middle States--"  "And that his mother was called Dunluce?"
10149{_}5369{_}demanded John Effingham earnestly, for he too appeared to wish to discover an affinity between himself and Paul.
10149{_}5370{_}"Nay, father, this I think he did not say; though it is quite probable; for the title of his aunt is an ancient barony, and those ancient baronies usually became the family name."
10149{_}5371{_}"In this you must be mistaken, Eve, since he mentioned that the right was derived through his mother's mother, who was an Englishwoman."
10149{_}5372{_}"Why not send for him at once, and put the question?"
10149{_}5373{_}said the simple-minded Mr. Effingham; "next to having him for my own son, it would give me pleasure, John, to learn that he was lawfully entitled to that which I know you have done in his behalf."
10149{_}5374{_}"That is impossible," returned John Effingham.
10149{_}5375{_}"I am an only child, and as for cousins through my mother, there are so many who stand in an equal degree of affinity to me, that no one in particular can be my heir-at-law.
10149{_}5376{_}If there were, I am an Effingham; my estate came from Effinghams, and to an Effingham it should descend in despite of all the Asshetons in America."
10149{_}5377{_}"Paul Powis included!"
10149{_}5378{_}exclaimed Eve, raising a finger reproachfully.
10149{_}5379{_}"True, to him I have left a legacy; but it was to a Powis, and not to an Assheton."
10149{_}5380{_}"And yet he declares himself legally an Assheton, and not a Powis."
10149{_}5381{_}"Say no more of this, Eve; it is unpleasant to me.
10149{_}5382{_}I hate the name of Assheton, though it was my mother's, and could wish never to hear it again."
10149{_}5383{_}Eve and her father were mute, for their kinsman, usually so proud and self-restrained, spoke with suppressed emotion, and it was plain that, for some hidden cause, he felt even more than he expressed.
10149{_}5384{_}The idea that there should be any thing about Paul that could render him an object of dislike to one as dear to her as her cousin, was inexpressibly painful to the former, and she regretted that the subject had ever been introduced.
10149{_}5385{_}Not so with her father.
10149{_}5386{_}Simple, direct, and full of truth, Mr. Effingham rightly enough believed that mysteries in a family could lead to no good, and he repeated his proposal of sending for Paul, and having the matter cleared up at once.
10149{_}5387{_}"You are too reasonable, Jack," he concluded, "to let an antipathy against a name that was your mother's, interfere with your sense of right.
10149{_}5388{_}I know that some unpleasant questions arose concerning your succession to my aunt's fortune, but that was all settled in your favour twenty years ago, and I had thought to your entire satisfaction."
10149{_}5389{_}"Unhappily, family quarrels are ever the most bitter, and usually they are the least reconcileable," returned John Effingham, evasively.--"I would that this young man's name were any thing but Assheton!
10149{_}5390{_}I do not wish to see Eve plighting her faith at the altar, to any one bearing that, accursed name!"
10149{_}5391{_}"I shall plight my faith, if ever it be done, dear cousin John, to the man, and not to his name."
10149{_}5392{_}"No, no--he must keep the appellation of Powis by which we have all learned to love him, and to which he has done so much credit."
10149{_}5393{_}"This is very strange, Jack, for a man who is usually as discreet and as well regulated as yourself.
10149{_}5394{_}I again propose that we send for Paul, and ascertain precisely to what branch of this so-much-disliked family he really belongs."
10149{_}5395{_}"No, father, if you love me, not now!"
10149{_}5396{_}cried Eve, arresting Mr. Effingham's hand as it touched the bell-cord; "it would appear distrustful, and even cruel, were we to enter into such an inquiry so soon.
10149{_}5397{_}Powis might think we valued his family, more than we do himself,"  "Eve is right, Ned; but I will not sleep without learning all.
10149{_}5398{_}There is an unfinished examination of the papers left by poor Monday, and I will take an occasion to summon Paul to its completion, when an opportunity will offer to renew the subject of his own history; for it was at the other investigation that he first spoke frankly to me, concerning himself."
10149{_}5399{_}"Do so, cousin Jack, and let it be at once," said Eve earnestly.
10149{_}5400{_}"I can trust you with Powis alone, for I know how much you respect and esteem him in your heart.
10149{_}5401{_}See, it is already ten."
10149{_}5402{_}"But, he will naturally wish to spend the close of an evening like this engaged in investigating something very different from Mr. Monday's tale," returned her cousin; the smile with which he spoke chasing away the look of chilled aversion that had so lately darkened his noble features.
10149{_}5403{_}"No, not to-night," answered the blushing Eve.
10149{_}5404{_}"I have confessed weakness enough for one day.
10149{_}5405{_}Tomorrow, if you will--if he will,--but not to-night.
10149{_}5406{_}I shall retire with Mrs. Hawker, who already complains of fatigue; and you will send for Powis, to meet you in your own room, without unnecessary delay."
10149{_}5407{_}Eve kissed John Effingham coaxingly, and as they walked together out of the library, she pointed towards the door that led to the chambers.
10149{_}5408{_}Her cousin laughingly complied, and when in his own room, he sent a message to Paul to join him.
10149{_}5409{_}"Now, indeed, may I call you a kinsman," said John Effingham, rising to receive the young man, towards whom he advanced, with extended hands, in his most winning manner.
10149{_}5410{_}"Eve's frankness and your own discernment have made us a happy family!"
10149{_}5411{_}"If any thing could add to the felicity of being acceptable to Miss Effingham," returned Paul, struggling to command his feelings, "it is the manner in which her father and yourself have received my poor offers."
10149{_}5412{_}"Well, we will now speak of it no more.
10149{_}5413{_}I saw from the first which way things were tending, and it was my plain-dealing that opened the eyes of Templemore to the impossibility of his ever succeeding, by which means his heart has been kept from breaking."
10149{_}5414{_}"Oh!
10149{_}5415{_}Mr. Effingham, Templemore never loved-Eve Effingham!
10149{_}5416{_}I thought so once, and he thought so, too; but it could not have been a love like mine."
10149{_}5417{_}"It certainly differed in the essential circumstance of reciprocity, which, in itself, singularly qualifies the passion, so far as duration is concerned.
10149{_}5418{_}Templemore did not exactly know the reason why he preferred Eve; but, having seen so much of the society in which he lived, I was enabled to detect the cause.
10149{_}5419{_}Accustomed to an elaborate sophistication, the singular union of refinement and nature caught his fancy; for the English seldom see the last separated from vulgarity; and when it is found, softened by a high intelligence and polished manners, it has usually great attractions for the _biases_."
10149{_}5420{_}"He is fortunate in having so readily found a substitute for Eve Effingham!"
10149{_}5421{_}"This change is not unnatural, neither.
10149{_}5422{_}In the first place, I, with this truth-telling 'tongue, destroyed all hope, before he had committed himself by a declaration; and then Grace Van Cortlandt possesses the great attraction of nature, in a degree quite equal to that of her cousin.
10149{_}5423{_}Besides, Templemore, though a gentleman, and a brave man, and a worthy one, is not remarkable for qualities of a very extraordinary kind.
10149{_}5424{_}He will be as happy as is usual for an Englishman of his class to be, and he has no particular right to expect more.
10149{_}5425{_}I sent for you, however, less to talk of love, than to trace its unhappy consequences in this affair, revealed by the papers of poor Monday.
10149{_}5426{_}It is time we acquitted ourselves of that trust.
10149{_}5427{_}Do me the favour to open the dressing-case that stands on the toilet- table; you will find in it the key that belongs to the bureau, where I have placed the secretary that contains the papers."
10149{_}5428{_}Paul did as desired.
10149{_}5429{_}The dressing-case was complicated and large, having several compartments, none of which were fastened.
10149{_}5430{_}In the first opened, he saw a miniature of a female so beautiful, that his eve rested on it, as it might be, by a fascination.--Notwithstanding some difference produced by the fashions of different periods, the resemblance to the object of his love, was obvious at a glance.
10149{_}5431{_}Borne away by the pleasure of the discovery, and actually believing that he saw a picture of Eve, drawn in a dress that did not in a great degree vary from the present attire, fashion having undergone no very striking revolution in the last twenty years, he exclaimed--  "This is indeed a treasure, Mr. Effingham, and most sincerely do I envy you its possession.
10149{_}5432{_}It is like, and yet, in some particulars, it is unlike--it scarcely does Miss Effingham justice about the nose and forehead!"
10149{_}5433{_}John Effingham started when he saw the miniature in Paul's hand, but recovering himself, he smiled at the eager delusion of his young friend, and said with perfect composure--  "It is not Eve, but her mother.
10149{_}5434{_}The two features you have named in the former came from my family; but in all the others, the likeness is almost identical."
10149{_}5435{_}"This then is Mrs.
10149{_}5436{_}Effingham!"
10149{_}5437{_}murmured Paul, gazing on the face of the mother of his love, with a respectful melancholy, and an interest that was rather heightened than lessened by a knowledge of the truth.
10149{_}5438{_}"She died young, sir?"
10149{_}5439{_}"Quite; she can scarcely be said to have become an angel too soon, for she was always one."
10149{_}5440{_}This was said with a feeling that did not escape Paul, though it surprised him.
10149{_}5441{_}There were six or seven miniature-cases in the compartment of the dressing-box, and supposing that the one which lay uppermost belonged to the miniature in his hand, he raised it, and opened the lid with a view to replace the picture of Eve's mother, with a species of pious reverence.
10149{_}5442{_}Instead of finding an empty case, however, another miniature met his eye.
10149{_}5443{_}The exclamation that now escaped the young man was one of delight and surprise.
10149{_}5444{_}"That must be my grandmother, with whom you are in such raptures, at present," said John Effingham, laughing--"I was comparing it yesterday with the picture of Eve, which is in the Russia-leather case, that you will find somewhere there.
10149{_}5445{_}I do not wonder, however, at your admiration, for she was a beauty in her day, and no woman is fool enough to be painted after she grows ugly."
10149{_}5446{_}"Not so--not so--Mr. Effingham!
10149{_}5447{_}This is the miniature I lost in the Montauk, and which I had given up as booty to the Arabs.
10149{_}5448{_}It has, doubtless, found its way into your state-room, and has been put among your effects by your man, through mistake.
10149{_}5449{_}It is very precious to me, for it is nearly every memorial I possess of my own mother!"
10149{_}5450{_}"Your mother!"
10149{_}5451{_}exclaimed John Effingham rising.
10149{_}5452{_}"I think there must be some mistake, for I examined all those pictures this very morning, and it is the first time they have been opened since our arrival from Europe.
10149{_}5453{_}It cannot be the missing picture."
10149{_}5454{_}"Mine it is certainly; in that I cannot be mistaken!"
10149{_}5455{_}"It would be odd indeed, if one of my grandmothers, for both are there, should prove to be your mother.--Powis, will you have the goodness to let me see the picture you mean."
10149{_}5456{_}Paul brought the miniature and a light, placing both before the eyes of his friend.
10149{_}5457{_}"That!"
10149{_}5458{_}exclaimed John Effingham, his voice sounding harsh and unnatural to the listener,--"that picture like _your_ mother!"
10149{_}5459{_}"It is her miniature--_the_ miniature that was transmitted to me, from those who had charge of my childhood.
10149{_}5460{_}I cannot be mistaken as to the countenance, or the dress."
10149{_}5461{_}"And your father's name was Assheton?"
10149{_}5462{_}"Certainly--John Assheton, of the Asshetons of Pennsylvania."
10149{_}5463{_}John Effingham groaned aloud; when Paul stepped back equally shocked and surprised, he saw that the face of his friend was almost livid, and that the hand which held the picture shook like the aspen.
10149{_}5464{_}"Are you unwell, dear Mr.
10149{_}5465{_}Effingham?"
10149{_}5466{_}"No--no--'tis impossible!
10149{_}5467{_}This lady never had a child.
10149{_}5468{_}Powis, you have been deceived by some fancied, or some real resemblance.
10149{_}5469{_}This picture is mine, and has not been out of my possession these five and twenty years."
10149{_}5470{_}"Pardon me, sir, it is the picture of my mother, and no other; the very picture lost in the Montauk."
10149{_}5471{_}The gaze that John Effingham cast upon the young man was ghastly; and Paul was about to ring the bell, but a gesture of denial prevented him.
10149{_}5472{_}"See," said John Effingham, hoarsely, as he touched a spring in the setting, and exposed to view the initials of two names interwoven with hair--"is this, too, yours?"
10149{_}5473{_}Paul looked surprised and disappointed.
10149{_}5474{_}"That certainly settles the question; my miniature had no such addition; and yet I believe that sweet and pensive countenance to be the face of my own beloved mother, and of no one else."
10149{_}5475{_}John Effingham struggled to appear calm; and, replacing the pictures, he took the key from the dressing case, and, opening the bureau, he took out the secretary.
10149{_}5476{_}This he signed for Powis, who had the key, to open; throwing himself into a chair, though every thing was done mechanically, as if his mind and body had little or no connection with each other.
10149{_}5477{_}"Some accidental resemblance has deceived you as to the miniature," he said, while Paul was looking for the proper number among the letters of Mr. Monday.
10149{_}5478{_}"No--no--that _cannot_ be the picture of your mother.
10149{_}5479{_}She left no child.
10149{_}5480{_}Assheton did you say, was the name of your father?"
10149{_}5481{_}"Assheton--John Assheton--about that, at least, there can have been no mistake.
10149{_}5482{_}This is the num her at which we left off--will you, sir, or shall I, read?"
10149{_}5483{_}The other made a sign for Paul to read; looking, at the same time, as if it were impossible for him to discharge that duty himself.
10149{_}5484{_}"This is a letter from the woman who appears to have been entrusted with the child, to the man Dowse," said Paul, first glancing his eyes over the page,--"it appears to be little else but gossip--ha!--what is this, I see?"
10149{_}5485{_}John Effingham raised himself in his chair, and he sat gazing at Paul, as one gazes who expects some extraordinary developement, though of what nature he knew not.
10149{_}5486{_}"This is a singular passage," Paul continued--"so much so as to need elucidation.
10149{_}5487{_}'I have taken the child with me to get the picture from the jeweller, who has mended the ring, and the little urchin knew it at a glance.'"
10149{_}5488{_}"What is there remarkable in that?
10149{_}5489{_}Others beside ourselves have had pictures;-and this child knows its own better than you."
10149{_}5490{_}"Mr. Effingham, such a thing occurred to myself!
10149{_}5491{_}It is one of those early events of which I still retain, have ever retained, a vivid recollection.
10149{_}5492{_}Though little more than an infant at the time, well do I recollect to have been taken in this manner to a jeweller's, and the delight I felt at recovering my mother's picture, that which is now lost, after it had not been seen for a month or two."
10149{_}5493{_}"Paul Blunt--Powis--Assheton "--said John Effingham, speaking so hoarsely as to be nearly unintelligible, "remain here a few minutes-- I will rejoin you."
10149{_}5494{_}John Effingham arose, and, notwithstanding he rallied all his powers, it was with extreme difficulty he succeeded in reaching the door, steadily rejecting the offered assistance of Paul, who was at a loss what to think of so much agitation in a man usually so self-possessed and tranquil.
10149{_}5495{_}When out of the room, John Effingham did better, and he proceeded to the library, followed by his own man, whom he had ordered to accompany him with a light.
10149{_}5496{_}"Desire Captain Ducie to give me the favour of his company for a moment," he then said, motioning to the servant to withdraw.
10149{_}5497{_}"You will not be needed any longer."
10149{_}5498{_}It was but a minute before Captain Ducie stood before him.
10149{_}5499{_}This gentleman was instantly struck with the pallid look, and general agitation of the person he had come to meet, and he expressed an apprehension that he was suddenly taken ill.
10149{_}5500{_}But a motion of the hand forbade his touching the bell-cord, and he waited in silent wonder at the scene which he had been so unexpectedly called to witness.
10149{_}5501{_}"A glass of that water, if you please, Captain Ducie," said John Effingham, endeavouring to smile with gentleman-like courtesy, as he made the request, though the effort, caused his countenance to appear ghastly again.
10149{_}5502{_}A little recovered by this beverage, he said more steadily--  "You are the cousin of Powis, Captain Ducie."
10149{_}5503{_}"We are sisters' children, sir."
10149{_}5504{_}"And your mother is"  "Lady Dunluce--a peeress in her own right."
10149{_}5505{_}"But, what--her family name?"
10149{_}5506{_}"Her own family name has been sunk in that of my father, the Ducies claiming to be as old and as honourable a family, as that from which my mother inherits her rank.
10149{_}5507{_}Indeed the Dunluce barony has gone through so many names, by means of females, that I believe there is no intention to revive the original appellation of the family which was first summoned."
10149{_}5508{_}"You mistake, me--your mother--when she married--was--"  "Miss Warrender."
10149{_}5509{_}"I thank you, sir, and will trouble you no longer," returned John Effingham, rising and struggling to make his manner second the courtesy of his words--"I have troubled you, abruptly--incoherently I fear--your arm--"  Captain Ducie stepped hastily forward, and was just in time to prevent the other from falling senseless on the floor, by receiving him in his own arms.
10149{_}5510{_}Chapter XXVII.
10149{_}5511{_}"What's Hecuba to him, or he to Hecuba, That he should weep for   her."
10149{_}5512{_}HAMLET.
10149{_}5513{_}The next morning, Paul and Eve were alone in that library which had long been the scene of the confidential communications of the Effingham family.
10149{_}5514{_}Eve had been weeping, nor were Paul's eyes entirely free from the signs of his having given way to strong sensations.
10149{_}5515{_}Still happiness beamed in the countenance of each, and the timid but affectionate glances with which our heroine returned the fond, admiring look of her lover, were any thing but distrustful of their future felicity.
10149{_}5516{_}Her hand was in his, and it was often raised to his lips, as they pursued the conversation.
10149{_}5517{_}"This is so wonderful," exclaimed Eve, after one of the frequent musing pauses in which both indulged "that I can scarcely believe myself awake.
10149{_}5518{_}That you Blunt, Powis, Assheton, should, after all, prove an Effingham!
10149{_}5519{_}"And I, who have so long thought myself an orphan, should find a living father, and he a man like Mr. John Effingham!"
10149{_}5520{_}I have long thought that something heavy lay at the honest heart of cousin Jack--you will excuse me Powis, but I shall need time to learn to call him by a name of greater respect."
10149{_}5521{_}"Call him always so, love, for I am certain it would pain him to meet with any change in you.
10149{_}5522{_}He _is_ your cousin Jack"  "Nay, he may some day unexpectedly become _my_ father too, as he has so wonderfully become yours," rejoined Eve, glancing archly at the glowing face of the delighted young man; "and then cousin Jack might prove too familiar and disrespectful a term."
10149{_}5523{_}"So much stronger does your claim to him appear than mine, that I think, when that blessed day shall arrive, Eve, it will convert him into _my_ cousin Jack, instead of your father.
10149{_}5524{_}But call _him_ as you may, why do you still insist on calling _me_ Powis?"
10149{_}5525{_}"That name will ever be precious in my eyes!
10149{_}5526{_}You abridge me of my rights, in denying me a change of name.
10149{_}5527{_}Half the young ladies of the country marry for the novelty of being called Mrs. Somebody else, instead of the Misses they were, while I am condemned to remain Eve Effingham for life."
10149{_}5528{_}"If you object to the appellation, I can continue to call myself Powis.
10149{_}5529{_}This has been done so long now as almost to legalize the act."
10149{_}5530{_}"Indeed, no--you are an Effingham, and as an Effingham ought you to be known.
10149{_}5531{_}What a happy lot is mine!
10149{_}5532{_}Spared even the pain of parting with my old friends, at the great occurrence of my life, and finding my married home the same as the home of my childhood!"
10149{_}5533{_}"I owe every thing to you, Eve, name, happiness, and even a home."
10149{_}5534{_}"I know not that.
10149{_}5535{_}Now that it is known that you are the great- grandson of Edward Effingham, I think your chance of possessing the Wigwam would be quite equal to my own, even were we to look different ways in quest of married happiness.
10149{_}5536{_}An arrangement of that nature would not be difficult to make, as John Effingham might easily compensate a daughter for the loss of her house and lands by means of those money-yielding stocks and bonds, of which he possesses so many."
10149{_}5537{_}"I view it differently.
10149{_}5538{_}_You_ were Mr.--my father's heir--how strangely the word father sounds in unaccustomed ears!--But you were my father's chosen heir, and I shall owe to you, dearest, in addition to the treasures of your heart and faith, my fortune."
10149{_}5539{_}"Are you so very certain of this, ingrate?--Did not Mr. John Effingham--cousin Jack--adopt you as his son even before he knew of the natural tie that actually exists between you?"
10149{_}5540{_}"True, for I perceive that you have been made acquainted with most of that which has passed.
10149{_}5541{_}But I hope, that in telling you his own offer, Mr.--that my father did not forget to tell you of the terms on which it was accepted?"
10149{_}5542{_}"He did you ample justice, or he informed me that you stipulated there should be no altering of wills, but that the unworthy heir already chosen, should still remain the heir."
10149{_}5543{_}"And to this Mr--"  "Cousin Jack," said Eve, laughing, for the laugh comes easy to the supremely happy.
10149{_}5544{_}"To this cousin Jack assented?"
10149{_}5545{_}"Most true, again.
10149{_}5546{_}The will would not have been altered, for your interests were already cared for."
10149{_}5547{_}"And at the expense of yours, dearest?
10149{_}5548{_}Eve!"
10149{_}5549{_}"It would have been at the expense of my better feelings, Paul, had it not been so.
10149{_}5550{_}However, that will can never do either harm or good to any, now."
10149{_}5551{_}"I trust it will remain unchanged, beloved, that I may owe as much to you as possible."
10149{_}5552{_}Eve looked kindly at her betrothed, blushed even deeper than the bloom which happiness had left on her cheek, and smiled like one who knew more than she cared to express.
10149{_}5553{_}"What secret meaning is concealed behind the look of portentous signification?"
10149{_}5554{_}"It means, Powis, that I have done a deed that is almost criminal.
10149{_}5555{_}I have destroyed a will."
10149{_}5556{_}"Not my father's!"
10149{_}5557{_}"Even so--but it was done in his presence, and if not absolutely with his consent, with his knowledge.
10149{_}5558{_}When he informed me of your superior rights, I insisted on its being done, at once, so, should any accident occur, you will be heir at law, as a matter of course.
10149{_}5559{_}Cousin Jack affected reluctance, but I believe he slept more sweetly, for the consciousness that this act of justice had been done."
10149{_}5560{_}"I fear he slept little, as it was; it was long past midnight before I left him, and the agitation of his spirits was such as to appear awful in the eyes of a son!"
10149{_}5561{_}"And the promised explanation is to come, to renew his distress!
10149{_}5562{_}Why make it at all?
10149{_}5563{_}is it not enough that we are certain that you are his child?
10149{_}5564{_}and for that, have we not the solemn assurance, the declaration of almost a dying man!"
10149{_}5565{_}"There should be no shade left over my mother's fame.
10149{_}5566{_}Faults there have been, somewhere, but it is painful, oh!
10149{_}5567{_}how painful!
10149{_}5568{_}for a child to think evil of a mother."
10149{_}5569{_}"On this head you are already assured.
10149{_}5570{_}Your own previous knowledge, and John Effingham's distinct declarations, make your mother blameless."
10149{_}5571{_}"Beyond question; but this sacrifice must be made to my mother's spirit.
10149{_}5572{_}It is now nine; the breakfast-bell will soon ring, and then we are promised the whole of the melancholy tale.
10149{_}5573{_}Pray with me, Eve, that it may be such as will not wound the ear of a son!"
10149{_}5574{_}Eve took the hand of Paul within both of hers, and kissed it with a sort of holy hope, that in its exhibition caused neither blush nor shame.
10149{_}5575{_}Indeed so bound together were these young hearts, so ample and confiding had been the confessions of both, and so pure was their love, that neither regarded such a manifestation of feeling, differently from what an acknowledgement of a dependence on any other sacred principle would have been esteemed.
10149{_}5576{_}The bell now summoned them to the breakfast-table, and Eve, yielding to her sex's timidity, desired Paul to precede her a few minutes, that the sanctity of their confidence might not be weakened by the observation of profane eyes.
10149{_}5577{_}The meal was silent; the discovery of the previous night, which had been made known to all in the house, by the declarations of John Effingham as soon as he was restored to his senses, Captain Ducie having innocently collected those within hearing to his succour, causing a sort of moral suspense that weighed on the vivacity if not on the comforts of the whole party, the lovers alone excepted.
10149{_}5578{_}As profound happiness is seldom talkative, the meal was a silent one, then; and when it was ended, they who had no tie of blood with the parties most concerned with the revelations of the approaching interview, delicately separated, making employments and engagements that left the family at perfect liberty; while those who had been previously notified that their presence would be acceptable, silently repaired to the dressing-room of John Effingham.
10149{_}5579{_}The latter party was composed of Mr. Effingham, Paul, and Eve, only.
10149{_}5580{_}The first passed into his cousin's bed-room, where he had a private conference that lasted half an hour.
10149{_}5581{_}At the end of that time, the two others were summoned to join him.
10149{_}5582{_}John Effingham was a strong-minded and a proud man, his governing fault being the self-reliance that indisposed him to throw himself on a greater power, for the support, guidance, and counsel, that all need.
10149{_}5583{_}To humiliation before God, however, he was not unused, and of late years it had got to be frequent with him, and it was only in connexion with his fellow-creatures that his repugnance to admitting even of an equality existed.
10149{_}5584{_}He felt how much more just, intuitive, conscientious even, were his own views than those of mankind, in general; and he seldom deigned to consult with any as to the opinions he ought to entertain, or as to the conduct he ought to pursue.
10149{_}5585{_}It is scarcely necessary to say, that such a being was one of strong and engrossing passions, the impulses frequently proving too imperious for the affections, or even for principles.
10149{_}5586{_}The scene that he was now compelled to go through, was consequently one of sore mortification and self-abasement; and yet, feeling its justice no less than its necessity, and having made up his mind to discharge what had now become a duty, his very pride of character led him to do it manfully, and with no uncalled-for reserves.
10149{_}5587{_}It was a painful and humiliating task, notwithstanding; and it required all the self-command, all the sense of right, and all the clear perception of consequences, that one so quick to discriminate could not avoid perceiving, to enable him to go through it with the required steadiness and connexion.
10149{_}5588{_}John Effingham received Paul and Eve, seated in an easy chair; for, while he could not be said to be ill, it was evident that his very frame had been shaken by the events and emotions of the few preceding hours.
10149{_}5589{_}He gave a hand to each, and, drawing Eve affectionately to him, he imprinted a kiss on a cheek that was burning, though it paled and reddened in quick succession, the heralds of the tumultuous thoughts within.
10149{_}5590{_}The look he gave Paul was kind and welcome, while a hectic spot glowed on each cheek, betraying that his presence excited pain as well as pleasure.
10149{_}5591{_}A long pause succeeded this meeting, when John Effingham broke the silence.
10149{_}5592{_}"There can now be no manner of question, my dear Paul," he said, smiling affectionately but sadly as he looked at the young man, "about your being my son.
10149{_}5593{_}The letter written by John Assheton to your mother, after the separation of your parents, would settle that important point, had not the names, and the other facts that have come to our knowledge, already convinced me of the precious truth; for precious and very dear to me is the knowledge that I am the father of so worthy a child.
10149{_}5594{_}You must prepare yourself to hear things that it will not be pleasant for a son to listen--"  "No, no--cousin Jack--_dear_ cousin Jack!"
10149{_}5595{_}cried Eve, throwing herself precipitately into her kinsman's arms, "we will hear nothing of the sort.
10149{_}5596{_}It is sufficient that you are Paul's father, and we wish to know no more--will hear no more."
10149{_}5597{_}"This is like yourself, Eve, but it will not answer what I conceive to be the dictates of duty.
10149{_}5598{_}Paul had two parents; and not the slightest suspicion ought to rest on one of them, in order to spare the feelings of the other.
10149{_}5599{_}In showing me this kindness you are treating Paul inconsiderately."
10149{_}5600{_}"I beg, dear sir, you will not think too much of me, but entirely consult your own judgment--your own sense of--in short, dear father, that you will consider yourself before your son."
10149{_}5601{_}"I thank you, my children--what a word, and what a novel sensation is this, for me, Ned!--I feel all your kindness, but if you would consult my peace of mind, and wish me to regain my self-respect, you will allow me to disburthen my soul of the weight that oppresses it.
10149{_}5602{_}This is strong language; but, while I have no confessions of deliberate criminality, or of positive vice to make, I feel it to be hardly too strong for the facts.
10149{_}5603{_}My tale will be very short, and I crave your patience, Ned, while I expose my former weakness to these young people."
10149{_}5604{_}Here John Effingham paused, as if to recollect himself; then he proceeded with a seriousness of manner that caused every syllable he uttered to tell on the ears of his listeners.
10149{_}5605{_}"It is well known to your father, Eve, though it will probably be new to you," he said, "that I felt a passion for your sainted mother, such as few men ever experience for any of your sex.
10149{_}5606{_}Your father and myself were suitors for her favour at the same time, though I can scarcely say, Edward, that any feeling of rivalry entered into the competition."
10149{_}5607{_}"You do me no more than justice, John, for if the affection of my beloved Eve could cause me grief, it was because it brought you pain."
10149{_}5608{_}"I had the additional mortification of approving of the choice she made; for, certainly, as respected her own happiness, your mother did more wisely in confiding it to the regulated, mild, and manly virtues of your father, than in placing her hopes on one as eccentric and violent as myself."
10149{_}5609{_}"This is injustice, John.
10149{_}5610{_}You may have been positive, and a little stern, at times, but never violent, and least of all with a woman."
10149{_}5611{_}"Call it what you will, it unfitted me to make one so meek, gentle, and yet high-souled, as entirely happy as she deserved to be, and as you did make her, while she remained on earth.
10149{_}5612{_}I had the courage to stay and learn that your father was accepted, (though the marriage was deferred two years in consideration for my feelings,) and then with a heart, in which mortified pride, wounded love, a resentment that was aimed rather against myself than against your parents, I quitted home, with a desperate determination never to rejoin my family again.
10149{_}5613{_}This resolution I did not own to myself, even, but it lurked in my intentions unowned, festering like a mortal disease; and it caused me, when I burst away from the scene of happiness of which I had been a compelled witness, to change my name, and to make several inconsistent and extravagant arrangements to abandon my native country even."
10149{_}5614{_}"Poor John!"
10149{_}5615{_}exclaimed his cousin, involuntarily, "this would have been a sad blot on our felicity, had we known it!"
10149{_}5616{_}"I was certain of that, even when most writhing under the blow you had so unintentionally inflicted, Ned; but the passions are tyrannical and inconsistent masters.
10149{_}5617{_}I took my mother's name, changed my servant, and avoided those parts of the country where I was known.
10149{_}5618{_}At this time, I feared for my own reason, and the thought crossed my mind, that by making a sudden marriage I might supplant the old passion, which was so near destroying me, by some of that gentler affection which seemed to render you so blest, Edward."
10149{_}5619{_}"Nay, John, this was, itself, a temporary tottering of the reasoning faculties,"  "It was simply the effect of passions, over which reason had never been taught to exercise a sufficient influence.
10149{_}5620{_}Chance brought me acquainted with Miss Warrender, in one of the southern states, and she promised, as I fancied, to realize all my wild schemes of happiness and resentment."
10149{_}5621{_}"Resentment, John?"
10149{_}5622{_}"I fear I must confess it, Edward, though it were anger against myself.
10149{_}5623{_}I first made Miss Warrender's acquaintance as John Assheton, and some months had passed before I determined to try the fearful experiment I have mentioned.
10149{_}5624{_}She was young, beautiful, well-born, virtuous and good; if she had a fault, it was her high spirit--not high temper, but she was high-souled and proud."
10149{_}5625{_}"Thank God, for this!"
10149{_}5626{_}burst from the inmost soul of Paul, with unrestrainable feeling.
