10149{_}5627{_}"You have little to apprehend, my son, on the subject of your mother's character; if not perfect, she was wanting in no womanly virtue, and might, nay ought to have made any reasonable man happy.
10149{_}5628{_}My offer was accepted, for I found her heart disengaged.
10149{_}5629{_}Miss Warrender was not affluent, and, in addition to the other unjustifiable motives that influenced me, I thought there would be a satisfaction in believing that I had been chosen for myself, rather than for my wealth.
10149{_}5630{_}Indeed, I had got to be distrustful and ungenerous, and then I disliked the confession of the weakness that had induced me to change my name.
10149{_}5631{_}The simple, I might almost say, loose laws of this country, on the subject of marriage, removed all necessity for explanations, there being no bans nor license necessary, and the Christian name only being used in the ceremony.
10149{_}5632{_}We were married, therefore, but I was not so unmindful of the rights of others, as to neglect to procure a certificate, under a promise of secrecy, in my own name.
10149{_}5633{_}By going to the place where the ceremony was performed, you will also find the marriage of John Effingham and Mildred Warrender duly registered in the books of the church to which the officiating clergyman belonged.
10149{_}5634{_}So far, I did what justice required, though, with a motiveless infatuation for which I can now hardly account, which _cannot_ be accounted for, except by ascribing it to the inconsistent cruelty of passion, I concealed my real name from her with whom there should have been no concealment.
10149{_}5635{_}I fancied, I tried to fancy I was no impostor, as I was of the family I represented myself to be, by the mother's side; and.
10149{_}5636{_}I wished to believe that my peace would easily be made when I avowed myself to be the man I really was.
10149{_}5637{_}I had found Miss Warrender and her sister living with a well-intentioned but weak aunt, and with no male relative to make those inquiries which would so naturally have suggested themselves to persons of ordinary worldly prudence.
10149{_}5638{_}It is true, I had become known to them under favourable circumstances, and they had good reason to believe me an Assheton from some accidental evidence that I possessed, which unanswerably proved my affinity to that family, without, betraying my true name.
10149{_}5639{_}But there is so little distrust in this country, that, by keeping at a distance from the places in which I was personally known, a life might have passed without exposure."
10149{_}5640{_}"This was all wrong, dear cousin Jack," said Eve, taking his hand and affectionately kissing it, while her face kindled with a sense of her sex's rights, "and I should be unfaithful to my womanhood were I to say otherwise.
10149{_}5641{_}You had entered into the most solemn of all human contracts, and evil is the omen when such an engagement is veiled by any untruth.
10149{_}5642{_}But, still, one would think you might have been happy with a virtuous and affectionate wife!"
10149{_}5643{_}"Alas!
10149{_}5644{_}it is but a hopeless experiment to marry one, while the heart is still yearning towards another.
10149{_}5645{_}Confidence came too late; for, discovering my unhappiness, Mildred extorted a tardy confession from me; a confession of all but the concealment of the true name; and justly wounded at the deception of which she had been the dupe, and yielding to the impulses of a high and generous spirit, she announced to me that she was unwilling to continue the wife of any man on such terms.
10149{_}5646{_}We parted, and I hastened into the south-western states, where I passed the next twelvemonth in travelling, hurrying from place to place, in the vain hope of obtaining peace of mind.
10149{_}5647{_}I plunged into the prairies, and most of the time mentioned was lost to me as respects the world, in the company of hunters and trappers."
10149{_}5648{_}"This, then, explains your knowledge of that section of the country," exclaimed Mr. Effingham, "for which I have never been able to account!
10149{_}5649{_}We thought you among your old friends in Carolina, all that time."
10149{_}5650{_}"No one knew where I had secreted myself, for I passed under another feigned name, and had no servant, even.
10149{_}5651{_}I had, however, sent an address to Mildred, where a letter would find me; for, I had begun to feel a sincere affection for her, though it might not have amounted to passion, and looked forward to being reunited, when her wounded feelings had time to regain their tranquillity.
10149{_}5652{_}The obligations of wedlock are too serious to be lightly thrown aside, and I felt persuaded that neither of us would be satisfied in the end, without discharging the duties of the state into which we had entered."
10149{_}5653{_}"And why did you not hasten to your poor wife, cousin Jack," Eve innocently demanded, "as soon as you returned to the settlements?"
10149{_}5654{_}"Alas!
10149{_}5655{_}my-dear girl, I found letters at St. Louis announcing her death.
10149{_}5656{_}Nothing was said of any child, nor did I in the least suspect that I was about to become a father.
10149{_}5657{_}When Mildred died, I thought all the ties, all the obligations, all the traces of my ill-judged marriage were extinct; and the course taken by her relations, of whom, in this country, there remained very few, left me no inclination to proclaim it.
10149{_}5658{_}By observing silence, I continued to pass as a bachelor, of course; though had there been any apparent reason for avowing what had occurred, I think no one who knows me, can suppose I would have shrunk from doing so."
10149{_}5659{_}"May I inquire, my dear sir," Paul asked, with a timidity of manner that betrayed how tenderly he felt it necessary to touch on the subject at all--"may I inquire, my dear sir, what course was taken by my mother's relatives?"
10149{_}5660{_}"I never knew Mr. Warrender, my wife's brother, but he had the reputation of being a haughty and exacting man.
10149{_}5661{_}His letters were not friendly; scarcely tolerable; for he affected to believe I had given a false address at the west, when I was residing in the middle states, and he threw out hints that to me were then inexplicable, but which the letters left with me, by Paul, have sufficiently explained.
10149{_}5662{_}I thought him cruel and unfeeling at the time, but he had an excuse for his conduct."
10149{_}5663{_}"Which was, sir--?"
10149{_}5664{_}Paul eagerly inquired.
10149{_}5665{_}"I perceive by the letters you have given me, my son, that your mother's family had imbibed the opinion, that I was John Assheton, of Lancaster, a man of singular humours, who had made an unfortunate marriage in Spain, and whose wife, I believe, is still living in Paris, though lost to herself and her friends.
10149{_}5666{_}My kinsman lived retired, and never recovered the blow.
10149{_}5667{_}As he was one of the only persons of the name, who could have married your mother, her relatives appear to have taken up the idea that he had been guilty of bigamy, and of course that Paul was illegitimate.
10149{_}5668{_}Mr. Warrender, by his letters, appears even to have had an interview with this person, and, on mentioning his wife, was rudely repulsed from the house.
10149{_}5669{_}It was a proud family, and Mildred being dead, the concealment of the birth of her child was resorted to, as a means of averting a fancied disgrace.
10149{_}5670{_}As for myself, I call the all-seeing eye of God to witness, that the thought of my being a parent never crossed my mind, until I learned that a John Assheton was the father of Paul, and that the miniature of Mildred Warrender, that I received at the period of our engagement, was the likeness of his mother.
10149{_}5671{_}The simple declaration of Captain Ducie concerning the family name of his mother, removed all doubt."
10149{_}5672{_}"But, cousin Jack, did not the mention of Lady Dunluce, of the Ducies, and of Paul's connections, excite curiosity?"
10149{_}5673{_}"Concerning what, dear?
10149{_}5674{_}I could have no curiosity about a child of whose existence I was ignorant.
10149{_}5675{_}I did know that the Warrenders had pretensions to both rank and fortune in England, but never heard the title, and cared nothing about money that would not probably, be Mildred's.
10149{_}5676{_}Of General Ducie I never even heard, as he married after my separation, and subsequently to the receipt of my brother-in-law's letters, I wished to forget the existence of the family.
10149{_}5677{_}I went to Europe, and remained abroad seven years and as this was at a time when the continent was closed against the English, I was not in a way to hear any thing on the subject.
10149{_}5678{_}On my return, my wife's aunt was dead; the last of my wife's brothers was dead; her sister must then have been Mrs. Ducie; no one mentioned the Warrenders, all traces of whom were nearly lost in this country, and to me the subject was too painful to be either sought or dwelt on.
10149{_}5679{_}It is a curious fact, that, in 1829, during our late visit to the old world, I ascended the Nile with General Ducie for a travelling companion.
10149{_}5680{_}We met at Alexandria, and wont to the cataracts and returned in company, He knew me as John Effingham, an American traveller of fortune, if of no particular merit, and I knew him as an agreeable English general officer.
10149{_}5681{_}He had the reserve of an Englishman of rank, and seldom spoke of his family, and it was only on our return, that I found he had letters from his wife, Lady Dunluce; but little did I dream that Lady Dunluce was Mabel Warrender.
10149{_}5682{_}How often are we on the very verge of important information, and yet live on in ignorance and obscurity!
10149{_}5683{_}The Ducies appear finally to have arrived at the opinion that the marriage was legal, and that no reproach rests on the birth of Paul, by the inquiries made concerning the eccentric John Assheton."
10149{_}5684{_}"They fancied, in common with my uncle Warrender, for a long time, that the John Assheton whom you have mentioned, sir," said Paul, "was my father.
10149{_}5685{_}But.
10149{_}5686{_}some accidental information, at a late day, convinced them of their error, and then they naturally enough supposed that it was the only other John Assheton that could be heard of, who passes, and probably with sufficient reason, for a bachelor.
10149{_}5687{_}This latter gentleman I have myself always supposed to be my father, though he has treated two or three letters I have written to him, with the indifference with which one would be apt to treat the pretensions of an impostor.
10149{_}5688{_}Pride has prevented me from attempting to renew the correspondence lately."
10149{_}5689{_}"It is John Assheton of Bristol, my mother's brother's son, as inveterate a bachelor as is to be found in the Union" said John Effingham, smiling, in spite of the grave subject and deep emotions that had so lately been uppermost in his thoughts.
10149{_}5690{_}"He must have supposed your letters were an attempt at mystification on the part of some of his jocular associates, and I am surprised that he thought it necessary to answer them at all."
10149{_}5691{_}"He did answer but one, and that reply certainly had something of the character you suggest, sir.
10149{_}5692{_}I freely forgive him, now I understand the truth, though his apparent contempt gave me many a bitter pang at the time.
10149{_}5693{_}I saw Mr. Assheton once in public, and observed him well, for, strange as it is, I have been thought to resemble him."
10149{_}5694{_}"Why strange?
10149{_}5695{_}Jack Assheton and myself have, or rather had a strong family likeness to each other, and, though the thought is new to me, I can now easily trace this resemblance to myself.
10149{_}5696{_}It is rather an Assheton than an Effingham look, though the latter is not wanting."
10149{_}5697{_}"These explanations are very clear and satisfactory," observed Mr. Effingham, "and leave little doubt that Paul is the child of John Effingham and Mildred Warrender; but they would be beyond all cavil, were the infancy of the boy placed in an equally plain point of view, and could the reasons be known why the Warrenders abandoned him to the care of those who yielded him up to Mr.
10149{_}5698{_}Powis."
10149{_}5699{_}"I see but little obscurity in that," returned John Effingham.
10149{_}5700{_}"Paul is unquestionably the child referred to in the papers left by poor Monday, to the care of whose mother he was intrusted, until, in his fourth year, she yielded him to Mr. Powis, to get rid of trouble and expense, while she kept the annuity granted by Lady Dunluce.
10149{_}5701{_}The names appear in the concluding letters; and had we read the latter through at first, we should earlier have arrived at, the same conclusion, Could we find the man called Dowse, who appears to have instigated the fraud, and who married Mrs. Monday, the whole thing would be explained."
10149{_}5702{_}"Of this I am aware," said Paul, for he and John Effingham had perused the remainder of the Monday papers together, after the fainting fit of the latter, as soon as his strength would admit; "and Captain Truck is now searching for an old passenger of his, who I think will furnish the clue.
10149{_}5703{_}Should we get this evidence, it would settle all legal questions."
10149{_}5704{_}"Such questions will never be raised," said John Effingham, holding out his hand affectionately to his son; "you possess the marriage certificate given to your mother, and I avow myself to have been the person therein styled John Assheton.
10149{_}5705{_}This fact I have endorsed on the back of the certificate; while here is another given to me in my proper name, with the endorsement made by the clergyman that I passed by another name, at the ceremony."
10149{_}5706{_}"Such a man, cousin Jack, was unworthy of his cloth!"
10149{_}5707{_}said Eve with energy.
10149{_}5708{_}"I do not think so, my child.
10149{_}5709{_}He was innocent of the original deception; this certificate was given after the death of my wife, and might do good, whereas it could do no harm.
10149{_}5710{_}The clergyman in question is now a bishop, and is still living.
10149{_}5711{_}He may give evidence if necessary, to the legality of the marriage."
10149{_}5712{_}"And the clergyman by whom I was baptized is also alive," cried Paul, "and has never lost sight of me He was, in part, in the confidence of my mother' family, and even after I was adopted by Mr. Powis he kept me in view as one of his little Christians as he termed me.
10149{_}5713{_}It was no less a person than Dr.----."
10149{_}5714{_}"This alone would make out the connection and identity," said Mr. Effingham, "without the aid of the Monday witnesses.
10149{_}5715{_}The whole obscurity has arisen from John's change of name, and his ignorance of the fact that his wife had a child.
10149{_}5716{_}The Ducies appear to have had plausible reasons, too, for distrusting the legality of the marriage; but all is now clear, and as a large estate is concerned, we will take care that no further obscurity shall rest over the affair."
10149{_}5717{_}"The part connected with the estate is already secured," said John Effingham, looking at Eve with a smile.
10149{_}5718{_}"An American can always make a will, and one that contains but a single bequest is soon written.
10149{_}5719{_}Mine is executed, and Paul Effingham, my son by my marriage with Mildred Warrender, and lately known in the United States' Navy as Paul Powis, is duly declared my heir.
10149{_}5720{_}This will suffice for all legal purposes, though we shall have large draughts of gossip to swallow."
10149{_}5721{_}"Cousin Jack!"
10149{_}5722{_}"Daughter Eve!"
10149{_}5723{_}"Who has given cause for it?"
10149{_}5724{_}"He who commenced one of the most sacred of his earthly duties, with an unjustifiable deception.
10149{_}5725{_}The wisest way to meet it, will be to make our avowals of the relationship as open as possible."
10149{_}5726{_}"I see no necessity, John, of entering into details," said Mr. Effingham; "you were married young, and lost your wife within a year of your marriage.
10149{_}5727{_}She was a Miss Warrender, and the sister of Lady Dunluce; Paul and Ducie are declared cousins, and the former proves to be your son, of whose existence you were ignorant.
10149{_}5728{_}No one will presume to question any of us, and it really strikes me that all rational people ought to be satisfied with this simple account of the matter."
10149{_}5729{_}"Father!"
10149{_}5730{_}exclaimed Eve, with her pretty little hands raised in the attitude of surprise, "in what capital even, in what part of the world, would such a naked account appease curiosity?
10149{_}5731{_}Much less will it suffice here, where every human being, gentle or simple, learned or ignorant, refined or vulgar, fancies himself a constitutional judge of all the acts of all his fellow-creatures?"
10149{_}5732{_}"We have at least the consolation of knowing that no revelations will make the matter any worse, or any better," said Paul, "as the gossips would tell their own tale, in every case, though its falsehood were as apparent as the noon-day sun.
10149{_}5733{_}A gossip is essentially a liar, and truth is the last ingredient that is deemed necessary to his other qualifications; indeed, a well authenticated fact is a death-blow to a gossip.
10149{_}5734{_}I hope, my dear sir, you will say no more than that I am your son, a circumstance much too precious to me to be omitted."
10149{_}5735{_}John Effingham looked affectionately at the noble young man, whom he had so long esteemed and admired; and the tears forced themselves to his eyes, as he felt the supreme happiness that can alone gladden a parent's heart.
10149{_}5736{_}Chapter XXVIII.
10149{_}5737{_}"For my part, I care not: I say little; but when the time comes,   there shall be smiles."--NYM.
10149{_}5738{_}Although Paul Effingham was right, and Eve Effingham was also right, in their opinions of the art of gossiping, they both forgot one qualifying circumstance, that, arising from different causes, produces the same effect, equally in a capital and in a province.
10149{_}5739{_}In the first, marvels form a nine days' wonder from the hurry of events; in the latter, from the hurry of talking.
10149{_}5740{_}When it was announced in Templeton that Mr. John Effingham had discovered a son in Mr. Powis, as that son had conjectured, every thing but the truth was rumoured and believed, in connection with the circumstance.
10149{_}5741{_}Of course it excited a good deal of a natural and justifiable curiosity and surprise in the trained and intelligent, for John Effingham had passed for a confirmed bachelor; but they were generally content to suffer a family to have feelings and incidents that were not to be paraded before a neighbourhood.
10149{_}5742{_}Having some notions themselves of the delicacy and sanctity of the domestic affections, they were willing to respect the same sentiments in others.
10149{_}5743{_}But these few excepted, the village was in a tumult of surmises, reports, contradictions, confirmations, rebutters, and sur-rebutters, for a fortnight.
10149{_}5744{_}Several village _elegants_, whose notions of life were obtained in the valley in which they were born, and who had turned up their noses at the quiet, reserved, gentleman-like Paul, because he did not happen to suit their tastes, were disposed to resent his claim to be his father's son, as if it were an injustice done to their rights; such commentators on men and things uniformly bringing every thing down to the standard of serf.
10149{_}5745{_}Then the approaching marriages at the Wigwam had to run the gauntlet, not only of village and county criticisms, but that of the mighty Emporium itself, as it is the fashion to call the confused and tasteless collection of flaring red brick houses, marten-box churches, and colossal taverns, that stands on the island of Manhattan; the discussion of marriages being a topic of never- ending interest in that well regulated social organization, after the subjects of dollars, lots, and wines, have been duly exhausted.
10149{_}5746{_}Sir George Templemore was transformed into the Honourable Lord George Templemore, and Paul's relationship to Lady Dunluce was converted, as usual, into his being the heir apparent of a Duchy of that name; Eve's preference for a nobleman, as a matter of course, to the _aristocratical_ tastes imbibed during a residence in foreign countries; Eve, the intellectual, feminine, instructed Eve, whose European associations, while they had taught her to prize the refinement, grace, _retenue_, and tone of an advanced condition of society, had also taught her to despise its mere covering and glitter!
10149{_}5747{_}But, as there is no protection against falsehood, so is there no reasoning with ignorance.
10149{_}5748{_}A sacred few, at the head of whom were Mr.
10149{_}5749{_}Steadfast Dodge and Mrs. Widow-Bewitched Abbott, treated the matter as one of greater gravity, and as possessing an engrossing interest for the entire community.
10149{_}5750{_}"For my part, Mr.
10149{_}5751{_}Dodge," said Mrs. Abbott, in one of their frequent conferences, about a fortnight after the _eclaircissement_ of the last chapter, "I do not believe that Paul Powis is Paul Effingham at all.
10149{_}5752{_}You say that you knew him by the name of Blunt when he was a younger man?"
10149{_}5753{_}"Certainly, ma'am.
10149{_}5754{_}He passed universally by that name formerly, and it may be considered as at least extraordinary that he should have had so many aliases.
10149{_}5755{_}The truth of the matter is, Mrs. Abbott, if truth could be come at, which I always contend is very difficult in the present state of the world--"  "You never said a juster thing, Mr.
10149{_}5756{_}Dodge!"
10149{_}5757{_}interrupted the lady, feelings impetuous as hers seldom waiting for the completion of a sentence, "I never can get hold of the truth of any thing now; you may remember you insinuated that Mr. John Effingham himself was to be married to Eve, and, lo and behold!
10149{_}5758{_}it turns out to be his son!"
10149{_}5759{_}"The lady may have changed her mind, Mrs. Abbott: she gets the same estate with a younger man."
10149{_}5760{_}"She's monstrous disagreeable, and I'm sure it will be a relief to the whole village when she is married, let it be to the father, or to the son.
10149{_}5761{_}Now, do you know, Mr.
10149{_}5762{_}Dodge, I have been in a desperate taking about one thing, and that is to find that, bony fie-dy, the two old Effinghams are not actually brothers!
10149{_}5763{_}I knew that they _called_ each other cousin Jack and cousin Ned, and that Eve affected to call her uncle _cousin_ Jack, but then she has so many affectations, and the people are so foreign, that I looked upon all that as mere pretence; I said to myself a neighbourhood _ought_ to know better about a man's family than he _can_ know himself, and the neighbourhood all declared they were brothers; and yet it turns out, after all, that they are only cousins!"
10149{_}5764{_}"Yes, I do believe that, for once, the family was right in that matter, and the public mistaken."
10149{_}5765{_}"Well, I should like to know who has a better right to be mistaken than the public, Mr.
10149{_}5766{_}Dodge.
10149{_}5767{_}This is a free country, and if the people can't sometimes be wrong, what is the mighty use of their freedom?
10149{_}5768{_}We are all sinful wretches, at the best, and it is vain to look for any thing but vice from sinners."
10149{_}5769{_}"Nay, my dear Mrs. Abbott, you are too hard on yourself, for every body allows that _you_ are as exemplary as you are devoted to your religious duties."
10149{_}5770{_}"Oh!
10149{_}5771{_}I was not speaking particularly of myself, sir; I am no egotist in such things, and wish to leave my own imperfections to the charity of my friends and neighbours.
10149{_}5772{_}But, do you think, Mr.
10149{_}5773{_}Dodge, that a marriage between Paul Effingham, for so I suppose he must be-called, and Eve Effingham, will be legal?
10149{_}5774{_}Can't it be set aside, and if that should be the case, wouldn't the fortune go to the public?"
10149{_}5775{_}"It _ought_ to be so, my dear ma'am, and I trust the day is not distant when it will be so.
10149{_}5776{_}The people are beginning to understand their rights, and another century will not pass, before they will enforce them by the necessary penal statutes.
10149{_}5777{_}We have got matters so now, that a man can no longer indulge in the aristocratic and selfish desire to make a will, and, take my word for it, we shall not stop until we bring every thing to the proper standard."
10149{_}5778{_}The reader is not to suppose from his language that Mr.
10149{_}5779{_}Dodge was an agrarian, or that he looked forward to a division of property, at some future day; for, possessing in his own person already, more than what could possibly fall to an individual share, he had not the smallest desire to lessen its amount by a general division.
10149{_}5780{_}In point of fact he did not know his own meaning, except as he felt envy of all above him, in which, in truth, was to be found the whole secret of his principles, his impulses, and his doctrines.
10149{_}5781{_}Any thing that would pull down those whom education, habits, fortune, or tastes, had placed in positions more conspicuous than his own, was, in his eyes, reasonable and just--as any thing that would serve him, in person, the same ill turn, would have been tyranny and oppression.
10149{_}5782{_}The institutions of America, like every thing human, have their bad as well as their good side; and while we firmly believe in the relative superiority of the latter, as compared with other systems, we should fail of accomplishing the end set before us in this work, did we not exhibit, in strong colours, one of the most prominent consequences that has attended the entire destruction of factitious personal distinctions in the country, which has certainly aided in bringing out in bolder relief than common, the prevalent disposition in man to covet that which is the possession of another, and to decry merits that are unattainable.
10149{_}5783{_}"Well, I rejoice to hear this," returned Mrs. Abbott, whose principles were of the same loose school as those of her companion, "for I think no one should have rights but those who have experienced religion, if you would keep vital religion in a country.
10149{_}5784{_}There goes that old sea-lion, Truck, and his fishing associate, the commodore, with their lines and poles, as usual, Mr.
10149{_}5785{_}Dodge; I beg you will call to them, for I long to hear what the first can have to say about his beloved Effinghams, now?"
10149{_}5786{_}Mr.
10149{_}5787{_}Dodge complied, and the navigator of the ocean and the navigator of the lake, were soon seated in Mrs. Abbott's little parlour, which might be styled the focus of gossip, near those who were so lately its sole occupants.
10149{_}5788{_}"This is wonderful news, gentlemen," commenced Mrs. Abbott, as soon as the bustle of the entrance had subsided.
10149{_}5789{_}"Mr. Powis is Mr. Effingham, and it seems that Miss Effingham is to become Mrs. Effingham.
10149{_}5790{_}Miracles will never cease, and I look upon this as one of the most surprising of my time."
10149{_}5791{_}"Just so, ma'am," said the commodore, winking his eye, and giving the usual flourish with a hand; "your time has not been that of a day neither, and Mr. Powis has reason to rejoice that he is the hero of such a history.
10149{_}5792{_}For my part, I could not have been more astonished, were I to bring up the sogdollager with a trout-hook, having a cheese paring for the bait."
10149{_}5793{_}"I understand," continued the lady, "that there are doubts after all, whether this miracle be really a true miracle.
10149{_}5794{_}It is hinted that Mr. Powis is neither Mr. Effingham nor Mr. Powis, but that he is actually a Mr. Blunt.
10149{_}5795{_}Do you happen to know any thing of the matter, Captain Truck?"
10149{_}5796{_}"I have been introduced to him, ma'am, by all three names, and I consider him as an acquaintance in each character.
10149{_}5797{_}I can assure you, moreover, that he is A, No.
10149{_}5798{_}1, on whichever tack you take him; a man who carries a weather helm in the midst of his enemies."
10149{_}5799{_}"Well, I do not consider it a very great recommendation for one to have enemies, at all.
10149{_}5800{_}Now, I dare say, Mr.
10149{_}5801{_}Dodge, _you_ have not an enemy on earth!"
10149{_}5802{_}"I should be sorry to think that I had, Mrs. Abbott.
10149{_}5803{_}I am every man's friend, particularly the poor man's friend, and I should suppose that every man _ought_ to be my friend.
10149{_}5804{_}I hold the whole human family to be brethren, and that they ought to live together as such."
10149{_}5805{_}"Very true, sir; quite true--we _are_ all sinners, and ought to look favourably on each other's failings.
10149{_}5806{_}It is no business of mine-- I say it is no business of ours, Mr.
10149{_}5807{_}Dodge, who Miss Eve Effingham marries; but were she _my_ daughter, I do think I should not like her to have three family names, and to keep her own in the bargain!"
10149{_}5808{_}"The Effinghams hold their heads very much up, though it is not easy to see _why_; but so they do, and the more names the better, perhaps, for such people," returned the editor.
10149{_}5809{_}"For my part, I treat them with condescension, just as I do every body else; for it is a rule with me, Captain Truck, to make use of the same deportment to a king on his throne, as I would to a beggar in the street."
10149{_}5810{_}"Merely to show that you do not feel yourself to be above your betters.
10149{_}5811{_}We have many such philosophers in this country."
10149{_}5812{_}"Just so," said the commodore.
10149{_}5813{_}"I wish I knew," resumed Mrs. Abbott; for there existed in her head, as well as in that of Mr.
10149{_}5814{_}Dodge, such a total confusion on the subject of deportment, that neither saw nor felt the cool sarcasm of the old sailor; "I wish I knew, now, whether Eve Effingham has really been regenerated!
10149{_}5815{_}What is your opinion, commodore?"
10149{_}5816{_}"Re-what, ma'am," said the commodore, who was not conscious of ever having heard the word before; for, in his Sabbaths on the water, where he often worshipped God devoutly in his heart, the language of the professedly pious was never heard; "I can only say she is as pretty a skiff as floats, but I can tell you nothing about resuscitation--indeed, I never heard of her having been drowned."
10149{_}5817{_}"Ah, Mrs. Abbott, the very best friends of the Effinghams will not maintain that they are pious.
10149{_}5818{_}I do not wish to be invidious, or to say unneighbourly things; but were I upon oath, I could testify to a great many things, which would unqualifiedly show, that none of them have ever experienced."
10149{_}5819{_}"Now, Mr.
10149{_}5820{_}Dodge, you know how much I dislike scandal," the widow- bewitched cried affectedly, "and I cannot tolerate such a sweeping charge.
10149{_}5821{_}I insist on the proofs of what you say, in which, no doubt, these gentlemen will join me."
10149{_}5822{_}By proofs, Mrs. Abbott meant allegations.
10149{_}5823{_}"Well, ma'am, since you insist on my _proving_ what I have said, you shall not be disappointed.
10149{_}5824{_}In the first place, then, they _read_ their family prayers out of a book."
10149{_}5825{_}"Ay, ay," put in the captain; "but that merely shows they have some education; it is done every where."
10149{_}5826{_}"Your pardon, sir; no people but the Catholics and the church people commit this impiety.
10149{_}5827{_}The idea of _reading_ to the Deity, Mrs. Abbott, is particularly shocking to a pious soul."
10149{_}5828{_}"As if the Lord stood in need of letters!
10149{_}5829{_}_That_ is very bad, I allow; for at _family_ prayers, a form becomes mockery."
10149{_}5830{_}"Yes, ma'am; but what do you think of cards?"
10149{_}5831{_}"Cards!"
10149{_}5832{_}exclaimed Mrs. Abbott, holding up her pious hands, in holy horror.
10149{_}5833{_}"Even so; foul paste-board, marked with kings and queens," said the captain.
10149{_}5834{_}Why this is worse than a common sin, being unqualifiedly anti-republican."
10149{_}5835{_}"I confess I did not expect-this!
10149{_}5836{_}I had heard that Eve Effingham was guilty of indiscretions, but I did not think she was so lost to virtue, as to touch a card.
10149{_}5837{_}Oh!
10149{_}5838{_}Eve Effingham; Eve Effingham, for what is your poor diseased soul destined!"
10149{_}5839{_}"She dances, too, I suppose you know that," continued Mr.
10149{_}5840{_}Dodge, who finding his popularity a little on the wane, had joined the meeting himself, a few weeks before, and who did not fail to manifest the zeal of a new convert.
10149{_}5841{_}"Dances!"
10149{_}5842{_}repeated Mrs. Abbott, in holy horror.
10149{_}5843{_}"Real fi diddle de di!"
10149{_}5844{_}echoed Captain Truck.
10149{_}5845{_}"Just so," put in the commodore; "I have seen it with my own eyes.
10149{_}5846{_}But, Mrs. Abbott, I feel bound to tell you that your own daughter--"  "Biansy-Alzumy-Anne!"
10149{_}5847{_}exclaimed the mother in alarm.
10149{_}5848{_}"Just so; my-aunty-all-suit-me-anne, if that is her name.
10149{_}5849{_}Do you know, ma'am, that I have seen your own blessed daughter, my-aunty- Anne, do a worse thing, even, than dancing!"
10149{_}5850{_}"Commodore, you are awful!
10149{_}5851{_}What _could_ a child of mine do that is worse than dancing?"
10149{_}5852{_}"Why, ma'am, if you _will_ hear all, it is my duty to tell you.
10149{_}5853{_}I saw aunty-Anne (the commodore was really ignorant of the girl's name) jump a skipping-rope, yesterday morning, between the hours of seven and eight.
10149{_}5854{_}As I hope ever to see the sogdollager, again, ma'am, I did!"
10149{_}5855{_}"And do you this as bad as dancing?"
10149{_}5856{_}"Much worse, ma'am, to my notion.
10149{_}5857{_}It is jumping about without music, and without any grace, either, particularly as it was performed by my-aunty-Anne."
10149{_}5858{_}"You are given to light jokes.
10149{_}5859{_}Jumping the skipping-rope is not forbidden in the bible."
10149{_}5860{_}"Just so; nor is dancing, if I know any thing about it; nor, for that matter, cards."
10149{_}5861{_}"But waste of time is; a sinful waste of time; and evil-passions, and all unrighteousness."
10149{_}5862{_}"Just so.
10149{_}5863{_}My-aunty-Anne was going to the pump for water--I dare say you sent her--and she was misspending her time; and as for evil passions, she did not enjoy the hop, until she and your neighbour's daughter had pulled each other's hair for the rope, as if they had been two she-dragons.
10149{_}5864{_}Take my word for it, ma'am, it wanted for nothing to make it sin of the purest water, but a cracked fiddle."
10149{_}5865{_}While the commodore was holding Mrs. Abbott at bay, in this manner, Captain Truck, who had given him a wink to that effect, was employed in playing off a practical joke at the expense of the widow.
10149{_}5866{_}It was one of the standing amusements of these worthies, who had gotten to be sworn friends and constant associates, after they had caught as many fish as they wished, to retire to the favourite spring, light, the one his cigar, the other his pipe, mix their grog, and then relieve their ennui, when tired of discussing men and things, by playing cards on a particular stump.
10149{_}5867{_}Now, it happens that the captain had the identical pack which had been used on all such occasions in his pocket, as was evident in the fact that the cards were nearly as distinctly marked on their backs, as on their faces.
10149{_}5868{_}These cards he showed secretly to his companion, and when the attention of Mrs. Abbott was altogether engaged in expecting the terrible announcement of her daughter's errors, the captain slipped them, kings, queens and knaves, high, low, jack and the game, without regard to rank, into the lady's work-basket.
10149{_}5869{_}As soon as this feat was successfully performed, a sign was given to the commodore that the conspiracy was effected, and that disputant in theology gradually began to give ground, while he continued to maintain that jumping the rope was a sin, though it might be one of a nominal class.
10149{_}5870{_}There is little doubt, had he possessed a smattering of phrases, a greater command of biblical learning, and more zeal, that the fisherman might have established a new shade of the Christian faith; for, while mankind still persevere in disregarding the plainest mandates of God, as respects humility, the charities, and obedience, nothing seems to afford them more delight than to add to the catalogue of the offences against his divine supremacy.
10149{_}5871{_}It was perhaps lucky for the commodore, who was capital at casting a pickerel line, but who usually settled his polemics with the fist, when hard pushed, that Captain Truck found leisure to come to the rescue.
10149{_}5872{_}"I'm amazed, ma'am," said the honest packet-master, "that a woman of your sanctity should deny that jumping the rope is a sin, for I hold that point to have been settled by all our people, these fifty years.
10149{_}5873{_}You will admit that the rope cannot be well-jumped without levity."
10149{_}5874{_}"Levity, Captain Truck!
10149{_}5875{_}I hope you do not insinuate that a daughter of mine discovers levity?"
10149{_}5876{_}"Certainly, ma'am; she is called the best rope jumper in the village, I hear; and levity, or lightness of carriage, is the great requisite for skill in the art.
10149{_}5877{_}Then there are 'vain repetitions' in doing the same thing over and over so often, and 'vain repetitions' are forbidden even in our prayers.
10149{_}5878{_}I can call both father and mother to testify to that fact."
10149{_}5879{_}"Well, this is news to me!
10149{_}5880{_}I must speak to the minister about it."
10149{_}5881{_}"Of the two, the skipping-rope is rather more sinful than dancing, for the music makes the latter easy; whereas, one has to force the spirit to enter into the other.
10149{_}5882{_}Commodore, our hour has come, and we must make sail.
10149{_}5883{_}May I ask the favour, Mrs. Abbott, of a bit of thread to fasten this hook afresh?"
10149{_}5884{_}The widow-bewitched turned to her basket, and raising a piece of calico, to look for the thread "high, low, jack and the game," stared her in the face.
10149{_}5885{_}When she bent her eyes towards her guests, she perceived all three gazing at the cards, with as much apparent surprise and curiosity, as if two of them knew nothing of their history.
10149{_}5886{_}"Awful!"
10149{_}5887{_}exclaimed Mrs. Abbott, shaking both hands,--"awful--awful-- awful!
10149{_}5888{_}The powers of darkness have been at work here!"
10149{_}5889{_}"They seem to have been pretty much occupied, too," observed the captain, "for a better thumbed pack I never yet found in the forecastle of a ship."
10149{_}5890{_}"Awful--awful--awful!--This is equal to the forty days in the wilderness, Mr.
10149{_}5891{_}Dodge."
10149{_}5892{_}"It is a trying cross, ma'am."
10149{_}5893{_}"To my notion, now," said the captain, "those cards are not worse than the skipping-rope, though I allow that they might have been cleaner."
10149{_}5894{_}But Mrs. Abbott was not disposed to view the matter so lightly.
10149{_}5895{_}She saw the hand of the devil in the affair, and fancied it was a new trial offered to her widowed condition.
10149{_}5896{_}"Are these actually cards!"
10149{_}5897{_}she cried, like one who distrusted the evidence of her senses.
10149{_}5898{_}"Just so, ma'am," kindly answered the commodore; "This is the ace of spades, a famous fellow to hold when you have the lead; and this is the Jack, which counts one, you know, when spades are trumps.
10149{_}5899{_}I never saw a more thorough-working pack in my life."
10149{_}5900{_}"Or a more thoroughly worked pack," added the captain, in a condoling manner.
10149{_}5901{_}"Well, we are not all perfect, and I hope Mrs. Abbott will cheer up and look at this matter in a gayer point of view.
10149{_}5902{_}For myself I hold that a skipping-rope is worse than the Jack of spades, Sundays or week days.
10149{_}5903{_}Commodore, we shall see no pickerel to-day, unless we tear ourselves from this good company."
10149{_}5904{_}Here the two wags took their leave, and retreated to the skiff; the captain, who foresaw an occasion to use them, considerately offering to relieve Mrs. Abbott from the presence of the odious cards, intimating that he would conscientiously see them fairly sunk in the deepest part of the lake.
10149{_}5905{_}When the two worthies were at a reasonable distance from the shore, the commodore suddenly ceased rowing, made a flourish with his hand, and incontinently began to laugh, as if his mirth had suddenly broken through all restraint.
10149{_}5906{_}Captain Truck, who had been lighting a cigar, commenced smoking, and, seldom indulging in boisterous merriment, he responded with his eyes, shaking his head from time to time, with great satisfaction, as thoughts more ludicrous than common came over his imagination.
10149{_}5907{_}"Harkee, commodore," he said, blowing the smoke upward, and watching it with his eye until it floated away in a little cloud, "neither of us is a chicken.
10149{_}5908{_}You have studied life on the fresh water, and I have studied life on the salt.
10149{_}5909{_}I do not say which produces the best scholars, but I know that both make better Christians than the jack- screw system."
10149{_}5910{_}"Just so.
10149{_}5911{_}I tell them in the village that little is gained in the end by following the blind; that is my doctrine, sir."
10149{_}5912{_}"And a very good doctrine it would prove, I make no doubt, were you to enter into it a little more fully--"  "Well, sir, I can explain--"  "Not another syllable is necessary.
10149{_}5913{_}I know what you mean as well as if I said it myself, and, moreover, short sermons are always the best.
10149{_}5914{_}You mean that a pilot ought to know where he is steering, which is perfectly sound doctrine.
10149{_}5915{_}My own experience tells me, that if you press a sturgeon's nose with your foot, it will spring up as soon as it is loosened.
10149{_}5916{_}Now the jack-screw will heave a great strain, no doubt; but the moment it is let up, down comes all that rests on it, again.
10149{_}5917{_}This Mr.
10149{_}5918{_}Dodge, I suppose you know, has been a passenger with me once or twice?"
10149{_}5919{_}"I have heard as much--they say he was tigerish in the fight with the niggers--quite an out-and-outer."
10149{_}5920{_}"Ay, I hear he tells some such story himself; but harkee, commodore, I wish to do justice to all men, and I find there is very little of it inland, hereaway.
10149{_}5921{_}The hero of that day is about to marry your beautiful Miss Effingham; other men did their duty too, as, for instance, was the case with Mr. John Effingham; but Paul Blunt-Powis- Effingham finished the job.
10149{_}5922{_}As for Mr.
10149{_}5923{_}Steadfast Dodge, sir, I say nothing, unless it be to add that he was nowhere near _me_ in that transaction; and if any man felt like an alligator in Lent, on that occasion, it was your humble servant."
10149{_}5924{_}"Which means that he was not nigh the enemy, I'll swear before a magistrate."
10149{_}5925{_}"And no fear of perjury.
10149{_}5926{_}Any one who saw Mr. John Effingham and Mr. Powis on that day, might have sworn that they were father and son, and any one who _did not see_ Mr.
10149{_}5927{_}Dodge might have said at once, that he did not belong to their family.
10149{_}5928{_}That is all, sir; I never disparage a passenger, and, therefore, shall say no more than merely to add, that Mr.
10149{_}5929{_}Dodge is no warrior."
10149{_}5930{_}"They say he has experienced religion, lately, as they call it."
10149{_}5931{_}"It is high time, sir, for he had experienced sin quite long enough, according to my notion.
10149{_}5932{_}I hear that the man goes up and down the country disparaging those whose shoe-ties he is unworthy to unloose, and that he has published some letters in his journal, that are as false as his heart; but let him beware, lest the world should see, some rainy day, an extract from a certain log-book belonging to a ship called the Montauk.
10149{_}5933{_}I am rejoiced at this marriage after all, commodore, or marriages rather, for I understand that Mr. Paul Effingham and Sir George Templemore intend to make a double bowline of it to-morrow morning.
10149{_}5934{_}All is arranged, and as soon as my eyes have witnessed that blessed sight, I shall trip for New-York again."
10149{_}5935{_}"It is clearly made out then, that the young gentleman is Mr. John Effingham's son?"
10149{_}5936{_}"As clear as the north-star in a bright night.
10149{_}5937{_}The fellow who spoke to me at the Fun of Fire has put us in a way to remove the last doubt, if there were any doubt.
10149{_}5938{_}Mr. Effingham himself, who is so cool-headed and cautious, says there is now sufficient proof to make it good in any court in America, That point may be set down as settled, and, for my part, I rejoice it is so, since Mr. John Effingham has so long passed for an old bachelor, that it is a credit to the corps to find one of them the father of so noble a son."
10149{_}5939{_}Here the commodore dropped his anchor, and the two friends began to fish.
10149{_}5940{_}For an hour neither talked much, but having obtained the necessary stock of perch, they landed at the favourite spring, and prepared a fry.
10149{_}5941{_}While seated on the grass, alternating be tween the potations of punch, and the mastication of fish, these worthies again renewed the dialogue in their usual discursive, philosophical, and sentimental manner.
10149{_}5942{_}"We are citizens of a surprisingly great country, commodore," commenced Mr. Truck, after one of his heaviest draughts; "every body says it, from Maine to Florida, and what every body says must be true."
10149{_}5943{_}"Just so, sir.
10149{_}5944{_}I sometimes wonder how so great a country ever came to produce so little a man as myself."
10149{_}5945{_}"A good cow may have a bad calf, and that explains the matter.
10149{_}5946{_}Have you many as virtuous and pious women in this part of the world, as Mrs.
10149{_}5947{_}Abbott?"
10149{_}5948{_}"The hills and valleys are filled with them.
10149{_}5949{_}You mean persons who have got so much religion that they have no room for any thing else?"
10149{_}5950{_}"I shall mourn to my dying day, that you were not brought up to the sea!
10149{_}5951{_}If you discover so much of the right material on fresh-water, what would you have been on salt?
10149{_}5952{_}The people who suck in nutriment from a brain and a conscience like those of Mr.
10149{_}5953{_}Dodge, too, commodore, must get, in time, to be surprisingly clear-sighted."
10149{_}5954{_}"Just so; his readers soon overreach themselves.
10149{_}5955{_}But it's of no great consequence, sir; the people of this part of the world keep nothing long enough to do much good, or much harm."
10149{_}5956{_}"Fond of change, ha?"
10149{_}5957{_}"Like unlucky fishermen, always ready to shift the ground.
10149{_}5958{_}I don't believe, sir, that in all this region you can find a dozen graves of sons, that lie near their fathers.
10149{_}5959{_}Every body seems to have a mortal aversion to stability,"  "It is hard to love such a country, commodore!"
10149{_}5960{_}"Sir, I never try to love it.
10149{_}5961{_}God has given me a pretty sheet of water, that suits my fancy and wants, a beautiful sky, fine green mountains, and I am satisfied.
10149{_}5962{_}One may love God, in such a temple, though he love nothing else."
10149{_}5963{_}"Well, I suppose if you love nothing, nothing loves you, and no injustice is done."
10149{_}5964{_}"Just, so, sir.
10149{_}5965{_}Self has got to be the idol, though in the general scramble a man is sometimes puzzled to know whether he is himself, or one of the neighbours."
10149{_}5966{_}"I wish I knew your political sentiments, commodore; you have been communicative on all subjects but that, and I have taken up the notion that you are a true philosopher."
10149{_}5967{_}"I hold myself to be but a babe in swaddling-clothes compared to yourself, sir; but such as my poor opinions are, you are welcome to them.
10149{_}5968{_}In the first place, then, sir, I have lived long enough on this water to know that every man is a lover of liberty in his own person, and that he has a secret distaste for it in the persons of other people.
10149{_}5969{_}Then, sir, I have got to understand that patriotism means bread and cheese, and that opposition is every man for himself."
10149{_}5970{_}"If the truth were known, I believe, commodore, you have buoyed out the channel!"
10149{_}5971{_}"Just so.
10149{_}5972{_}After being pulled about by the salt of the land, and using my freeman's privileges at their command, until I got tired of so much liberty, sir, I have resigned, and retired to private life, doing most of my own thinking out here on the Otsego-Water, like a poor slave as I am."
10149{_}5973{_}"You ought to be chosen the next President!"
10149{_}5974{_}"I owe my present emancipation, sir, to the sogdollager.
10149{_}5975{_}I first began to reason about such a man as this Mr.
10149{_}5976{_}Dodge, who has thrust himself and his ignorance together into the village, lately, as an expounder of truth, and a ray of light to the blind.
10149{_}5977{_}Well, sir, I said to myself, if this man be the man I know him to be as a man, can he be any thing better as an editor?"
10149{_}5978{_}"That was a home question put to yourself, commodore; how did you answer it?"
10149{_}5979{_}"The answer was satisfactory, sir, to myself, whatever it might be to other people.
10149{_}5980{_}I stopped his paper, and set up for myself.
10149{_}5981{_}Just about that time the sogdollager nibbled, and instead of trying to be a great man, over the shoulders of the patriots and sages of the land, I endeavoured to immortalize myself by hooking him.
10149{_}5982{_}I go to the elections now, for that I feel to be a duty, but instead of allowing a man like this Mr.
10149{_}5983{_}Dodge to tell me how to vote, I vote for the man in public that I would trust in private."
10149{_}5984{_}"Excellent!
10149{_}5985{_}I honour you more and more every minute I pass in your society.
10149{_}5986{_}We will now drink to the future happiness of those who will become brides and bridegrooms to-morrow.
10149{_}5987{_}If all men were as philosophical and as learned as you, commodore, the human race would be in a fairer way than they are to-day."
10149{_}5988{_}"Just so; I drink to them with all my heart.
10149{_}5989{_}Is it not surprising, sir, that people like Mrs. Abbott and Mr.
10149{_}5990{_}Dodge should have it in their power to injure such as those whose happiness we have just had the honour of commemorating in advance?"
10149{_}5991{_}"Why, commodore, a fly may bite an elephant, if he can find a weak spot in his hide.
10149{_}5992{_}I do not altogether understand the history of the marriage of John Effingham, myself; but we see the issue of it has been a fine son.
10149{_}5993{_}Now I hold that when a man fairly marries, he is bound to own it, the same as any other crime; for he owes it to those who have not been as guilty as himself, to show the world that he no longer belongs to them."
10149{_}5994{_}"Just so; but we have flies in this part of the world that will bite through the toughest hide."
10149{_}5995{_}"That comes from there being no quarter-deck in your social ship, commodore.
10149{_}5996{_}Now aboard of a well-regulated packet, all the thinking is done aft; they who are desirous of knowing whereabouts the vessel is, being compelled to wait till the observations are taken, or to sit down in their ignorance.
10149{_}5997{_}The whole difficulty comes from the fact that sensible people live so far apart in this quarter of the world, that fools have more room than should fall to their share.
10149{_}5998{_}You understand me, commodore?"
10149{_}5999{_}"Just so," said the commodore, laughing, and winking.
10149{_}6000{_}"Well, it is fortunate that there are some people who are not quite as weak-minded as some other people.
10149{_}6001{_}I take it, Captain Truck, that you will be present at the wedding?"
10149{_}6002{_}The captain now winked in his turn, looked around him to make sure no one was listening, and laying a finger on his nose, he answered, in a much lower key than was usual for him--  "You can keep a secret, I know, commodore.
10149{_}6003{_}Now what I have to say is not to be told to Mrs. Abbott, in order that it may be repeated and multiplied, but is to be kept as snug as your bait, in the bait-box."
10149{_}6004{_}"You know your man, sir."
10149{_}6005{_}"Well then, about ten minutes before the clock strikes nine, to- morrow morning, do you slip into the gallery of New St. Paul's, and you shall see beauty and modesty, when 'unadorned, adorned the most.'
10149{_}6006{_}You comprehend?"
10149{_}6007{_}"Just so," and the hand was flourished even more than usual.
10149{_}6008{_}"It does not become us bachelors to be too lenient to matrimony, but I should be an unhappy man, were I not to witness the marriage of Paul Powis to Eve Effingham."
10149{_}6009{_}Here both the worthies, "freshened the nip," as Captain Truck called it, and then the conversation soon got to be too philosophical and contemplative for this unpretending record of events and ideas.
10149{_}6010{_}Chapter XXIX    "Then plainly know, my heart's dear love is set On the fair   daughter of rich Capulet; As mine on hers, so hers is set on mine;   And all combined, save what thou must confine By holy marriage."
10149{_}6011{_}ROMEO AND JULIET.
10149{_}6012{_}The morning chosen for the nuptials of Eve and Grace arrived, and all the inmates of the Wigwam were early afoot, though the utmost care had been taken to prevent the intelligence of the approaching ceremony from getting into the village.
10149{_}6013{_}They little knew, however, how closely they were watched; the mean artifices that were resorted to by some who called themselves their neighbours, to tamper with servants, to obtain food for conjecture, and to justify to themselves their exaggerations, falsehoods, and frauds.
10149{_}6014{_}The news did leak out, as will presently be seen, and through a channel that may cause the reader, who is unacquainted with some of the peculiarities of American life, a little surprise.
10149{_}6015{_}We have frequently alluded to Annette, the _femme de chambre_ that had followed Eve from Europe, although we have had no occasion to dwell on her character, which was that of a woman of her class, as they are well known to exist in France.
10149{_}6016{_}Annette was young, had bright, sparkling black eyes, was well made, and had the usual tournure and manner of a Parisian grisette.
10149{_}6017{_}As it is the besetting weakness of all provincial habits to mistake graces for grace, flourishes for elegance, and exaggeration for merit, Annette soon acquired a reputation in her circle, as a woman of more than usual claims to distinction.
10149{_}6018{_}Her attire was in the height of the fashion, being of Eve's cast-off clothes, and of the best materials, and attire is also a point that is not without its influence on those who are unaccustomed to the world.
10149{_}6019{_}As the double ceremony was to take place before breakfast, Annette was early employed about the person of her young mistress, adorning it in the bridal robes.
10149{_}6020{_}While she worked at her usual employment, the attendant appeared unusually agitated, and several times pins were badly pointed, and new arrangements had to supersede or to supply the deficiencies of her mistakes.
10149{_}6021{_}Eve was always a model of patience, and she bore with these little oversights with a quiet that would have given Paul an additional pledge of her admirable self-command, as well as of a sweetness of temper that, in truth, raised her almost above the commoner feelings of mortality.
10149{_}6022{_}"_Vous etes un peu agitee, ce matin, ma bonne Annette_," she merely observed, when her maid had committed a blunder more material than common.
10149{_}6023{_}"_J'espere que Mademoiselle a ete contente de moi, jusqu' a present_," returned Annette, vexed with her own awkwardness, and speaking in the manner in which it is usual to announce an intention to quit a service.
10149{_}6024{_}"Certainly, Annette, you have conducted yourself well, and are very expert in your _metier_.
10149{_}6025{_}But why do you ask this question, just at this moment?"
10149{_}6026{_}"_Parceque_--because--with mademoiselle's permission, I intended to ask for my _conge_."
10149{_}6027{_}"_Conge_!
10149{_}6028{_}Do you think of quitting me, Annette?"
10149{_}6029{_}"It would make me happier than anything else to die in the service of mademoiselle, but we are all subject to our destiny"--the conversation was in French--"and mine compels me to cease my services as a _femme de chambre_."
10149{_}6030{_}"This is a sudden, and for one in a strange country, an extraordinary resolution.
10149{_}6031{_}May I ask, Annette, what you propose to do?"
10149{_}6032{_}Here, the woman gave herself certain airs, endeavoured to blush, did look at the carpet with a studied modesty that might have deceived one who did not know the genus, and announced her intention to get married, too, at the end of the present month.
10149{_}6033{_}"Married!"
10149{_}6034{_}repeated Eve--"surely not to old Pierre, Annette!"
10149{_}6035{_}"Pierre, Mademoiselle!
10149{_}6036{_}I shall not condescend to look at Pierre.
10149{_}6037{_}_Je vais me marier avec un avocat_."
10149{_}6038{_}"_Un avocat_!"
10149{_}6039{_}"_Oui, Mademoiselle_.
10149{_}6040{_}I will marry myself with Monsieur Aristabule Bragg, if Mademoiselle shall permit."
10149{_}6041{_}Eve was perfectly mute with astonishment, notwithstanding the proofs she had often seen of the wide range that the ambition of an American of a certain class allows itself.
10149{_}6042{_}Of course, she remembered the conversation on the Point, and it would not have been in nature, had not a mistress who had been so lately wooed, felt some surprise at finding her discarded suitor so soon seeking consolation in the smiles of her own maid.
10149{_}6043{_}Still her surprise was less than that which the reader will probably experience at this announcement; for, as has just been said, she had seen too much of the active and pliant enterprise of the lover, to feel much wonder at any of his moral _tours de force_.
10149{_}6044{_}Even Eve, however, was not perfectly acquainted with the views and policy that had led Aristabulus to seek this consummation to his matrimonial schemes, which must be explained explicitly, in order that they may be properly understood.
10149{_}6045{_}Mr. Bragg had no notion of any distinctions in the world, beyond those which came from money, and political success.
10149{_}6046{_}For the first he had a practical deference that was as profound as his wishes for its enjoyments; and for the last he felt precisely the sort of reverence, that one educated under a feudal system, would feel for a feudal lord.
10149{_}6047{_}The first, after several unsuccessful efforts, he had found unattainable by means of matrimony, and he turned his thoughts towards Annette, whom he had for some months held in reserve, in the event of his failing with Eve and Grace, for on both these heiresses had he entertained designs, as a _pis aller_.
10149{_}6048{_}Annette was a dress-maker of approved taste, her person was sufficiently attractive, her broken English gave piquancy to thoughts of no great depth, she was of a suitable age, and he had made her proposals and been accepted, as soon as it was ascertained that Eve and Grace were irretrievably lost to him.
10149{_}6049{_}Of course, the Parisienne did not hesitate an instant about becoming the wife of _un avocat;_ for, agreeably to her habits, matrimony was a legitimate means of bettering her condition in life.
10149{_}6050{_}The plan was soon arranged.
10149{_}6051{_}They were to be married as soon as Annette's month's notice had expired, and then they were to emigrate to the far west, where Mr. Bragg proposed to practise law, or keep school, or to go to Congress, or to turn trader, or to saw lumber, or, in short, to turn his hand to any thing that offered; while Annette was to help along with the _menage_, by making dresses, and teaching French; the latter occupation promising to be somewhat peripatetic, the population being scattered, and few of the dwellers in the interior deeming it necessary to take more than a quarter's instruction in any of the higher branches of education; the object being to _study_, as it is called, and not to _know_.
10149{_}6052{_}Aristabulus, who was filled with _go-aheadism_, would have shortened the delay, but this Annette positively resisted; her _esprit de corps_ as a servant, and all her notions of justice, repudiating the notion that the connexion which had existed so long between Eve and herself, was to be cut off at a moment's warning.
10149{_}6053{_}So diametrically were the ideas of the _fiances_ opposed to each other, on this point, that at one time it threatened a rupture, Mr. Bragg asserting the natural independence of man to a degree that would have rendered him independent of all obligations that were not effectually enacted by the law, and Annette maintaining the dignity of a European _femme de chambre,_ whose sense of propriety demanded that she should not quit her place without giving a month's warning.
10149{_}6054{_}The affair was happily decided by Aristabulus's receiving a commission to tend a store, in the absence of its owner; Mr. Effingham, on a hint from his daughter, having profited by the annual expiration of the engagement, to bring their connexion to an end.
10149{_}6055{_}This termination to the passion of Mr. Bragg would have afforded Eve a good deal of amusement at any other moment; but a bride cannot be expected to give too much of her attention to the felicity and prospects of those who have no natural or acquired claims to her affection.
10149{_}6056{_}The cousins met, attired for the ceremony, in Mr. Effingham's room, where he soon came in person, to lead them to the drawing-room.
10149{_}6057{_}It is seldom that two more lovely young women are brought together on similar occasions.
10149{_}6058{_}As Mr. Effingham stood between them, holding a hand of each, his moistened eyes turned from one to the other in honest pride, and in an admiration that even his tenderness could not restrain.
10149{_}6059{_}The _toilettes_ were as simple as the marriage ceremony will permit; for it was intended that there should be no unnecessary parade; and, perhaps, the delicate beauty of each of the brides was rendered the more attractive by this simplicity, as it has often been justly remarked, that the fair of this country are more winning in dress of a less conventional character, than when in the elaborate and regulated attire of ceremonies.
10149{_}6060{_}As might have been expected, there was most of soul and feeling in Eve's countenance, though Grace wore an air of charming modesty and nature.
10149{_}6061{_}Both were unaffected, simple and graceful, and we may add that both trembled as Mr. Effingham took their hands.
10149{_}6062{_}"This is a pleasing and yet a painful hour," said that kind and excellent man; "one in which I gain a son, and lose a daughter."
10149{_}6063{_}"And _I_, dearest uncle," exclaimed Grace, whose feelings trembled on her eye-lids, like the dew ready to drop from the leaf, "have _I_ no connexion with your feelings?"
10149{_}6064{_}"You are the daughter that I lose, my child, for Eve will still remain with me.
10149{_}6065{_}But Templemore has promised to be grateful, and I will trust his word."
10149{_}6066{_}Mr. Effingham then embraced with fervour both the charming young women, who stood apparelled for the most important event of their lives, lovely in their youth, beauty, innocence, and modesty; and taking an arm of each, he led them below.
10149{_}6067{_}John Effingham, the two bridegrooms, Captain Ducie, Mr. and Mrs. Bloomfield, Mrs. Hawker, Captain Truck, Mademoiselle Viefville, Annette, and Ann Sidley, were all assembled in the drawing-room, ready to receive them; and as soon as shawls were thrown around Eve and Grace, in order to conceal the wedding dresses, the whole party proceeded to the church.
10149{_}6068{_}The distance between the Wigwam and New St. Paul's was very trifling, the solemn pines of the church-yard blending, from many points, with the gayer trees in the grounds of the former; and as the buildings in this part of the village were few, the whole of the bridal train entered the tower, unobserved by the eyes of the curious.
10149{_}6069{_}The clergyman was waiting in the chancel, and as each of the young men led the object of his choice immediately to the altar, the double ceremony began without delay.
10149{_}6070{_}At this instant Mr. Aristabulus Dodge and Mrs. Abbot advanced from the rear of the gallery, and coolly took their seats in its front.
10149{_}6071{_}Neither belonged to this particular church, though, having discovered that the marriages were to take place that morning by means of Annette, they had no scruples on the score of delicacy about thrusting themselves forward on the occasion; for, to the latest moment, that publicity-principle which appeared to be interwoven with their very natures, induced them to think that nothing was so sacred as to be placed beyond the reach of curiosity.
10149{_}6072{_}They entered the church, because the church they held to be a public place, precisely on the principle that others of their class conceive if a gate be blown open by accident, it removes all the moral defences against trespassers, as it removes the physical.
10149{_}6073{_}The solemn language of the prayers and vows proceeded none the less for the presence of these unwelcome intruders; for, at that grave moment, all other thoughts were hushed in those that more properly belonged to the scene.
10149{_}6074{_}When the clergyman made the usual appeal to know if any man could give a reason why those who stood before him should not be united in holy wedlock, Mrs. Abbott nudged Mr.
10149{_}6075{_}Dodge, and, in the fulness of her discontent, eagerly inquired in a whisper, if it were not possible to raise some valid objection.
10149{_}6076{_}Could she have had her pious wish, the simple, unpretending, meek, and _church_-going Eve, should never be married.
10149{_}6077{_}But the editor was not a man to act openly in any thing, his particular province lying in insinuations and innuendoes.
10149{_}6078{_}As a hint would not now be available, he determined to postpone his revenge to a future day.
10149{_}6079{_}We say revenge, for Steadfast was of the class that consider any happiness, or advantage, in which they are not ample participators, wrongs done to themselves.
10149{_}6080{_}That is a wise regulation of the church, which makes the marriage ceremony brief, for the intensity of the feelings it often creates would frequently become too powerful to be suppressed, were it unnecessarily prolonged.
10149{_}6081{_}Mr. Effingham gave away both the brides, the one in the quality of parent, the other in that of guardian, and neither of the bridegrooms got the ring on the wrong finger.
10149{_}6082{_}This is all we have to of the immediate scene at the altar.
10149{_}6083{_}As soon as the benediction was pronounced, and the brides were released from the first embraces of their husbands, Mr. Effingham, without even kissing Eve, threw the shawls over their shoulders, and, taking an arm of each, he led them rapidly from the church, for he felt reluctant to suffer the holy feelings that were uppermost in his heart to be the spectacle of rude and obtrusive observers.
10149{_}6084{_}At the door, he relinquished Eve to Paul, and Grace to Sir George, with a silent pressure of the hand of each, and signed for them to proceed towards the Wigwam.
10149{_}6085{_}He was obeyed, and in less than half an hour from the time they had left the drawing-room, the whole party was again assembled in it.
10149{_}6086{_}What a change had been produced in the situation of so many, in that brief interval!
10149{_}6087{_}"Father!"
10149{_}6088{_}Eve whispered, while Mr. Effingham folded her to his heart, the unbidden tears falling from both their eyes--"I am still thine!"
10149{_}6089{_}"It would break my heart to think otherwise, darling.
10149{_}6090{_}No, no--I have not lost a daughter, but have gained a son."
10149{_}6091{_}"And what place am I to occupy in this scene of fondness?"
10149{_}6092{_}inquired John Effingham, who had considerately paid his compliments to Grace first, that she might not feel forgotten at such a moment, and who had so managed that, she was now receiving the congratulations of the rest of the party; "am I to lose both son and daughter?"
10149{_}6093{_}Eve, smiling sweetly through her tears, raised herself from her own father's arms, and was received in those of her husband's parent.
10149{_}6094{_}After he had fondly kissed her forehead several times, without withdrawing from his bosom, she parted the rich hair on his forehead, passing her hand down his face, like an infant, and said softly--  "Cousin Jack!"
10149{_}6095{_}"I believe this must be my rank and estimation still Paul shall make no difference in our feeling; we will love each other as we have ever done."
10149{_}6096{_}"Paul can be nothing new between you and me.
10149{_}6097{_}You have always been a second father in my eyes, and in my heart, too, dear--dear cousin Jack."
10149{_}6098{_}John Effingham pressed the beautiful, ardent, blushing girl to his bosom again; and as he did so, both felt, notwithstanding their language, that a new and dearer tie than ever bound them together.
10149{_}6099{_}Eve now received the compliments of the rest of the party, when the two brides retired to change the dresses in which they had appeared at the altar, for their more ordinary attire.
10149{_}6100{_}In her own dressing-room, Eve found Ann Sidley, waiting with impatience to pour out her feelings, the honest and affectionate creature being much too sensitive to open the floodgates of her emotions in the presence of third parties.
10149{_}6101{_}"Ma'am--Miss Eve--Mrs.
10149{_}6102{_}Effingham!"
10149{_}6103{_}she exclaimed as soon as her young mistress entered, afraid of saying too much, now that her nursling had become a married woman.
10149{_}6104{_}"My kind and good Nanny!"
10149{_}6105{_}said Eve, taking her old nurse in her arms, their tears mingling in silence for near a minute.
10149{_}6106{_}"You have seen your child enter on the last of her great earthly engagements, Nanny, and I know you pray that they may prove happy."
10149{_}6107{_}"I do--I do--I do--ma'am--madam--Miss Eve--what am I to call you in future, ma'am?"
10149{_}6108{_}"Call me Miss Eve, as you have done since my childhood, dearest Nanny."
10149{_}6109{_}Nanny received this permission with delight, and twenty times that morning she availed herself of the permission; and she continued to use the term until, two years later, she danced a miniature Eve on her knee, as she had done its mother before her, when matronly rank began silently to assert its rights, and our present bride became Mrs. Effingham.
10149{_}6110{_}"I shall not quit you, ma'am, now that you are married?"
10149{_}6111{_}Ann Sidley timidly asked; for, although she could scarcely think such an event within the bounds of probability, and Eve had already more than once assured her of the contrary with her own tongue, still did she love to have assurance made doubly sure.
10149{_}6112{_}"I hope nothing will ever happen to make me quit you, ma'am?"
10149{_}6113{_}"Nothing of that sort, with my consent, ever shall happen, my excellent Nanny.
10149{_}6114{_}And now that Annette is about to get married, I shall have more than the usual necessity for your services."
10149{_}6115{_}"And Mamerzelle, ma'am?"
10149{_}6116{_}inquired Nanny, with sparkling eyes; "I suppose she, too, will return to her own country, now you know every thing, and have no farther occasion for her?"
10149{_}6117{_}"Mademoiselle Viefville will return to France in the autumn, but it will be with us all; for my dear father, cousin Jack, my husband--" Eve blushed as she pronounced the novel word--"and myself, not forgetting you my old nurse, will all sail for England, with Sir George and Lady Templemore, on our way to Italy, the first week in October."
10149{_}6118{_}"I care not, ma'am, so that I go with you.
10149{_}6119{_}I would rather we did not live in a country where I cannot understand all that the people say to you, but wherever you are will be my earthly paradise."
10149{_}6120{_}Eve kissed the true-hearted woman, and, Annette entering, she changed her dress.
10149{_}6121{_}The two brides met at the head of the great stairs, on their way back to the drawing-room.
10149{_}6122{_}Eve was a little in advance, but, with a half- concealed smile, she gave way to Grace, curtsying gravely, and saying--  "It does not become _me_ to precede Lady Templemore--I, who am only Mrs. Paul Effingham."
10149{_}6123{_}"Nay, dear Eve, I am not so weak as you imagine.
10149{_}6124{_}Do you not think I should have married him had he not been a baronet?"
10149{_}6125{_}"Templemore, my dear coz, is a man any woman might love, and I believe, as firmly as I hope it sincerely, that he will make you happy."
10149{_}6126{_}"And yet there is one woman who would not love him, Eve!"
10149{_}6127{_}Eve looked steadily at her cousin for a moment, was startled, and then she felt gratified that Sir George had been so honest, for the frankness and manliness of his avowal was a pledge of the good faith and sincerity of his character.
10149{_}6128{_}She took her cousin affectionately by the hand, and said--  "Grace, this confidence is the highest compliment you can pay me, and it merits a return.
10149{_}6129{_}That Sir George Templemore may have had a passing inclination for one who so little deserved it, is possibly true--but my affections were another's before I knew him."
10149{_}6130{_}"You never would have married Templemore, Eve; he says himself, now, that you are quite too continental, as he calls it, to like an Englishman."
10149{_}6131{_}"Then I shall take the first good occasion to undeceive him; for I do _like_ an Englishman, and he is the identical man."
10149{_}6132{_}As few women are jealous on their wedding-day, Grace took this in good part, and they descended the stairs together, side by side, reflecting each other's happiness, in their timid but conscious smiles.
10149{_}6133{_}In the great hall, they were met by the bridegrooms, and each taking the arm of him who had now become of so vast importance to her, they paced the room to and fro, until summoned to the _dejeuner a la fourchette_, which had been prepared under the especial superintendence of Mademoiselle Viefville, after the manner of her country.
10149{_}6134{_}Wedding-days, like all formally prepared festivals, are apt to go off a little heavily.
10149{_}6135{_}Such, however, was not the case with this, for every appearance of premeditation and preparation vanished with this meal.
10149{_}6136{_}It is true the family did not quit the grounds, but, with this exception, ease and tranquil happiness reigned throughout.
10149{_}6137{_}Captain Truck was alone disposed to be sentimental, and, more than once, as he looked about him, he expressed his doubts whether he had pursued the right course to attain happiness,  "I find myself in a solitary category," he said, at the dinner- table, in the evening.
10149{_}6138{_}"Mrs. Hawker, and both the Messrs. Effinghams, _have been_ married; every body else _is_ married, and I believe I must take refuge in saying that I _will be_ married, if I can now persuade any one to have me.
10149{_}6139{_}Even Mr. Powis, my right-hand man, in all that African affair, has deserted me, and left me like a single dead pine in one of your clearings, or a jewel-block dangling at a yard-arm, without a sheave.
10149{_}6140{_}Mrs. Bride--" the captain styled Eve thus, throughout the day, to the utter neglect of the claims of Lady Templemore--"Mrs. Bride, we will consider my forlorn condition more philosophically, when I shall have the honour to take you, and so many of this blessed party, back again to Europe, where I found you.
10149{_}6141{_}Under your advice I think I might even yet venture."
10149{_}6142{_}"And I am overlooked entirely," cried Mr. Howel, who had been invited to make one at the wedding-feast; "what is to become of me, Captain Truck, if this marrying mania go any further?"
10149{_}6143{_}"I have long had a plan for your welfare, my dear sir, that I will take this opportunity to divulge; I propose, ladies and gentlemen, that we enlist Mr. Howel in our project for this autumn, and that we carry him with us to Europe.
10149{_}6144{_}I shall be proud to have the honour of introducing him to his old friend, the island of Great Britain."
10149{_}6145{_}"Ah!
10149{_}6146{_}that is a happiness, I fear, that is not in reserve for me!"
10149{_}6147{_}said Mr. Howel, shaking his head.
10149{_}6148{_}"I have thought of these things, in my time, but age will now defeat any such hopes."
10149{_}6149{_}"Age, Tom Howel!"
10149{_}6150{_}said John Effingham; "you are but fifty, like Ned and myself.
10149{_}6151{_}We were all boys together, forty years ago, and yet you find us, who have so lately returned, ready to take a fresh departure.
10149{_}6152{_}Pluck up heart; there may be a steam-boat ready to bring you back, by the time you wish to return."
10149{_}6153{_}"Never," said Captain Truck, positively.
10149{_}6154{_}"Ladies and gentlemen, it is morally impossible that the Atlantic should ever be navigated by steamers.
10149{_}6155{_}That doctrine I shall maintain to my dying day; but what need of a steamer, when we have packets like palaces?"
10149{_}6156{_}"I did not know, captain, that you entertained so hearty a respect for Great Britain--it is encouraging, really, to find so generous a feeling toward the old island in one of her descendants.
10149{_}6157{_}Sir George and Lady Templemore, permit me to drink to your lasting felicity."
10149{_}6158{_}"Ay--ay--I entertain no ill-will to England, though her tobacco laws are none of the genteelest.
10149{_}6159{_}But my wish to export you, Mr. Howel, is less from a desire to show you England, than to let you perceive that there are other countries in Europe--"  "Other countries!--Surely you do not suppose I am so ignorant of geography, as to believe that there are no other countries in Europe--no such places as Hanover, Brunswick, and Brunswick Lunenberg, and Denmark; the sister of old George the Third married the king of that country; and Wurtemberg, the king of which married the Princess Royal--"  "And Mecklenburg-Strelitz," added John Effingham, gravely, "a princess of which actually married George the Third _propria persona_, as well as by proxy.
